content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Responding To God
content.introtext: 'When I heard these words I sat down and wept...' Nehemiah 1:4 NRS<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150812.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Don’t feel like you’ve ever heard God’s clear–cut call for you? When you get an unshakeable sense of ‘I want to see change’ deep inside, you’re on to something. You might not feel like that about a particular issue right now but keep praying and you will. Let’s see what Nehemiah did when he heard God call him. The call to Nehemiah began with terrible news. God’s people were suffering and His holy city was destroyed. Nehemiah’s response was to sit down and weep. Bawl his eyes out. This is instinctive, natural and right. We talk a lot about being joyful in Church, but the Bible is also full of people weeping in response to the suffering they see. Their tears reflect God’s pain. When we see suffering, it *should* hurt us when we know it goes against the grain of God’s will for the world. And, before Nehemiah could even respond in sorrow, he had to hear the news. In the same way, we have to hear before we can respond. And to hear, we have to listen. We have to open our ears and hearts to news of places and people in need. We have to allow ourselves to be stirred, to feel discomfort. But, crucially, we’ve then got to follow it with action. Compassion is not just a feeling, it’s a response. Pick a situation around you or a story in the news you think needs to change, and take it to God and ask Him how and when you should get involved. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 16-18, Mark 5:21-30, Ps 119:49-56, Prov 21:4-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67728&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Asking For Help
content.introtext: 'If it pleases the King... I ask...' Nehemiah 2:5 NRS <br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150813.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Bring back to mind the situation or person you spent time thinking about yesterday. Time to work out how to respond. Nehemiah’s got this next step down. He asked for help, and not just from anyone. He went to the highest human authority available—the king. He felt no shame about appealing on behalf of his people to someone with some downright intimidating cred. Got a person or place on your heart? Don’t be ashamed to ask for help—or be too proud to ask those with power to help you. Some (in fact, most) tasks in God’s Kingdom will need more than a one–man band approach. Nehemiah knew he was doing the work of God, but he also knew that there were power structures in place that he had to work with to bring about Godly change. What’s more, the king he approached wasn’t a follower of God. The connections God will give you when you say ‘yes’ to His plan might not be ones you expect. Be open to His surprises. When God makes a way, He makes a way. So then, back to that situation or person you thought of yesterday. Who could you go to for help as you let God work in you? Is there someone in authority—a boss, a relative, a politician—you could ask? What support could they offer you? Are you brave enough to get on it? Share your concern for this place or person with at least one authority figure this week, and ask them for advice and support. You might be surprised by what they can do, and what support they offer you. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 19:1-23:20, Mark 5:31-43, Ps 119:57-64, Prov 21:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67729&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Get To Work
content.introtext: '...They replied, "Let us start rebuilding." So they began this good work.' Nehemiah 2:18 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150814.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Yesterday, we looked at sharing our call with others. After that, the best advice any of us will hear is simply: ‘make a start’. Taking the plunge is what stops your call from just being a dead–end. So why don’t we? We tell ourselves we don’t have the right things in place. Like: (1) ‘I’m not qualified’? Well, Kingdom work usually involves called (*not* qualified) people doing things they never dreamt of. (2) ‘People aren’t agreeing with me’? We’ll get into this tomorrow, but for now, know this: God’s people always get flak. David’s own brother took pot–shots at him before the Goliath fight, even calling him ‘evil’ (1 Samuel 17:28). (3) And what about ‘the timing isn’t right just yet’? Ecclesiastes 11:4 NIV says: ‘<em>Whoever watches the wind will not plant; whoever looks at the clouds will not reap</em>.’ If you’re looking for a sign that the time is right, you might end up missing it. Whatever you need, don’t be afraid to ask. Nehemiah went for it—he shared his plan with some friends, got them to commit, and then they began. In fact, the whole of chapter 3 is just a list of the different people who helped Nehemiah in different ways. He was humble enough to ask for help, and bold enough to confidently share his plan, knowing that it was worthwhile. Can you support a Christian group who are facing seriously difficult opposition and spreading the Gospel anyway? Prayer is a significant need. Consider an organisation like opendoors.org.au </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 23:21-26:19, Mark 6:1-13, Ps 119:65-72, Prov 21:10-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67730&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Unfamiliar Paths
content.introtext: 'Lord, let Your ear be attentive to the prayer of this Your servant...' Nehemiah 1:11 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150815.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Whether you have a clear–cut plan for the future or not, it’s always best to bring whatever we have to God in prayer. Often we’ve got a–million–and–one possible ideas for the future: excitement, back–up plans, ‘when I’ve got enough money’ plans... If that’s the boat you’re in, God will help you to narrow down the options, if you reciprocate that attentive ear thing (check out today’s verse), and listen right back to Him. Or perhaps, like a lot of us, you’re the opposite. The ‘what are you doing next year?’ question is one that haunts a lot of us, mostly because we’re pretty bad at getting hold of ideas for the futures. Wherever we find ourselves, it’s likely we’ll all benefit from a reminder: ‘…<em>along unfamiliar paths I will guide them; I will turn the darkness into light be-fore them and make the rough places smooth. These are the things I will do; I will not forsake them</em>.’ (Isaiah 42:16 NIV) Whether the ‘darkness’ is the sea of choices you feel you have to wade through, or a sense of blankness about the future, God will be there. We’ll be taking a last look at Nehemiah’s wall–building capers tomorrow, but for now, remember how much prayer he put in before he went along with God’s plan. Be encouraged: it’s not an overnight process. Just bring what you have before Him, and leave the ball in His court. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 26:20-29:30, Mark 6:14-29, Ps 119:73-80, Prov 21:14-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67731&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Swords and Trowels
content.introtext: '...Those who carried materials did their work with one hand and held a weapon in the other.' Nehemiah 4:17 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150816.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>So, Nehemiah took on God’s mission to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem. Good on him. Couldn’t be much better and easier, right? Hmmm. Actually, he faced pretty tough opposition: heavy criticism and even threats to his life. The reality is, when we follow out a call God has for our lives (no matter how big or small), there may be opposition. You could find that you’ll be struggling to carry out that call. Opposition is exactly what Nehemiah’s workers were ready for; they were building with a sword in one hand and a trowel in the other. When you’ve got a deep sense of God’s approval and conviction for a call, it’s important to get yourself grounded in it. Keeping a journal of the times you’ve prayed, and the ways you’ve found God responds, is a good way of doing this (hey, if you haven’t got a journal, maybe it’s time to splash out on one?), as well as listing some helpful Bible verses. Then, when you find yourself facing opposition, maybe even from your own doubts, those words will become your Ephesians 6:17 style defence. Let’s take the whole ‘following God’s call’ thing seriously. We humans come alive when God gives us a mission. It’s so worth catching hold of God’s short and long term plans for our lives. Write a Bible verse about God’s protection down (let’s call it your sword–verse). Write one about how to build your life around Him on another piece of paper (your trowel–verse). Hold one in each hand, and pray for Him to direct you in His plan. Carry the verses with you today. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 31:31-37, Heb 8:1-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67732&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Mixed Motives
content.introtext: 'Amaziah did what was pleasing in the Lord's sight, but not wholeheartedly.' 2 Chronicles 25:2 NLT<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150817.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Question: can we do things that God wants in a way which doesn’t put Him first? Yes, we can. This is exactly what 2 Chronicles tells us King Amaziah did. On the outside, he was doing all the right things, but his heart wasn’t in it. His heart was on his own agenda, his own desires. Hmmm. What’s that mean, then? First, a heart turned towards God, and towards serving others, is one that is wide open to God’s blessings. Our motives for doing things are, so often, mixed. The challenge for us, then, is this: ‘<em>Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God</em>.’ (Matthew 5:8 NIV) In our service, if we strip back the bits that point to us rather than Him, we’re clearing up the airwaves to see Him more clearly and let His blessings in. It’s always good to consider where our heart is when we give. How often have we thought: ‘This will make me look good. I wonder how many people saw me do that?’ The beauty of it is that we don’t need to give so God will mark off a few more brownie points for us on a ticklist. ‘<em>God loves a cheerful giver</em>.’ (2 Corinthians 9:7 NIV) He really does. The giving of our money, time and energy can be from gratitude to His love for us. That’s a win–win for everyone involved—we don’t need to impress anyone, and our lives become bigger. So, let’s make sure our motives for giving are right. Assess your giving, assess your motives, and pray them all through. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 1-4, Mark 6:30-44, Ps 119:81-88, Prov 21:17-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67733&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Wise Up!
content.introtext: 'Wise people are rewarded...' Proverbs 14:24 GNT<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150818.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>A (very) brief summary of Proverbs 14: wisdom is the best. Without it, you’re like someone who tears their house down (verse 1), will ‘believe anything’ (verse 15), and have no qualms about making rash decisions that don’t honour God (verse 16). Sounds like it might be useful, then. As well as the big–scale school/university/work decisions we make, we are faced with hundreds of different everyday courses of action to take ourselves. Whether it’s that link you shouldn’t click, that impulse buy you didn’t need, that drinking game your flatmates are playing, it’s wisdom that gives us an insight into what will help us to build our lives best. Essentially, being wise will help us to keep putting God (and others) first, creating a solid foundation in life. Is it something we’re left alone to teach ourselves, then? Do we have to make a few terrible decisions first before eventually narrowing down what we should really be up to? Thankfully, this doesn’t have to be the case. For Solomon, a pretty wise bloke, wisdom was about admitting that handling life’s situations is best done with God at the reigns (yes, that’s wordplay), not us (1 Kings 3:9). When we humble ourselves and admit that we don’t always know what’s best, God will strengthen our conscience to start knowing which way to go. Now get that journal (didn’t grab one the day before yesterday? Go grab one now... Good work.) Now, open it up and make two lists: one of what you want to learn and improve in yourself this month, and one of people or places you want to help practically and generously this month. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 5-7, Mark 6:45-56, Ps 119:89-96, Prov 21:20-23<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67734&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: It's Dangerous to Go Alone (1)
content.introtext: 'Share in the troubles we have like a good soldier of Christ Jesus.' 2 Timothy 2:3 NCV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150819.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>There are certain tactics the enemy will try use to get under our skin. Perhaps you’re feeling pressure from friends and family, or your own heart and head fill you with doubts, anxieties and temptations. It’s a serious matter, but sticking close to God gives us real strength when it comes to resisting Satan. The next few days are committed to helping us triumph when the carrot of giving up is dangling in front of us. Sometimes the world’s moving goalposts when it comes to morality are a constant temptation. Jesus spent a lot of time teaching us not to be anxious about getting by, but to influence the world as ‘<em>salt</em>’ and ‘<em>light</em>’ (Matthew 5:13–14). As hard as it is, ‘<em>Religion that is pure and undefiled before God, the Father, is this: to visit orphans and widows in their affliction, and to keep oneself unstained from the world</em>.’ (James 1:27 ESV) Corruption leads to distancing from God. Wince. Good news: none of us can survive on our own. In this letter to Timothy—a young Christian preparing to face the difficulties of leading a church and staying faithful to God’s call—Paul reminds him that, just as good soldiers will share the burdens and struggles of their mates, we should do the same. It is an encouragement to know that we can call on other Christians to step up and support us, to have our backs, and to feel our pain with us. It’s our duty too to do the same for others. So, encourage someone who needs it today. Share in their troubles, like a good soldier of Christ Jesus. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 8-11, Mark 7:1-13, Ps 119:97-104, Prov 21:24-27 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67735&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: It's Dangerous to Go Alone (2)
content.introtext: '...Make no provision for the flesh...' Romans 13:14 NAS<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150820.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>In Paul’s letter to the Church in Rome, he brings up a hugely important factor in the battle against Satan. Something that can, but really shouldn’t, be an elephant in the room—letting ourselves indulge in things (often secretly) that don’t honour God. Each day, we’re faced with a choice to ‘<em>cast off the works of darkness</em>.’ (Romans 13:12 ESV) We’ll be blunt here: if you’ve got a niggle that something might be a hindrance to you, it probably is. We can all think of things that we don’t want to (or don’t know how to) let go of. That website? That ego–boosting slice of gossip? Those thoughts? Behind the temptation to keep hold of those things and use them, there’s a much better life that God has called us to as a ‘<em>new creation</em>’ (2 Corinthians 5:17 NIV) in Him. To back that up with some serious God–protection, it’s vital to build our relationship with God, regardless of how well or badly we feel we’re doing—He invites us to <em>‘pray in the Spirit at all times and on every occasion.</em>’ (Ephesians 6:18 NLT) This makes it harder for just–this–one–time things to slip under the radar. God doesn’t need us to be perfect (which is good, since we aren’t), but cutting back the things that hinder you will change your life. Is it time for you to find an accountability partner? Choose someone who you can be honest with. Commit to regularly keep each other in check about the thing–(or things)–to–stop–doing that came to mind today. If you can, pray for each other too. Let’s get each others’ backs. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 12-15, Mark 7:14-23, Ps 119:105-112, Prov 21:28-31 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67736&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Give Up(wards)
content.introtext: 'Set your minds on things above, not on earthly things.' Colossians 3:2 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150730.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Matthew 6:24 NIV says: ‘You cannot serve both God and money.’ Right. Not a problem. Buying a few new t–shirts, when we already have a full ward-robe, isn’t ‘serving money’, is it? Possibly not. There’s nothing wrong in buying stuff. But we would ask you this… Did you ask God what He wanted you to do with that cash before splashing it? Now, this is NOT a guilt trip. Promise. It’s a reality check. Some inspiration to move forwards with. And it’s inspiration that we all need. We’ve all got to get our priorities straight. Everything we’ve got is a gift from God anyway. Our very lives, and everything in them, are given by Him, so we have a definite duty to invite Him to shine through them. That means offering everything back to Him, as soon as it lands in our lap (or, even, once we’ve worked our snowflake–patterned Christmas–in–July socks off for it). Whether it’s the $100 birthday money from granny, or the $2 you just found on the floor, God loves it when you give it back to Him. He won’t necessarily tell you to give $102 to charity/church/the homeless guy in town. He may just ask you to give a portion to one of them. But, if you take all your money to Him, you accept the risk that He may tell you to give away what’s left over, after you’ve paid your bills. In fact, scratch that, you don’t just ‘accept’ that risk. You’ll learn to delight in the God–given hazard of generosity. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Ezra 6-8, Mark 1:35-45, Ps 78:17-31, Prov 19:27-29 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67253&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Can't Touch This (Significance) (2)
content.introtext: <p>'Thank You for making me...' Psalm 139:14 NLT<br /><br /></p>
content.fulltext: <p><br />When you realise someone likes you as you are, it’s pretty great. Even when someone sheepishly says, ‘I maybe sorta kinda like you,’ it’s a massive confidence boost, right? It doesn’t even have to be romantic. It can be as straightforward as that person, the one you respect more than anyone, complimenting what you’ve done. It sticks with us when we know we’re appreciated. And that’s just when fellow humans value us! What about God? Yes, the God of creation, the same God who named the stars (Psalm 147:4) thinks more highly of you than He does the stars. Jesus says: ‘...<em>the very hairs on your head are all numbered</em>.’ (Matthew 10:30 NKJ) Your adoring fans might know your eye colour, what flavour you like your latté, or your favourite film. But the amount of hair on your head? Nah. God knows every detail about you, and loved you even before you knew Him (Ephesians 1:4). What does all this mean? God appreciates you. A lot. He values you more than you can imagine. The things that make you ‘you’ are given huge weight because of that. It’s good to remember that the best compliment, or the most alluring romance, can’t touch the significance you’ve already been given. And it’s good to remember that ‘re–member’ literally means to put back together again. Like Humpty Dumpty. So when you recollect and remember that God has made you, you’re doing something really wonderful. Particularly if you’re feeling fractured or broken today, find somewhere to be quiet and remember, and let Him put you back together again.</p> <p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Jn 3:11-5:21, Mark 2:23-3:6, Ps 78:56-64, Prov 20:7-10 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <em>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob &amp; Debby Gass)</em> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src="http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&amp;track=67719&amp;www=blog" alt="" width="0" height="0" /></p>

content.title: Created to Create
content.introtext: 'He...reveals His thoughts to man.' Amos 4:13 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150709.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>God is a creative God. He created something as delicately precise as atoms, neurons and quarks. He created something as grand and supersized as the IC1101 galaxy, which is estimated as 100 thousand light years across. God created Shakespeare and Picasso and your next door neighbour. The Piano Key butterfly gets a name from a stunning keyboard tattooed to its wings—again the work of Creator God. The shark, the wombat, jelly trifles, soap bubbles—they were all modelled at the hand of God. You get the idea: God is creative. Well, the Bible teaches we are made in the image of God—so if God is creative… yep, good guess, so are we. Ok, maybe you tend to colour outside the lines, sing like a strangled bullfrog or run like a demented crab—but in other unique ways you will reflect God’s creativity. Styling hair could be your thing. Or unravelling an equation. Or curling a free–kick. Or dissecting an aneurysm. Or turning over a sentence. Creativity doesn’t just happen in the art room. To some, God reveals beauty in mathematical sequences and scientific formulae; to others, He shows up in drama or paintings. However we’ve been wired; we’ve all received ‘creativity’. Not sure about that? You don’t have to class yourself as a ‘creative type’ to be able to bring ideas up that will bless people—we all have ways to reflect God’s creativity. When you tap into God’s creativity, He helps you see things not as they are, but as they can be. Today, do three creative things, in your own God–given way. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Eph 1:1-4:16, Matt 25:31-46, Ps 79, Prov 17:24-26 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67232&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Primed For Transformation
content.introtext: 'Be transformed by...renewing...your mind.' Romans 12:2 NKJ<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150710.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Romans 12 tells us to let the Holy Spirit transform us by ‘renewing...your mind.’ We can sometimes cringe at the notion of doing something that ‘isn’t me’. We tend to carve out a comfortable little possie for ourselves and that’s how the world comes to see us. And we buy into the world’s view! So when God comes along and tells the person who could never speak in class to preach to a large congregation, it’s hard to think anyone will take that seriously. Sometimes, though, we’re asked to challenge those expectations. God made us with purpose, value, dignity and worth, but along the way He’s still going to need to step in and grow us. As that emerges, of course we’re going to change. It’s practically a necessity if He’s fulfilling His purposes in us. When we don’t have the power or energy to change our own self–image, God does. In fact, whenever He calls us to do things we don’t see ourselves being capable of, He transforms us so that we can do whatever is needed. Like Op-timus Prime, we can be renewed and restored, and will come back kicking, with new Energon–like energy and power (perhaps minus the painted–on flames, though?) It’s not always easy to change others’ first impressions of us. We can don glasses but people won’t think we’re smarter. And, it can be even harder to change our own impression of ourselves. With God, though, real change happens. And those changes will eventually shine through. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Eph 4:17-6:24, Matt 26:1-13, Ps 109:1-15, Prov 17:27-28 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67233&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Kin, Not Clones (1)
content.introtext: 'May they be brought to complete unity.' John 17:23 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150711.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Truth time. We may not like to admit it, but sometimes we can subconsciously believe that we’re ‘better’ than someone else because we got this grade or that job. Our Church denomination is better or our social class is higher. John 17:23 tells us that God wants His children to be unified, and unity doesn’t allow for judgment. We can ignore lecturers and tolerate seemingly–silly ideas, with a forced smile, but our opinion of that other person has gone down. When this happens, immediately we’ve separated ourselves in spirit because of a difference of opinion. But we’re supposed to be different. God wants His children to be unified—but not by all being clones of each other. That said, ‘complete unity’ seems a tall order, doesn’t it? It is. Let’s be honest, it isn’t so easy to be unified with that guy who’s always one–upping you. We’ve all heard a bunch of talks or sermons about accepting people’s differences. We (probably) all agree with that rationally, and even in practice. What we’re likely to neglect is making accommodation in our mind for those who have a different way of thinking to us (ever got frustrated with someone who doesn’t do things your way?) That’s harder. But unity demands we learn to make room for others and respect their convictions. ‘Each one should be fully convinced in his own mind.’ (Romans 14:5 NIV) When you hear someone air an idea that opposes one of yours today, consider whether you’re actually listening, or if you’re just planning a lecture (even a silent–mental–lecture) entitled: ‘This is why you’re wrong.’ Really listen to what they say, and turn it into a fair conversation. You might learn something. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 1:1-3:21, Matt 26:14-25, Ps 109:16-31, Prov 18:1-3 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67234&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Kin, Not Clones (2)
content.introtext: 'Have fervent love for one another.' 1 Peter 4:8 NKJ<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150712.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>‘Do nothing out of selfish ambition…value others above yourselves.’ (Philippians 2:3 NIV) You’ve heard it a hundred times: the golden rule, love your neighbour, etc. So why do people still talk about valuing others above yourself when everyone’s heard it a million times? Well, your Mum told you that sprouts were good for you a million times but did you eat them? Yeah. See what we mean? Christians talk about loving each other all the time because it’s important. It’s one thing to know you should be unified, it’s another to put aside pettiness and actually work for it. What we do affects other people whether we think about it or not, and quite often, when we inadvertently hurt someone, we feel awful. Or we can try to justify it: We were ‘only following the rules’. But when somebody else’s action affects us, we don’t tend to offer the same courtesy we offer ourselves. We attribute blame and assume that we know that their intention was to hurt us. For some reason, we don’t expect from others the same human weaknesses that we have. Jesus told us that love trumps everything. Paul said, ‘Everything is permissible—but not everything is beneficial.’ (1 Corinthians 10:23 NIV) He was talking about doing things that are ok but that other people might find offensive. And he basically says: think twice... then think again. Holding onto the view ‘but I did nothing wrong’ for the sake of offended pride is not on. Holding onto the spirit of Scripture that Jesus taught (again, love) is on. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Gen 14:18-20, Ps 110, Heb 5:5-11 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67235&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Doing vs. Being
content.introtext: 'You cannot be fruitful unless you remain in Me.' John 15:4 NLT<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150713.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Jesus tells us straight up that our successes lie in Him. End of story. Unless we’re doing things in His name and with His backing, it’s not going to work out. We have a problem when we try to emulate Jesus, without Jesus. A lot goes into the running of a Church and, when you get to a certain point in your Church life, you might think about helping out. That’s brilliant. It’s a great thing to want to use your talent with technology to set up the sound equipment, or to use your awesome coffee–making–and–smiling–at–the–same–time skills in joining the refreshment team. Sometimes, though, we can get caught up in wanting to help. Suddenly, we’re on twelve different rotas and we never actually get to sit and listen to a sermon. We’re doing all these things for God, but if we’re not building our relationship with Him, then we lose track of why we’re doing those things in the first place. James 2:26 famously says that ‘faith without works is dead’. But works without faith aren’t alive, either. They become a façade, sometimes even an at-tempt to buy favour with God! It doesn’t matter if you look like a Super Christian outwardly, if you’re not right with God inwardly. When we stop doing things in Him, we can’t succeed, and our efforts become meaningless. Spend an hour today not doing anything but waiting on God. No matter how much work you have to do, clear your schedule just for one hour. Sit with your Bible and a pen, and maybe some Spirit–focussed music. But just *be* in that hour, don’t worry about *doing* anything. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 3:22-7:17, Matt 26:26-35, Ps 118:1-9, Prov 18:4-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67236&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Wait for it...
content.introtext: 'The Lord has need of him.' Luke 19:34 NKJ<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150714.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>When you’re a Christian it’s less–than–great not knowing how God wants to use you. When people all around are talking about their callings and all’s quiet on the Heaven–front for you, it can be disheartening. But remember that story about the colt Jesus rode into Jerusalem? That colt had never been ridden and was tied to a tree, overlooked and underestimated by the people around him. But Jesus had ‘need of him’ and knew the right time to call for him. Now, you’re not a baby horse (or a baby goat. Neigh, we kid you not), but the same applies in your life. You’ve heard that God has a plan for you and you may be wondering what that is (or not; if you already know, then that’s prettyyyy cool). However we have to remember that plans run on a schedule and, unlike ours, God’s plans tend to stay on schedule. He’s going to call you when He knows the time is right. That can be difficult to accept, but let’s face it, God’s plan is better than anything we could come up with. Jesus was never influenced by other people’s opinions. It didn’t matter that the colt was overlooked or the prostitute was looked down upon or that everyone hated the taxman, Jesus still loved them and had a purpose for them. He knows your value better than others do, and better than you do. So, try this reminder: when you’re making tea tonight, stop cooking halfway through and see if you’d want to eat it. Bet you’d rather wait until it’s cooked and ready. Some things you just have to wait for. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 7:18-11:27, Matt 26:36-46, Ps 118:10-18, Prov 18:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67237&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Muscle Memory Prayer (1)
content.introtext: 'Whatever you ask for in prayer, believe...and it will be yours.' Mark 11:24 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150715.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Let’s pray. Hands together. Sound like a familiar instinct? If you were taught to pray as a kid, it’s probably muscle memory. You likely also felt that rush of rebellion as you sneakily took a peek around the assembly hall to see if anyone ‘wasn’t praying right.’ But you’ve probably realised that God doesn’t care if your hands are together, at your sides, or raised in the air. Prayer isn’t about hand placement. There’s a cool thought from William Ward: ‘We stamp and address an envelope and send it on its way with complete confidence that it will reach its destination. Yet we wonder and even doubt if our prayers will be heard by an ever–present, ever–loving God.’ When Peter told a man who couldn’t walk to get up and go, it didn’t happen because he thought, half–heartedly, ‘Meh, might as well give it a go.’ It happened because he knew that God has real power, and would answer his prayer. God rewarded Peter’s sincere faith. We can get caught up in the words of a prayer or the length of it. It can be hard to remember that prayer is just a way of telling God that we’re ready and believing. Peter simply said, ‘In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk’ (Acts 3:6 ESV), and it happened. God knows already what we want to say. So pray in a way you’re comfortable with, and keep an eye out for answers. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 12:1-14:20, Matt 26:47-56, Ps 118:19-29, Prov 18:10-12 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67238&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Flexi-Time
content.introtext: <p>'The steps of a good man are ordered by the Lord.' Psalm 37:23 NKJ<br /><br />Ever been snowboarding or skiing? It’s all about knee–flexibility—the key to dealing with all the unexpected turns on the way. Too rigid, and you lose balance and fall over. Analogy–time… We all have ideas about how we’d like our lives to turn out: go to this uni, or get that job. And it’s perfectly fine (wise, even) to make plans for where we’d like to go or things we’d like to do. But we have to be careful. Head on over to James 4:13–16. (Ouch. James knows how to pack a punch.) James 4:16 NIV says that we ‘<em>boast in our arrogant schemes</em>.’ That’s where the problem lies, when it’s all about me me me, and we hold on so tightly to these plans. A good way to tell if our plans are problematic is if we honestly can’t imagine our lives without them. And of course, a good job or a loving spouse is awesome, but we shouldn’t need them to have a John 10:10 (‘<em>life to the full</em>’) kind of life. And because nothing (but God) is certain, we never know where we’ll end up. We reckon the help for our daily plans is knee–flexibility. We’ve got to be kneeling and praying constantly, to make sure our plans are God’s plans, and that our attitudes and actions are ones He wants us to have. Basically, praying James 4:15 NIV all the time—‘<em>If it is the Lord’s will, we will live and do this or that</em>.’ Check in with Jesus. Make ‘Jesus, what do you think of my plans?’ time today.</p> <p><br /><br />SoulFood: Acts 10-11; Matt 3:11-17; Ps 103:13-22; Pro 10:30-32 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob &amp; Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src="http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&amp;track=65570&amp;www=blog" alt="" height="0" width="0" /></p>

content.title: Love Your Church (7)
content.introtext: 'You too are being built together to become a dwelling in which God lives.' Ephesians 2:22 NIV<br /><br /><p>Stuff you might already know: Jesus gave His life for you. He died for you to bring you new life. Which is pretty awesome. And it doesn’t stop there. It’s not just an individual thing: ‘<em>Christ…loved the Church and gave Himself for her</em>.’ (Ephesians 5:25 NKJ) His design isn’t that you come to know Him and then carry on with your own thing exactly as before. In case you hadn’t noticed by now, we reckon doing this Church–as–body–in–community thing is really important. Realising who Jesus is and what He’s done for you is the vital first step, but God wants most of the other steps in your life to involve others who know Him: Hebrews 10:25 NIV instructs us to make sure we’re ‘<em>not giving up meeting together.</em>’ Why? Because when we’re together we’re ‘<em>a dwelling in which God lives by His Spirit</em>.’ (Ephesians 2:22 NIV) When we’re living our faith with others, we can have confidence that our efforts at being ‘Church’ isn’t a hit–and–miss ordeal. It’s God’s design. Welcoming newbies is important. The idea is to do it in the same way we’ve been accepted by God: ‘<em>Receive one another, just as Christ…received [you]</em>.’ (Romans 15:7 NKJ) And yes, that’s not a piece of cake. It’s probably several coffees, chats and relationship–building conversations later that a never–heard–much–of–Jesus/ isn’t–Church–for–old–people/ new–to–the–faith person will start to see what Church is meant to be. So whether your church life is tightly connected or you’re struggling to fit in, remember this: you’re not designed to do life on your own.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Heb 9:1-11:16; Luke 10:13-24; Ps 28; Pro 5:3-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65500&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Trust or Take?
content.introtext: 'Then Jesus was led by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted there by the devil.' Matthew 4:1 NLT<br /><br /><p>It’s the start of His public ministry. Jesus has walked into the desert, guided by the Holy Spirit. No food. No shelter. No friends. Why? He’s deliberately removed Himself from those helpful things in order to grow closer to His Father. But there’s a sly presence in the desert with Him, out to do Him real harm. The devil tempts Jesus to miraculously create His own food, throw Himself off a building and ask for unlimited power. The common factor in these temptations is this: ‘Stop trusting that Your Father cares for you. If God can’t provide food, protection, and purpose, then what’s He good for? Just take it Yourself.’ Jesus’ hunger and fatigue makes it an opportune moment for the enemy to launch an attack on the core of His love for His Father. Jesus (not just fully God, but also fully human, remember…) really could have chosen against His Father. But the immense trust Jesus chose to invest in Father God at this point strengthened Him on His lonely journey to the cross. He was leaving no space for any dangerous half–doubts as to whether His Father might have His back. The trust Jesus had for His Father was demonstrated through 40 tough desert days. Amazingly, we get given this faith as a gift. Where are you tempted to stop trusting that your Father cares for you and take things for yourself? Realise that these are opportunities to get closer to the Father, and turn in trust to Him.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 16:1-35; John 6:30-40 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65484&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Crafty As
content.introtext: 'Temptation comes from our own desires, which entice us and drag us away.' James 1:14 NLT<br /><br /><p>It’s a war out there. And the enemy can, and does, use your own moves against you. In yesterday’s story (if you read further in the Bible passage) Satan started mouthing off Scripture against Jesus. God’s own Word used against God. It might seem a bit of a weird strategy, but it’s something that can trip us all up and be used against us. Satan’s attempt to twist God’s powerful Word against God Himself was ingenious. Of course, because Jesus was on to it, He was able to identify the lies. But the attack strategy is still crafty as. How so? The enemy goes after our weak points, sure, but he also attacks our strengths and the things we lean on for support—places where we feel comfortable. Whether it’s your knowledge of the Bible, or some good thing you think you have complete control over (great self discipline, helpful conversations with others, a hobby you love), there’s a real danger to watch out for there. The enemy took Scripture out of context and attacked Jesus with it. Don’t let the enemy take good (even Godly) things out of their right context and use them to attack you. Instead do what Jesus did. The enemy used Scripture, and what did Jesus do? The same. ‘<em>Jesus responded, “The Scriptures also say, ‘You must not test the Lord your God.’”</em>’ (Matthew 4:7 NLT) Whatever you’re being tested with, even Scripture, getting to know your Bible better front–to–back will give you the context to spot the enemy’s craftiness.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 16-18; Luke 7:24-35; Ps 107:33-43; Pro 3:27-28<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65485&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Signs in the Dirt
content.introtext: 'My power works best in weakness.' 2 Corinthians 12:9 NLT<br /><br /><p>Know those times when one thing after another after another after another just seems to be going wrong? You’re not abandoned! Author CS Lewis wrote this in a letter to a good friend on January 20, 1942, at the very height of the Second World War: ‘No amount of falls will really undo us if we keep on picking ourselves up each time. We shall of course be very muddy and tattered children by the time we reach home. But the bathrooms are all ready, the towels put out, and the clean clothes are in the airing cupboard. The only fatal thing is to lose one’s temper and give it up. It is when we notice the dirt that God is most present to us: it is the very sign of His presence.’ CS Lewis knew that when we’re weak, messy and completely unable to save ourselves, then it’s God’s moment—if we let Him. At those times, we learn that He never wants us to have to do life all on our own. And we learn an almost secret truth: God doesn’t like it when we fall over, but He loves it if we turn to Him for help and allow Him to show Himself strong on our behalf. So, if you see one of those ‘ugh everything is going wrong’ Facebook statuses, then it’s time to pray for God to pick that person up from the dirt. Even if—<em>especially</em> if—the person is you. God’s power in your life shows itself most clearly at your point of weakness.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 19-21; Luke 7:36-50; Ps 111; Pro 3:29-30<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65486&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Be Prepared
content.introtext: 'Sensible people will see trouble coming and avoid it, but an unthinking person will walk right into it and regret it later.' Proverbs 27:12 GNT<br /><br /><p>Sometimes things just happen that trip you up, whether it’s within your family, your friendship group or something out of the blue. But just like King Solomon in the Bible tells us, we should be prepared for the toast to land butter side down. Ok, ok, he didn’t put it exactly like that but he did tell us days of trouble are inevitable. Why does the Bible record the failures of the greats like Abraham, Moses, Elijah and Peter? To give us hope; to let us know nobody performs flawlessly; to help us believe if they can do it then, by God’s grace, we can too. If you’re walking in God’s path, you’re bound to come across trouble. Satan doesn’t bother to lay traps on the wrong path. It’s when you’re on the right path, you’ll run into the most enemies, the most challenges (and the most adventure). The more we head in the direction God has laid out for us, the more the enemy is going to try and stop us from heading down it. So we need to anticipate trouble and avoid it. God promises that ‘<em>no weapon forged against you will prevail</em>.’ (Isaiah 54:17 NIV) And that’s why we can look ahead—knowing Satan hasn’t got power over the future. God’s got that. If you’re the kind of person who tends to think only in the moment, then pray to God that you develop a ‘trouble–sensor’ so you know ahead of time when to start presenting the problem to God.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 25-26; Luke 8:16-25; Ps 120; Pro 3:33-35<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65488&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Practise Peace
content.introtext: 'Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God.' Matthew 5:9 NIV<br /><br /><p>Being willing to look past differences; commending people to each other; tactfully steering on–the–edge conversations in a different direction; this is the stuff that a peacemaker should be geared up for. ‘<em>You’ll be called children of God</em>,’ says Jesus about these sorts of people. That’d be a fairly cool thing to be called by someone (and by Jesus Christ, no less.) Hmm. But what if you’re not the peaceable sort, deep down? What if inner turmoil, unresolved issues or a few weighty chips on your shoulder are stopping you from building bridges of peace with other people? A good place to start would be this: do you want to feel anger whenever you think of specific people who get on your nerves, or would you rather be reconciled with them? Are you quite happy to carry on feeling anxious about by them, or would you rather feel at ease even with people who bother you? The bonus about any decision to be a peacemaker is it heightens your own sense of wellbeing. Still God wants you to be a peacemaker for the other person’s sake. Start by asking Him, not for a nice peaceful vibe for yourself, but for genuine patience with especially difficult people. Pray for them and plan ahead as to how you might respond to conflict or argument. Commit to practising peace with them. And, all through the process, keep talking to God about the situation.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 27-29; Luke 8:26-39; Ps 67; Pro 4:1-2<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65489&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Jesus No Grudge, You No Grudge
content.introtext: '...forgiveness of sins, in accordance with the riches of God's grace.' Ephesians 1:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>In the Gospel stories we come across a man called Peter, famous for his brash declarations of love for Jesus, and then skittishly running away from his own words. He was one of Jesus’ disciples and he messed up, big time. Even though he promised he’d always follow Jesus whatever the cost, when it came to the crunch he denied (three times...) that he even knew Him. Dark days. But when Jesus met him after His resurrection He did an amazing thing—He forgave him without hesitation. Then Jesus told him, ‘<em>Follow me</em>.’ God is always willing to forgive you if you repent when you’ve messed up, so that it doesn’t get in the way of your relationship with Him. A mate hurt you? Jesus still forgave Peter even though he had right royally failed Him. Jesus didn’t hold a grudge. Not for Peter, and not for you when you mess up too. ‘<em>In accordance with the riches</em>’ of that grace, make sure you’re not holding grudges against a person. God is not finished with them yet—so should you be? In the meantime, He doesn’t want us grudge–keeping. Can you match that? Before you take communion at church this week, get in touch with someone who you feel you’ve broken off communication with, whether your fault or theirs. Jesus tells us: ‘<em>Leave your gift there in front of the altar. First go and be reconciled...then come and offer your gift</em>.’ (Matthew 5:24 NIV) That’s crystal clear as to what we should do to reconcile with people—so see how this will help with your relationships in general.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 30:1-32:24; Luke 8:40-56; Ps 125; Pro 4:3-4 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65490&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Look Where You're Going
content.introtext: 'I press on toward the goal for the prize.' Philippians 3:14 NIV<br /><br /><p>You could spend a day on YouTube looking up videos of people doing stupid things in public who then wished the ground would swallow them up. Never mind stupid public moments—it’s far more painful when we feel that way about our sin. Sometimes we can look back on our lives and still feel ashamed about the stuff we did around people, even though we’ve already been through the process of saying sorry to God and them. We can’t change our past (despite Doctor Who/Marty McFly/all other time travellers) and sometimes our mistakes do have long–term consequences, but God calls us to look forward, not back. We can learn from our mistakes without dwelling on them. That’s what Paul was getting at when he said: ‘…<em>forgetting what is behind and straining towards what is ahead</em>.’ (Philippians 3:13 NIV) So, next time you find yourself looking back, remember that (a) you’ll probably trip over if you’re not looking where you’re going (which would just be another moment to add to that embarrassing fails list) and (b) believers are forgiven. God’s already got your back. Turn and face the future. If you don’t, it’ll be like putting a cup of water on a table, turning your back and trying to pick up the cup with two hands. Pretty tricky, right? But that’s just what it’s like when we try to grasp God’s truth still looking the other way—it’s a mess waiting to happen. So keep yourself pointed in God’s direction: He’s on your side and wants you to look ahead with Him.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Isa 53:1-12; Acts 8:26-40 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65491&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: A Warehouse of 'Stuff'
content.introtext: '...Life does not consist in an abundance of possessions.' Luke 12:14 NIV<br /><br /><p>Why does it seem like God is so against us wanting the good stuff in life? Well, maybe He’s not. Sometimes we get caught up in chasing the stuff that we believe is good, and neglect the real, Godly, ‘good stuff’. Since God made us, He alone knows what can, and will, truly satisfy us. Jesus’ parable in Luke 12:16–21 talks about a guy who goes after all the best stuff (in this case, crops), and thinks if he stores it all up he’ll be fine. But here’s the problem, if we do like this guy did and go filling up our metaphorical barns with crops/clothes/other–delicious–but–worldly–stuff, we leave little room for God (look at verse 21). With no room for God, we push away the offer of salvation and leave no opportunity for Him to fill, renew and change us. We also miss out on sharing the truly good stuff with others. Let’s put it like this: if you had a warehouse full of clothes, you’d have decent threads for a lifetime (especially if you’re not sharing them...) But fill it with God and you’d not only have an abundance of His deep–joy bringing presence, but it’s the sort that only increases when you share Him with others. Having ‘stuff’ isn’t wrong; in fact, God can bless others through it. Open up your barn and have a look at what you have stored there. What has taken the place of God and can be shared with others?</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 32:25-33:56; Luke 9:1-17; Ps 134; Pro 4:5-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65492&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Bee-Sting
content.introtext: 'God is working in you, giving you the desire and the power to do what pleases Him.' Philippians 2:13 NLT<br /><br /><p>Here’s a question: what are you afraid of? Bees, spiders, maybe even just the dark? Here’s an even bigger question: are you afraid of using your God–given abilities? Ouch. That last one might have had more sting than a bee, because it’s often something we struggle with. The ‘but–I’m–not–good–enough’ culture makes its way around the church. A lot of the time we naturally strive to be the best we can be; we love to succeed. But there’s a difference between serving God and striving for ourselves. God isn’t after the world’s view of ‘success’. He’s after a sincere heart and a disciple ready to use their gifts for His glory. 2 Chronicles 16:9 NIV says: <em>‘For the eyes of the Lord range throughout the Earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to Him.</em>’ Wow, sounds pretty big, right? It is. And we don’t get left with a flat–pack and a confusing manual. God encourages us through His Word (the Bible), and we’re told to use our gifts to benefit others and to bring glory to His name (take a look at Romans 12:6–8). So, next time you feel a bit hesitant about your abilities, remember whose strength you’re relying on, and be encouraged to start to use them. Get a wise friend or older Christian to pray with you about the desires and passions God is putting on your heart. Write them down and ask God to use them in the right way as well as take the sting from any anxiety you have. Let go of your fear!</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 34-36; Luke 9:18-27; Ps 138; Pro 4:14-17 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65493&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Church (1)
content.introtext: 'Christ loved the church and gave Himself up for her.' Ephesians 5:25 NIV<br /><br /><p>Perfect worship, faultless preaching, sinless people and delicious food. Sounds like the perfect church? Yes. Does it exist? No. (And not just because church food normally consists of budget biscuits.) Even though we know the perfect church doesn’t exist, we can still find ourselves complaining about the Church* instead of doing something about it. In Ephesians 5:22–33 we get some pretty direct instructions about our attitude towards the Church. The passage describes Jesus as the head of the Church (Ephesians 5:23) and us as His bride (Ephesians 5:24–25). It’s a pretty picture, but what does it actually mean? It means we should respect and love the Church, being keen to see it grow and develop to become more like what Jesus desires. How does that happen? In verse Ephesians 5:29 we’re reminded that just like our human bodies, the Church needs nourishment—in the form of a real, meaty, Bible–based diet that comes from Christ. It also talks about Jesus caring for the Church, something we should be passionate about too. We need to care about the future of the Church, even when it’s looking more like bride–zilla than wife material. And this change of attitude starts with us! Jesus loves your church with all its imperfections—look at it the way He does.</p> <p><small>* <em>Church (big C) = the name for all of God’s people, through all time; church (little c) = the name for one group/meeting/meeting place of God’s people.</em></small></p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jonah 1-4; Luke 9:28-36; Ps 141; Pro 4:18-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65494&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Church (2)
content.introtext: 'And you are living stones that God is building into His spiritual temple.' 1 Peter 2:5 NLT<br /><br /><p>Right, so we go to church but we are the Church? The Oxford English Dictionary describes ‘church’ as ‘a building used for public Christian worship’. But not everyone will set foot into a church building in their lifetime (some people actively avoid it), so we need to take Church to them. We’re like a motorhome of worship. Which kind of puts today’s verse into a bit more context—being living stones, we can take ‘church’ past the four walls of the building. Great, but do we have the authority and ability to do that? Well, 1 Peter 2:9 NIV describes us as ‘<em>a royal priesthood</em>’ and ‘<em>a holy nation</em>’, which basically means that, having been the recipients of God’s mercy, we’re now accredited trainers (authorised) in God’s love. That’s quite a big deal. What about the ability part, though? Are we strong enough to be Church in the real world? Yep, God’s got that covered too. We’re ‘<em>living stones</em>’ (1 Peter 2:5 NIV) because life’s been breathed into us through the Holy Spirit. Think of that as super–powered Spirit–petrol in the tank. We go out in Christ–led, Spirit–filled power, and we have a pretty amazing example to follow in Jesus, the cornerstone: take a look at Ephesians 2:20. The cornerstone is the first stone set in the foundation of a building. It’s super important, because all other stones are arranged around this particular stone. Ask God how you can be a ‘living stone’ to build the body of Christ—the Church, remembering that Jesus loves His Church.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Titus 1-3; Luke 9:37-45; Ps 145:1-13; Pro 4:20-22 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65495&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Church (3)
content.introtext: 'The glory of the Lord filled the house of the Lord.' 1 Kings 8:11 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Have a read of 1 Kings 8:1–21. Let’s set the scene: King Solomon has built this incredible temple. If temples were cars, this one would have been a Ferrari. Having taken seven years to build it, it was worth having a bit of a celebration, so he invited lots of important people to bring the Ark of the Covenant (the holy box with the original stones of the Ten Commandments inside) inside. They put it in the inner sanctuary, the Most Holy room (1 Kings 8:6). And then God showed up. His glory came in a cloud, and He filled the temple (1 Kings 8:10). Pretty cool, but what does it all mean in our modern day Church? It means that, if we want to be people filled with God’s presence (you know, now that we’re the walking, talking temple of the Holy Spirit… see 1 Corinthians 6:19–20) we’ve got to ensure that God takes centre stage in the Church. Not a worship leader or preacher. The Ark of the Covenant was less about the objects it contained and more about the fact it meant that the presence of God was with them. Reminder time: get a bit arty and cut a cloud shape out of some paper, write 1 Corinthians 6:19 (‘<em>Do you not know that your bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God? You are not your own.</em>’) on the back and put it in your purse/wallet as a reminder that God’s presence lives in you. You are meant to make a difference wherever you go as you carry God’s glory.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Thess 1-5; Luke 9:46-56; Ps 145:14-21; Pro 4:23-24 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65496&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Church (4)
content.introtext: 'The many parts make up one whole body.' 1 Corinthians 12:12 NLT<br /><br /><p>So, the Church is a body (Have a read of 1 Corinthians 12:12–31). Heard it before? Well here is some deeper stuff to take note of in that body analogy: (1) <em>We need each other</em>. People can offer stuff you can’t, and you can offer stuff other people need. We need to be inter–dependent (1 Corinthians 12:21–22). (2) <em>Unity is major</em>. This means we need to be willing to work together. It doesn’t mean we have to all like the same stuff or even agree on every topic. (Unity doesn’t mean we should compromise on the essentials of the faith.) (3) <em>All body parts are important</em>. Without ears we can’t hear, but if the whole body were an ear it wouldn’t be a body anymore (1 Corinthians 12:17–20). It would just be one gigantic mutant ear—useless. And weird. (4) <em>We need to be more like a real body</em>. Paul is chatting about stuff that could never happen in a physical body—a foot couldn’t get jealous and wish it was a hand. And yet, in the body of Christ it happens. How do we guard against it? We choose to love the diversity in the Church and we exercise whatever our particular body part is. When we stretch our body and get on with serving we will be growing and strengthening the Church. Individual but working inter–dependently…mutant ear avoided. Think of a three–legged race. It’s a joint effort, right? Just like that, we’ve got to get in step with others in Church and be willing to work together as one body.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Heb 1-4; Luke 9:57-62; Ps 149; Pro 4:25-27 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65497&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Church (5)
content.introtext: 'If My people who are called by My name will humble themselves...' 2 Chronicles 7:14 NKJ<br /><br /><p>So, we’ve established that Church is a place for not–perfect people, that you’ve got a part to play, and that it’s all about God. So what about when we get it properly right? How do we keep it up? If a church is doing well, and is full of the glory of God, then the only way it will keep itself from an ego–overload is by passing that glory straight back to Jesus. Yes. All of it. In the book of 2 Chronicles, you’ll find even more about Solomon’s temple. God promised to carry on working with the people (and us) to ‘<em>forgive their sin and heal their land</em>’ (2 Chronicles 7:14 NIV), if we do a very important thing: Get humble. The Hebrew in today’s verse for the word ‘humble’ is <em>kana′</em>, meaning ‘<em>to bring low</em>’. This can be done by prayer, in the first place. The best kind of prayer is supposed to be simple—we can pray when we see or hear about someone. Saying sorry (out loud, not to yourself) and not holding people’s pasts against them are two humility top–ups. Knowing how much God has done on our part already (giving His Son Jesus) is the key to this. That’s what ‘lowering’ yourself looks like (see Hebrews 2:9. Also Philippians 2:7–8.) Humility isn’t just a way to put others first, it’s also a way to protect yourself when things are going really well for you. ‘<em>God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble</em>.’ (James 4:6 NKJ) Today, look for a way to delight in a situation where someone else is being blessed.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Isa 9:1-7; Luke 2:1-7; Matt 4:12-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65498&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Church (6)
content.introtext: 'The Lord will lift up a standard [shield of defence].' Isaiah 59:19 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Solomon had some serious confidence in God. Check it out in 2 Chronicles 6:26–31. He’s pretty confident that life won’t be easy for God’s people, so he doesn’t wait around; he brings it before God. Then what? He recognises the need for God’s people to bring everything before God together: ‘<em>When a prayer or plea is made by anyone among your people Israel</em>.’ (1 Kings 8:38 NIV) And he trusts that God will keep them close, so that they can ‘…<em>fear you and walk in obedience to you.</em>’ (2 Chronicles 6:31 NIV) Quite a nice little pray–obey–pray cycle there. See, God wants us to rally together with other Christians and pray. Does it grab God’s attention and remind Him to ‘<em>lift up a shield</em>’ (Isaiah 59:19) for you? Not really—God is not ‘forgetful’. But how much stronger and life–impacting can faith be when we remember we’re not alone? Prayer solidifies a higher–than–just–church–friends bond: regardless of what you’re praying for, it’s been a fact through the ages that ‘<em>He who dwells in the secret place of the Most High shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty</em>.’ (Psalm 91:1 NKJ) So, when we dwell in that prayer–place at the same time as others, we’re drawn together under God’s protective shadow. Praying together keeps you vulnerable to each other, protected by God, and your faith is stronger when shared. If your church runs a regular prayer meeting (the chances are good), go along. If there’s not one, why don’t you ask to arrange one? There’s always something to pray about—whether it’s thanks, or prayer in a time of need.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Heb 5-8; Luke 10:1-12; Ps 5; Pro 5:1-2 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65499&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Church (8)
content.introtext: '...after you have suffered a while, the God of all grace will perfect, establish, strengthen, and settle you.' 1 Peter 5:10 NKJ<br /><br /><p>God sees the Church as finished—‘<em>complete in Him</em>.’ (Colossians 2:10 NKJ) The Church is as saved right now as we’ll be when we stand in Heaven. But, yeah, look up the news headlines. Chances are if you scroll enough, the Church will be mentioned in there somewhere, looking as if we’re making gigantic idiots of ourselves. (Sometimes it’s media bias but sometimes we really <em>are</em> being foolish.) Some Christians would rather only think about the Church in its perfected, free–from–sin state, in Heaven. Great. But. Looking only at that understanding of Church takes our eye off the reality of the broken brothers and sisters around us who aren’t perfect, who need our prayers and practical help now. It also stops us looking out for the glorious moments when that perfect Church breaks through into this world, and makes us less keen for the process of a community growing together through the Spirit. ‘<em>We all…beholding as in a mirror the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image…by the Spirit of the Lord</em>.’ (2 Corinthians 3:18 NKJ) That’s today, now. The Holy Spirit is at work in Church life every day, in every way (really), moulding us into the image of Jesus. That means we don’t look only to the one–day–will–be perfect Church, or look only at the messy, broken Church as it is today, but look to the Christ at the centre, where all is stillness and He remains the same, being powerful to change us. Give thanks that God loves His Church, right now, just as it is! And pray that the Church can look outward to those who need it.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Num 6:1-21; Matt 4:1-17; Mark 2:18-22; Luke 9:23-26 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65501&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Lonely God?
content.introtext: 'He departed again to the mountain by Himself alone.' John 6:15 NKJ<br /><br /><p>If you were always wandering off alone at random points in the day, people would slap a label on you pretty fast: loner, likes your own company, drifter, introvert, whatever. They’d be wondering what you were doing. Just as Jesus’ friends wondered about His times alone in the mountains. Was this just a bit of Me–time? What was Jesus doing up before dawn? He’d disappear whenever people wanted something more from Him, like trying to make Him king. Was something else going on? Jesus was away from anyone else on earth, but this wasn’t space for Me–time. It was time to spend with His Father—real time, in real conversation. What was the draw? Along with all the helpful prayer requests that He was probably dropping in, He was also getting back to His source. He was making sure to keep firmly in control of a life that could have been pulled away from His Father by so many distractions. He was grounding it in real experiences of joyful meeting with Him. Can you really have that shared space with God in a way that charges you with joy, launches you into the day with a spring in your step? Yes. Your time with God is not your alone time. You’re sharing it. Make your time with God your well–kept secret. Have a regular early morning space with Him (or if you have that anyway, take it extra slow) and, without making it about you, see if other people notice the difference in you.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Heb 11:17-13:25; Luke 10:25-37; Ps 33:1-12; Pro 5:7-14 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65502&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your 'Enemies' (1)
content.introtext: 'Pray for those who spitefully use you and persecute you.' Matthew 5:44 NKJ<br /><br /><p>When the old ‘<em>love your enemies</em>’ verse gets quoted too many times, it becomes easy to ignore. ‘<em>Enemies</em>’ can become a big group that includes the sort of people who lightly tread your personal like/dislike line, not just the people who are more than intolerable and fry your brain when you think about them. Today’s translation of the verse gives it back some of the ‘meat’ it might be missing for you. ‘<em>Those who spitefully use you</em>.’ Mmmh. That’s beyond ‘sort of enemy’ status, that hits some bitter ground. Try thinking of people who make you feel like that. Thinking about people who have hurt you is hard, and it can cause you to take out your anger in other ways—like punching pillows or writing furious blogs. This is a common way we try to ‘get over’ our anger, but it’s scientifically a bit questionable: all it does is reinforce the anger mode in your brain. And now some actual practical help: you can make some gestures of helping and loving people you really dislike, but getting to the place where you can genuinely love your enemies from your heart might mean going through a few stages first. So. Part one of the process. If you’re struggling to get rid of some anger, try this. Just stop. Tell God how angry you are. He’s ok with that. (See, for instance, Psalm 83 where Asaph told God just exactly what he’d like done to His enemies.) Then ask God for help to park up those feelings for the moment, so you get on with your day. Come back tomorrow and we’ll talk more about dealing with this most difficult of problems.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 1-2; Luke 10:38-42; Ps 33:13-22; Pro 5:15-20 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65503&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Love Your Enemies (2)
content.introtext: 'Then the Lord said, "Is it right for you to be angry?"' Jonah 4:4 NKJ<br /><br /><p>‘Don’t complain. That attitude isn’t of God. Just rejoice!’ How many times have you heard that, or a variation of that, in church? Anger gets a bad rep in Christian circles. Lots of ‘super–holy’ people see it as just cynicism or bitterness, and not something a good church–goer should be going through. Jonah’s bitterness against a whole city of people nearly took him over the edge, to the point where he could have happily watched that whole community, kids and all, burn to the ground. God waited with Jonah, showing him His patience and wanting him to share in it. So, yes, anger’s not something to dwell on. But it’s so much worse to pretend to be happy and ‘over it’ when you’re actually broiling with anger. Breaking the pattern means taking the anger to God as often as it bubbles up. That way, you can be freed to love your enemies from the heart. Feeling anger isn’t wrong. Letting it take root is. To stop it taking root, though, you have to process it (work through it) and do what it takes to get it out of your system. How? When the feeling rises, know it for what it is—‘this is anger’—without trying to pretend you don’t feel it. Then, examine where it’s coming from—‘is this from a real wrong that’s been done to me? Is my reaction legit?’ —and talk out what caused (not how angry you are) it with a trusted and wise friend.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 3-5; Luke 11:1-13; Ps 36; Pro 5:21-23 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65504&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>
