content.title: Care Enough to Confront
content.introtext: 'Warn... those who are out of line.' 1 Thessalonians 5:14 AMP<br /><br /><p>We tend to shy away from confronting others with truth. ‘Why can’t we just sit back and let people get on with whatever they want?’ Answer: ‘We’re all part of the Body of Christ—the Church.’ And the healthier/less distracted we (the parts) are, the more effective we’re likely to be, as a whole Church. See, if we’re saturating ourselves in God–time, getting closer to Him and His will, things that don’t match His will start to stand out. Look up at today’s verse: it’s up to us to call others out when it seems they’re straying. But, how do we do that without: (a) <em>Getting proud of ourselves for not falling into the same trap</em> and/or (b) <em>Going in all–guns–blazing and causing more harm than good</em>? Well, Paul says: ‘…<em>be patient with everyone</em>.’ (1 Thessalonians 5:14 NIV) That way, those we need to confront may be patient with us. And, recognising that sin isn’t a public affair. Jesus tells us to always begin the ‘you’re–a–bit–wrong–there’ process with a private conversation (Matthew 18:15–17). Here it is then: confronting someone if they seem to be straying from God–ideals isn’t a bad shout. But ‘<em>speaking the truth in love</em>’ (Ephesians 4:15) needs care and attention. Not willing to do more than just tell someone off, nor to help them through a rough patch? Might be worth praying about whether you should be the one to approach them. Has God placed people in your life recently to confront you to guide your actions? If so, be grateful. Thank them for it.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Ps 23; John 10:7-18 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65505&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Not My Will, But Yours God
content.introtext: 'In everything set them an example...' Titus 2:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>Throughout the Gospels, you’ll be able to see that Jesus’ whole life was about showing mankind how to live. The time between Him coming to earth and Him giving His life up to save us wasn’t just ‘filling in’ time; it was when He lived out the perfect way of how to be human. ‘<em>Believe me when I say that I am in the Father and the Father is in Me; or at least believe on the evidence of the works themselves</em>.’ (John 14:11 NIV) Jesus tells us the things He spent His life on earth doing reflected the very nature of God. Whoever was watching Him was being shown a reflection of Love. And, because every action was centred in His being God, there’s proper integrity (Titus 2:7) from one action to the next. Jesus’ integrity is entirely based in the love of God, and that love is in every action. That means that, when He said, ‘<em>Father, if You are willing, take this cup from Me; yet not My will, but Yours be done</em>’ (Luke 22:42 NIV), He was wholeheartedly admitting that He wasn’t looking forward to being nailed to a cross (understandably). But… He was also saying that He loves us enough (He loves you and me enough), to have the integrity to go through with His Father’s will rather than submit to His own human vulnerability. That’s consistency for you. And that’s our example—love–inspired integrity to do God’s will, over any of our own human fear or dismay. So, follow His example and pray ‘not my will, but Yours’ in your time with God today.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 6-7; Luke 11:14-28; Ps 40:1-8; Pro 6:1-5 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65506&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Everyone's a Winner
content.introtext: '...that you may be successful wherever you go.' Joshua 1:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>‘That you may be successful wherever you go’. How lovely. Being a Christian means success in all areas. Win. Go be prosperous in every way. End of reading? Wait! Let’s back this truck up a bit. Grab a Bible. Flick to Joshua 1:7, and read all of it. Right. According to that, true success only stems from following God’s laws carefully and consistently. And if success is defined by obedience to God, then it doesn’t always mean being an Oscar–winning actor/supermodel/wealthy philanthropist. Those who are definitively ‘successful’ in the eyes of the world aren’t necessarily God–defined ‘successful’. Their obedience to God is between them and Him, so only He knows if they, and we, are successful in the real sense of the word. In fact, let’s talk about that. The real sense of the word. The original root of the word ‘success’ comes from the Latin <em>succedere</em>, which means two things—‘to follow after another’ and ‘to ascend, or go up’. That’s pretty much the handiest hint to being successful ever. Think about it. If you’re following someone (Jesus, we hope…), straining upwards towards their standards, growing towards them, ascending, and keeping your eyes aloft, then you’re ‘<em>succedere</em>’–ing. If you’ve made the decision to follow Jesus Christ, you’re successful. By default. You, friend, are already a winner. Regardless of situations, outcomes, or whatever–you–feel–right–now, you are succeeding at life. It may be almost a Christian cliché, but give Romans 8:28 a read. Chew it over, and give it proper consideration.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 8-9; Luke 11:29-44; Ps 40:9-17; Pro 6:6-8 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65507&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Homeward Bound
content.introtext: 'Either way, Christ's love controls us.' 2 Corinthians 5:14 NLT<br /><br /><p>Paul said, ‘<em>Whatever we do, it’s not for our gain, but because Christ’s love controls us.</em>’ Paul regularly introduces himself as ‘a servant’ for Christ. We’ve often heard it said that ‘God isn’t looking for slaves.’ Well. Maybe He sort of is, but it’s not in the way we think. God isn’t looking for forced labour from vulnerable oppressed workers. The New Testament word <em>doulos</em> is actually a word that we also translate as ‘slave’. It means ‘bondservant’: someone who is bound, tied, to serve someone. Quite a physical description actually. Imagine being tied to your work… or worse, your teacher or your boss. Being ‘bound’ to something doesn’t match our ideals of wanting to be free. It also doesn’t match up with our idea that Jesus has won us freedom, and taken our burdens away. But how about this: What if our response to Jesus doing that amazing work for us was to look Him in the face and say, ‘Thank You Lord! However I can honour You, please let me!’ What if our love for Him, our love for seeing Him given the glory He deserves, would be enough to make us all passionately want to be ‘slaves’ of His Kingdom of freedom? Again, it’s not about forced labour… but our love compelling us? That’s a different matter altogether. First, spend time talking to Jesus about what He’s done for you. Now, if you want a symbolic and prophetic reminder, get a piece of string or ribbon and tie it around your wrist for the day, to remember Who you’re ‘bound’ to, and why.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 10-11; Luke 11:45-54; Ps 53; Pro 6:9-11 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65508&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: You're Protected From Evil (1)
content.introtext: 'No evil shall be allowed to befall you...' Psalm 91:10 ESV<br /><br /><p>How much of our time is spent worrying about stuff that doesn’t matter? What we’re actually doing is giving a situation or a person a high standing they don’t deserve. This leads to the matter getting out of proportion, and occupying a bigger brain–space than it ought to do. As Christians, we have a God–given arsenal of tools for us to stand our ground. We can stand firm against Satan’s schemes, ‘<em>for God has not given us a spirit of fear and timidity, but of power, love, and self–discipline.</em>’ (2 Timothy 1:7 NLT) Thing is, we often forget how much God really has our backs. Passages like Psalm 91:10–11 NLT remind us that God is absolutely working for our good—He places angels to guard us from evil: ‘<em>For He orders His angels to protect you wherever you go</em>.’ Not a trace of dictatorship. There is a good type of ‘fear’, though. If God provides for our every need (with angels thrown in, and all), what’s there to be afraid of? The ‘fear of God’ is different. It’s about reverence; it’s about our need to recognise the place that God has in creation—He’s infinitely higher than us. To ‘fear’ Him means to be in awe of His majesty and accept Him as no less than incomparable. Then, everything (including every other fear…) will find its place under Him. So now, take a moment to name one of your fears. Speak it out. Now imagine standing firm against that fear, surrounded by Him and His angels guarding you against that fear. How does it feel? Stand tall—you’re protected from evil.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 12-13; Luke 12:1-12; Ps 58; Pro 6:12-15 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65509&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: You're Protected From Evil (2)
content.introtext: 'Hide me in the shadow of Your wings.' Psalm 17:8 NIV<br /><br /><p>Take a look at Paul’s words to the Romans: ‘<em>Don’t you realise that you become the slave of whatever you choose to obey?...give yourselves to be slaves to righteous living so that you will become holy.</em>’ (Romans 6:16–19 NLT) This isn’t about making a new ticklist, or to constantly be checking that every single part of us is in perfect shape all the time. It’s about choosing to live with God in charge of our decisions: then He’ll work in us to become more like Him. Which means we have a choice to make: are we going to set our minds/efforts on living with God? But there’s also the other side to it: Choosing to indulge in things that aren’t pleasing to God. Jesus didn’t mince words on this kind of thing. In Matthew 5:28 NIV He says that ‘<em>anyone who looks at a woman lustfully has already committed adultery with her in his heart</em>.’ It doesn’t matter what level you’re operating on, any form of sexual indulgence/ theft/ gossip is not only against God’s will, but dangerous. Yes, we’re at the heavy end of things here, but we all need to get this: if we include not–so–godly decisions in our lifestyle, then we offer the enemy a way to entrap and enslave us. (1) <em>We need to choose God</em>, and (2<em>) We need to </em>‘<em>throw off everything that hinders and the sin that so easily entangles.</em>’ (Hebrews 12:1 NIV) Galatians 5:19–21 is a great place for a spiritual check–up. It’s free. Do it. But here’s the good news: He’s already paid the price—all your mistakes are forgiven already.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 14-15; Luke 12:13-21; Ps 61; Pro 6:16-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65510&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: You're Protected From Evil (3)
content.introtext: '...I have given you authority ... over all the power of the enemy.' Luke 10:19 ESV<br /><br /><p><em>Spiritual warfare</em>. There’s a spiritual dynamic to life—and some of it isn’t healthy. But God is definitely the boss; Satan only has authority in your life when you give it to him; he has no power over you when your life is ‘<em>hidden in Christ</em>.’ (Colossians 3:3 ESV) If you’ve compromised your cover in some way by walking away from the God who is protecting you, there is still room for repentance. Essentially, this means changing your attitudes (which in turn, changes your actions). Repentance is the key to freedom from all oppression of the enemy. When we choose to get on board with what God wants, we gain access to Christ’s authority: ‘<em>I have given you authority…to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you.</em>’ (Luke 10:19 NIV) In Ephesians 6:10–17, Paul compares the kind of protection we get from God to a suit of armour. They’re well worth checking out, but for now we’ll stick to just one: the ‘Sword of the Spirit’. Which Paul writes is ‘<em>the Word of God</em>.’ (Ephesians 6:17 NIV) That’s the one offensive weapon we’ve got—and it’s all that we need. You see, Satan can only trick us if we don’t know the Scriptures; it’s on God’s Word that we will get a peaceful, solid knowledge of our love for Him. Not only is Scripture full of that ‘good stuff’, but it’s paralysing to the forces of evil. You have been given the Word of God to use as part of your spiritual battle—it’s true and it’s living—use it! It will protect you.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 16:1-18:15; Luke 12:22-34; Ps 66:1-12; Pro 6:20-22 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65512&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear the Air
content.introtext: 'Keep me from looking at worthless things. Let me live by Your word.' Psalm 119:37 NCV<br /><br /><p>You could apply today’s verse to your time on the internet, watching tv, shopping… (you get the idea). Anything that involves coming across information or images. So what’s the benchmark of ‘worth’? Philippians 4:8 NLT says this: <em>‘Fix your thoughts on what is true, and honourable, and right, and pure, and lovely, and admirable</em>.’ If you find you’re taking in a lot of stuff that’s at odds with what God wants, your mental filter for straining out impurities is under attack. It’s been the same since Adam and Eve. The fact that the Psalmist writes about his battle to keep his mind God–honouring is pretty telling. Put it like this: the world we live in has always gravitated toward selfishness. Even if you disconnect yourself completely from the world of technology or never look at a billboard again, there’ll still always be a reason to guard your mind. The answer’s always been the same too: replace the world’s influence with God’s. <em>‘How I long for Your precepts! Preserve my life in Your righteousness</em>.’ (Psalm 119:40 NIV) What does that look like, then? Actively inviting God to build a guard for your mind through Bible reading and prayer time and teaching podcasts, rather than passively hoping that the world won’t pollute your mind. Is it worth it? Yes. The freedom that comes with looking for what God wants above earthly desires will clear the mind–smog and take you much closer to the fullness God has for you.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Ruth 1:3-18; John 6:41-69 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65547&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: 'Gideon Up'
content.introtext: 'Go in the strength you have and save Israel out of Midian's hand. Am I not sending you?' Judges 6:14 NIV<br /><br /><p>You’ll find that as you go on with God, you go through different kinds of ‘seasons’. Often, those seasons follow on logically, and the one prepares you for the next. Sometimes, though, God prompts us to go somewhere/do something that we don’t feel ready for. First reaction? If you’re anything like us, you’ll have been tempted to (a) <em>hide</em>, or (b) <em>talk God out of it</em>. Gideon (in the book of Judges) was the smallest guy in his family and his family was the weakest in his tribe. Yet God used him to lead an army. The thing is, it was an army of 300 that went to war against another army of over 100,000 men. Yikes! Outnumbered by over 300 to 1. It seemed an impossible task, but God declared: ‘<em>I will be with you.</em>’ (Judges 6:16 NIV) That’s all that counts really, isn’t it? One ‘Yes’ from God like that is enough to cancel out all our ‘but what ifs’ and ‘maybes’. If God brings you to the edge of something, even if it’s somewhere unknown and looks like a sharp drop, He’ll bring you through, and show you how it fits your journey with Him. If it looks like God is prodding you in a scary direction, it’ll be for the best. So, don’t let it frighten you into inertia. Do you feel God is calling you to do something that, for you, is really scary? Pray to Him to take care of your next step, then ask Him for His plan so you can take it. Don’t stay static. Gideon up!</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 18:16-20:43; Luke 12:35-48; Ps 66:13-20; Pro 6:23-25 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65514&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: You Can Succeed, Because...
content.introtext: 'When you didn't think much of yourself, God made you king of Israel...' 1 Samuel 15:17 TLB<br /><br /><p>When Samuel anointed Saul as king, Saul couldn’t believe it. He couldn’t understand why God would choose someone as seemingly unimportant as him to be king. Things were looking really bright—Samuel said, ‘<em>The Spirit of the Lord will rush upon you, and you will prophesy with them and be turned into another man</em>.’ (1 Samuel 10:6 ESV) Awesome! Yet over time Saul got a bit too comfortable. Gradually, he stopped listening to God, went increasingly his own way and starting making some catastrophic mistakes. Remember that time when you first heard that God chose you to be in His family and Jesus chose to die for you? How amazing was that? How in awe of His Word and His ways were you? Over time though, it can be easy to start to take that relationship with Jesus for granted and to not listen to God so much anymore. The ability to forget is staggering. The most dangerous moment in our life is when we think we can succeed without God. The key is in truly knowing our worth, and why. We need to know how loved we truly are—enough to die for, enough for God to tell us to make a difference in this world. But sometimes we can forget that the valuation of us was God’s, and that ability to make a difference was His gift. The key: humility—knowing our worth because we know the One who values us. So today: here’s an assignment for you! Go for a short walk with God—without your phone! Ask Him to show you what you mean to Him.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Kings 21-22; Luke 12:49-59; Ps 70; Pro 6:26-28 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65515&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Your Bucket List
content.introtext: 'Know that it is near, right at the door.' Matthew 24:33 NIV<br /><br /><p>Have you heard of a Bucket List? It’s a list of all the things a person wants to do before they die (or ‘kick the bucket’.) Say a whole group of people, with the ability to carry out world–changing actions, knew their time was nearly up—how would that change what they usually did? Say that group was… drum roll… the Church? The same Jesus who spoke God’s truth to people in Israel 2,000 years ago speaks the same God’s–truth–promise to those of us living as His followers, today and in any age: ‘<em>I am coming soon</em>.’ (Revelation 3:11 NIV) The first Christians really took this seriously. They spread God’s goodness with a ferocious energy, as if they’d had it revealed to them specifically. The truth is, we don’t know when Jesus will return and when this life as we know it will be over. We’re not supposed to (we’re told that the timeframe for His return is something only God knows, and not public knowledge). Which makes every day count. Christians in 2AD, 500AD and 2015AD are all supposed to be asking themselves: Are we ready? Are we living with an eye open to the fact that Jesus is coming back? What differences would you make to your life and those around you? Write your own Bucket List, one inspired by Jesus’ return. Pray into it and see how God helps you tick it off. He has made us to be world–changers.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Rev 1-4; Luke 13:1-17; Ps 77; Pro 6:29 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65516&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Introduce Someone
content.introtext: 'Go throughout the whole world and preach the Gospel to all people.' Mark 16:15 GNT<br /><br /><p>It’s always good to have someone introduce you to new people. In a nutshell, that is what Jesus asks us to do: introduce people to Him. Our primary call isn’t to ‘bring people to church’, or to turn evangelism into a massive project with no personality or heart. We are, most simply, called to introduce people to this Jesus we know. We just need to be honest and brave, and Jesus will do the hard bit (the ‘heart bit’?...). We hear stories of people going into the deepest parts of the world for God, but there are heaps who don’t know Jesus right here in Australia—they’re in our lecture halls, our offices, our coffee shops, our footy teams. You don’t have to know everything about Christianity or the Bible; you just have to be in love with Jesus. When you have real love for someone, you can’t help mention them naturally in conversation. Oh, and in case you’re wondering, Jesus said, ‘<em>If I am lifted up from the earth, I will draw all people toward Me</em>.’ (John 12:32 NCV) The work of ‘drawing people toward Him’ belongs to Jesus. He just wants us to make Him visible initially. Is there one person who you’d really like to concentrate on introducing to Jesus? Now, pray that you are able to introduce them to Him in a natural way. After that, it’s Jesus who develops the relationship.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Rev 5-9; Luke 13:18-35; Ps 136:1-12; Pro 6:30-31 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65517&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: You, Fellow-Christian
content.introtext: 'Encourage one another daily...so that none of you may be hardened by sin's deceitfulness.' Hebrews 3:13 NIV<br /><br /><p>Sin is a filthy, stinking, rotten liar. That stuff that promises to feel soooo good at the expense of being able to stay close to God, well, it’s bad stuff. If you’re reading this, you’ve probably already got an inkling of that. So why mention it? Because we all have to be continually careful not to fall for the lies. Today’s verse is about the sort of encouragement that stands alongside your Christian brothers and sisters and says, ‘Come on family! We know Who we stand for! I’m with you, don’t give in to that distraction!’ And frankly, from time to time, we all need someone to say it to us. The full verse even includes the phrase ‘...<em>encourage one another daily, as long as it is called “Today”.</em>..’ (Hebrews 3:13 NIV) The writer’s got a sense of urgency—like the message of solidarity, of support for each other, is really needed, and needed now. We suspect you’ve noticed this already, but your Christ–siblings are surrounded by tasty temptations, right now, that would trap their hearts and turn them to stone, if they give in. God’s prevention plan for this disaster? You, fellow–Christian. Your encouragement could be the lifebuoy that drags someone back from sin. Get on to it now! Who do you know who loves Jesus, and needs to know the arm of a fellow–follower around them ‘<em>whilst it is still called “Today”</em>’? Fire off a message to remind them why they’re a Christian, and that they’re not alone. Quick!</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Rev 10-14; Luke 14:1-14; Ps 136:13-26; Pro 6:32-35 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65518&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Good Plan vs Best Plan
content.introtext: 'David gave his son Solomon the plans for...the temple.' 1 Chronicles 28:11 NIV<br /><br /><p>David was an achiever. His rule and reign of Israel went over pretty well most of the time, he got some nice feedback over the Goliath incident, he wrote a good chunk of what’s called the Psalms, and was described by the Lord as ‘<em>a man after [God’s] own heart</em>.’ (Acts 13:22 NIV) So there’s nothing David couldn’t do, right? Well, oddly, God specified that David wasn’t the man for the job of building His temple. Go read about it in 1 Chronicles 28:6–7. David could have piped up: ‘Actually Lord, how’d You feel about me taking this one? I mean, I’ve got the runs on the board, don’t you think it’s best if I handle this?’ But he didn’t. David knew God better than to try to push his own plans on Him. So what about us? Well, making our own plans isn’t wrong, in fact, it’s positively good. Taking them back to God to get checked out is what makes them best. In 1 Chronicles 28:2 David gets his plan–correction from God, and in verse 20 he gives us a great example of how to handle that correction—with wisdom, grace and love. Is God the lead–planner in your life decisions? And if you get a nudge from Him to change tack, how willing are you to change? The best achievement the Bible describes is a life fully submitted to God. Got plans? For work? For time with mates? Even for this weekend? Great. Now ask God what changes He’d make, and listen out for a response. (Keep your Bible open, He likes to answer with it most times.)</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Rev 15-18; Luke 14:15-24; Ps 106:1-23; Pro 7:1-2 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65520&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Repack Your Backpack
content.introtext: 'Each one should carry his own load.' Galatians 6:5 NIV<br /><br /><p>Galatians 6 starts by telling us to keep watch on ourselves. It’s telling us to step back every now and then and take stock of our life. Know what’s inside you. Learn how to outsmart your own weaknesses. God’s growth plan for you is: ‘<em>We will no longer be immature... We won’t be tossed and blown about... We will not be influenced when people try to trick us... Instead, we will speak the truth in love, growing in every way more and more like Christ.</em>’ (Ephesians 4:14–15 NLT) Say your life is a backpack you’re lugging up a steep hill. Wouldn’t it be fairly helpful to know what’s in there, and why? If you’re still being defeated by the same habits and hang–ups you struggled with as a new believer, or five years ago, then pause—God wants you to be aware of what’s going on inside you. Search out His help. Instead of always having to be ‘carried’, get on your feet to the place where you can feed yourself spiritually (with the right stuff—Spirit–food that’ll help you grow), pray in faith over your own problems, and make Spirit–led decisions concerning your life. Write down on different bits of paper all the things—spiritual gifts, strong friendships, defining moments, wrong choices—that float around your heart and head. Now start to pack your backpack. What’s worth putting in for the journey? And what’ll just weigh you down? Give some of them to God to deal with if you’re not sure.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Sam 21:1-6; Hosea 6:4-6; Matt 12:1-14 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65521&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: He Ain't Heavy, He's My Brother
content.introtext: 'Bear one another's burdens, and so fulfil the law of Christ.' Galatians 6:2 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Truth is, you’ll probably need to be lifted and carried for parts of your life—things will get tricky occasionally. But that’s not the long–term plan. Instead of always having to be lifted, God wants you to lift others. Why is it ‘<em>more blessed to give than to receive</em>’ (Acts 20:35 NKJ)? When you give out (of your personal resources, your ability to bless others, your spiritual gifts), you make yourself vulnerable and open to relying on God to make it up to you. God, then, can make it up to you by pouring out everything you need and more, not just enough for your own needs, but just loads left over to give out—joyfully—to others. That’s the cycle. God will give you so much so that you can give away so much. When you’re in a community, and everyone is giving away on a person–to–person level, you’ll all be provided for, and that’s how God has designed things to be. (PS: this currency is God’s, though, and He gives you what He wants for you, not necessarily $500 in an envelope after you double–tithed last week.) When you’re all wrapped up in yourself, you make a pretty small package. It’s when you open up and reach out in love to others that you begin to grow, and that God flows through you big time. So how about this coming weekend, you organise one day around someone else? Spend time just hanging out and, when you do, see if there’s anything you can help them with or pray about with them. You’ll be fulfilling the law of Christ.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Rev 19-22; Luke 14:25-35; Ps 106:24-48; Pro 7:3-5 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65522&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: You Can Pickle That
content.introtext: 'Discretion will preserve you.' Proverbs 2:11 NKJ<br /><br /><p>There are very few things in the world worth pickling. Pickled onions. Pickled eggs. Pickled pigs’ feet. Ok, we’ll stop there. Today’s proverb says: ‘<em>Discretion will preserve you</em>.’ It’s worth preserving a character of decency and keeping it stored up inside you. Discretion basically means guarding your tongue when it comes to the facts you know about other people—sensitive facts, like: ‘She struggles with hating her family,’ ‘He’s really conscious of his self–esteem,’ ‘He was once a drug addict,’ etc. Divulging what you know about other people’s problems and failures can gain you rapt attention from an uncaring crowd. That may make you feel good momentarily, but afterwards it may have a terrible impact on the relationship. Plus, you get a reputation as a person who can’t be trusted. Not good. You’ve probably said the wrong thing, at the wrong time, to the wrong person, and ended up biting your fist on the way out the door. The good thing is you actually can conserve and preserve good characteristics. Once you’ve started to hold your tongue in one tricky situation, it gets easier the next time, and so on. Sometimes you need a prompt to start acting that way, though. Make sure to not let that prompt be someone’s shock over some accidentally revealed info. As you consider the sensitive things you know about other people that would hurt them if they got out, draw up your own privacy policy. Decide that this is info you won’t share or sell to unnamed third parties. content.title: Turn It Up
content.introtext: 'Cast your cares on the Lord and He will sustain you.' Psalm 55:22 NIV<br /><br /><p>Augustine defined sin as ‘humanity turned in upon itself’. Now, you might be pretty confident in yourself. Or, you might be someone who really struggles to accept compliments, who doesn’t really like mirrors (or friends with camera–phones…) and sees no reason why anyone should like you—psst… you’re made in God’s image and He thinks you’re beautiful, by the way. Either way, the problem comes when we look at ourselves (or others) more than we look at God. If we spend more time looking at ourselves (yes, whether out of self–love or self–loathing), we’re taking our eyes off the One who wants to give us the true, objective definition of who we really are. It’s not even about what we think of ourselves: it’s that we do think of ourselves more. Martin Luther said, ‘<em>I</em> have held many things in my hands, and I have lost them all; but whatever I have placed in God’s hands, that I still possess.’ Putting everything, especially ourselves, into God’s hands, is the best and only way to keep our perspective right. So what about those worries? Or about those doubts? Will I be able to keep this up? Will I ever be good enough?<em> ‘Cast your cares on the Lord and He will sustain you.</em>’ (Psalm 55:22 NIV) Today, make a point to walk everywhere with a straight back, chin up. As you walk, mull over where in your life you’re ‘turned in upon yourself’, rather than looking ‘up’ at Jesus’ opinion of you. (Also, it’s good posture…)</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 1:1-4:17; Luke 15:1-10; Ps 112; Pro 7:6-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65523&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Meet Yourself. Again.
content.introtext: 'I cry out to You, O God, but You do not answer.' Job 30:20 NIV<br /><br /><p>‘Lord. Where. Are. You?’ Do you feel like God isn’t answering that prayer? Job felt like it too. ‘<em>I cry out to You, O God, but You do not answer; I stand up, but You merely look at me… When I hoped for good, evil came; when I looked for light, then came darkness</em>.’ (Job 30:20; 26 NIV) All of us go through times when it feels like God vanished just when we blinked. And when we go looking for Him in all the usual places—prayer, Scripture, worship, church, creation—He seemingly isn’t there. When you’ve been in that place for a while, you meet two old friends for the first time, again. Yourself. And, eventually, God. By recognising that God doesn’t always talk in the same way, you surrender that control over your expectations. Maybe you used to hear from God in a particular way. But then He’s silent. There’s no answer. The change doesn’t mean He has abandoned you. It can mean that you’d started to put Him in a box. You began to rely more on the method than the relationship. And if that’s the case, it’s about waiting on God as He takes you beyond the way it used to be into the heart of a new relationship. There’s a real communication that goes on when you, and God, are silent together. More on that tomorrow, too. If this speaks to you today—stop asking for things to be the way they were. Just for a little while. Plan some prayer times over the next few days that are just about listening out for God. Look for Him to speak to you in an unexpected way.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 7-9; Luke 16:1-18; Ps 135; Pro 7:21-23 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65525&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Meet God. Again.
content.introtext: 'He will bring justice if you will only wait.' Job 35:14 NLT<br /><br /><p><em>Silence isn’t absence</em>. Sometimes God says to you, ‘<em>Be still, and know that I am God</em>.’ (Psalm 46:10 NIV) When God seems silent, He can be giving us a chance to discover Him again in a totally new way. You have to be really secure with somebody to just sit quietly with them. Silence takes the emphasis off words and builds a level of intimacy where they’re no longer necessary. Something changes in your relationship with God when you sit silently with Him. But what if you’re waiting desperately for some answer to prayer? First up, check out the conversation around today’s verse in Job. Second, Charles Trumbull said, ‘God knows when to withhold or grant visible signs of encouragement. It’s good when He sends confirmation, but we grow faster when we’ve trusted Him without it. Those who do, always receive the greatest visible evidence of His love.’ God answers every prayer; it’s just that across some He writes, ‘Just wait.’ It takes as long as it takes—and usually feels uncomfortable the whole time. But there’s good news. Eventually your prayers become less about getting answers and more about realising that you’re with God, and right alongside His long–lasting provision for you, at a deeper level than you imagined. If this reading speaks to you today, well this may seem repetitive (word4U2day said pretty much the same yesterday) but stop asking for things. Just for a little while. Plan some prayer times over the next few days that are just about listening out for God. Look for Him to speak to you in an unexpected way.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 10-12; Luke 16:19-31; Ps 24; Pro 7:24-25 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65526&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Make Space
content.introtext: '"I am the Lord's servant," said Mary; "may it happen to me as you have said."' Luke 1:38 GNT<br /><br /><p>Mary famously gets called to be the mother of Jesus in the story behind today’s verse. Popularly, that story’s called the Annunciation, which is a fancy way of saying ‘<em>the announcement</em>’. God sends an angel to announce to Mary His plans that her life would become a space for Jesus’ arrival into the world. Wow. But nothing happens until she says ‘yes’. It’s a curious one, this. God has determined something is definitely going to happen but still gives Mary the chance to confirm His plan by saying: ‘<em>let it be done to me as you have said</em>.’ That’s key. When have you felt the announcement of God, calling you out from the normal, asking if He can make you more aware of His presence and start working more and more through you? The poem Annunciation by Denise Levertov asks, ‘Aren’t there annunciations of one sort or another in most lives?’ Moments when you feel a dream on your heart especially strongly. Moments when you feel weighted down with darkness. These moments carry opportunity, chance to see the purpose that extends down beneath the surface of your life. So, will you let Him in? Not begrudgingly. Not turning away as if dodging a bullet. Will you be space for the uncontained God, today? Even if you don’t feel a fully spelled–out call of God on your life, know that God can turn anything to His use. Examine your life to see where it is most stressed or most enlivened right now. Are those places you could invite God into?</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 13-15; Luke 17:1-19; Ps 26; Pro 7:26-27 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65527&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: He's Got the Power
content.introtext: 'We have this treasure in jars of clay to show that this all-surpassing power is from God and not from us.' 2 Corinthians 4:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>Look at Jesus’ family tree and notice He’s not descended from the people society admires. His mother got pregnant outside of marriage. (We know the full story of that, of course, but not everyone around her at the time believed it.) This would’ve led to her being seen as ‘undesirable’ in society. But God was using her. In an absolutely huge way. And, look further back in the Bible—God quite often uses the underdog. David and Goliath ring a bell? What this shows us is that God is the one with the power. God never goes for the same type of person over another. He is so far beyond the categories we’d choose (people that impress us, experienced winners, ‘the most likely to succeed’). We are all (and they are all) ‘<em>jars of clay</em>’; we’ve all been made and sculpted by God and are fragile. And He uses us, fragility and all. The treasure we’ve been given is that God is for us. Hands down, He’s for us. Which is kind of a great relief: to know that it’s not up to us; to vindicate ourselves; to make something of ourselves; to be someone worth boasting about; but that God’s already done all the work. Are there any relationships or areas in your life where you aren’t living like God is the one with the power? Take it before God and take courage, as Paul says, ‘<em>What, then, shall we say in response to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?</em>’ (Romans 8:31 NIV)</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Sam 5:1-6:16; Rev 11:15-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65528&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: This Is Your Life
content.introtext: 'What is the best thing to do in the short life that God has given us? I think we should enjoy eating, drinking, and working hard. This is what God intends for us to do.' Ecclesiastes 5:18 CEV<br /><br /><p>It’s easy to let your eyes drift off what God’s given you and find yourself fixated on someone else’s lot. Surprisingly, God has a lot to say about this idea of contentment with your own lot in life. In fact, the writer of Ecclesiastes lays out how God’s given you opportunities to find joy and let it bubble out of every corner your life, even the dark ones. Ecclesiastes 5:18–20 NKJ says: ‘<em>It is good and fitting for one to eat and drink, and to enjoy… for it is his heritage</em>.’ But when you’re struggling to find that contentment and basic happiness in life, there’s a tendency to be envious about what other people’s lives look like. Somebody else’s life suddenly becomes much more appealing and seems all rosy–glow wonderful. This makes us susceptible to extremes in perspective. One myth, the ‘forever myth’, tells you your own situation will never improve. Another, the ‘never myth’, says if things get any worse you’ll never be able to handle them. Both are distortions. Contentment with your life comes from the hands of the God who deals out enough for today. Think over things in your life that you may take for granted: a great friend, listening to music, sports or the taste of your favourite meal. God has made them all for your appreciation; they are signs that He’s with you. If you’re going through some tough times, remember that they’ll pass, and that God’s with you all the way (Isaiah 41:10).</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 16:1 - 18:16; Luke 17:20-37; Ps 115; Pro 8:1-3 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65531&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Don't Run--Be Bold!
content.introtext: 'The wicked flee though no one pursues, but the righteous are as bold as a lion.' Proverbs 28:1 NIV<br /><br /><p>Having a guilty conscience means always running—whether from the people you’ve hurt; from the people who’d be in charge of punishing you; or even (Jonah–style) from God. But today’s verse tells us that running is pretty much pointless, because ‘no one pursues’. When we’re running from guilt, chances are that we’re mostly only running from our own conscience. And, especially because this running is all in our heads, we don’t really get anywhere. We’re far more likely to just implode. So, is there another option? What about the second half of that verse then? ‘<em>The righteous are as bold as lions</em>.’ Actually… That says a lot about God’s power. It says that, when we’re righteous, we’re granted the boldness of the fiercest lion. And here’s even more good news: John 1:12. Yes. <em>‘Yet to all who did receive Him, to those who believed in His name, He gave the right to become children of God</em>.’ Because of Jesus, we’re fully adopted into God’s family. That means that, because He chooses to always see us in and through Christ, we’re called, and most importantly enabled, to be righteous. That means that we can all take a firm hold of that boldness. The first step towards that is to focus our whole attention on living out the righteousness we’re offered. So let’s use our righteous–boldness to avoid fleeing in fright. If you feel like there are some mistakes you’re running from (or have run from in the past) do these three things: (1) <em>Worship</em>. Know that you’re righteous, because of Jesus. (2) <em>Own up to the mistake before God.</em> Ask for His healing for it. (3) <em>Own up to the people/person affected</em>. Have any conversations that need to happen.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 18:17-20:21; Luke 18:1-17; Ps 11; Pro 8:4-5 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65532&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Let God Take the Strain
content.introtext: 'Their hearts are secure, they will have no fear; in the end they will look in triumph on their foes.' Psalm 112:8 NIV<br /><br /><p>It’s probably fair to say that we’re most likely to be bold (especially about sharing our faith) when we’re feeling closest to God. So, lesson 1: if you’re a Christian but have made a mess of the whole purity/truthfulness/ kindness/fruit–of–the–Spirit (see Galatians 5:22–23) thing, God won’t reject your ‘sorry’. The past is there to be learnt from, not burnt from. Yet what about when we mess up over and over? Ever done the ‘I promise I won’t do that sin any more’ thing, and then (no matter how long you manage to hold off) you seem to fall back into the habit? Breaking news! God is transforming us ‘<em>from one degree of glory to another</em>.’ (2 Corinthians 3:18 NRS) One degree. To another. That implies that you (1) <em>aren’t perfect</em>, and (2) <em>can, with God’s help, get closer to His likeness</em>. Satan loves to reach into whatever dark pit of ‘won’t–go–back–there’ he can find, and drag back up whatever he knows will make you squirm before God. We’ve all been there. Guess what? There is no darkness in your life that Jesus hasn’t forgiven. To bring this back round: don’t sweat that you aren’t perfect. God’s aware of that bit. When you know you’re out of your depth or really struggling, don’t sweat. He’s got you—‘Be still’ and let Him take the strain. God wants you to pray, declare out loud even, the pains that stop you from feeling His closeness and power. Giving these faith–on–hold pains to God gives the enemy no room to operate in your life.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 21-23; Luke 18:18-43; Ps 19; Pro 8:6-7 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65533&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Pilgrim vs the World
content.introtext: 'They go from strength to strength, till each appears before God in Zion.' Psalm 84:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>The great boxer Muhammad Ali once said, ‘What keeps me going is goals.’ He’s right; our motivation for doing something is nearly always the prize we receive at the end. Jesus didn’t beat around the bush when He appealed to these desires in us: He promises ‘<em>treasure in Heaven</em>.’ (Matthew 6:20 NIV) But to get the treasure, we’re to live boldly for God here in the world. That means going from strength to strength in our living out of what God asks us to do, here. Paul says, in 1 Corinthians 9:24–27, that we’re to keep our eyes fixed on the prize of where God and His people are—Heaven—and run with all our might toward it. As we live for Him, there are two things that keep us going: joyful remembering and hopeful looking forward. That’s what pilgrims used to do, back in the day when pilgrimages were a popular way of expressing faith in God. A pilgrim is described as: ‘a traveller (literally one who has come from afar) who is on a journey to a holy place. Typically, this is a physical journey, often on foot, to some place of special significance.’ As they travelled they’d be remembering Christ, letting Him be known, and looking forwards. Treat your day like a pilgrimage. As you go about your day, with its ups and downs, remind yourself that you have the sure hope of Heaven. Let that motivate you to do bold, good works for God. And, don’t forget to enjoy your day too—Jesus came that we may have abundant life here on earth too!</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Kings 24-25; Luke 19:1-21; Ps 116:1-11; Pro 8:8-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65534&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Servant and Friend
content.introtext: 'Serve wholeheartedly, as if you were serving the Lord, not men.' Ephesians 6:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>Here are two great verses: ‘<em>Serve wholeheartedly, as if you were serving the Lord, not men</em>’ (Ephesians 6:7 NIV); and <em>‘I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from My Father I have made known to you</em>.’ (John 15:15 NIV) They give a whole new spin to what service is. When we work to serve God, it becomes more than drudging, low–level service. We’re actually part of some of God’s plans (we’re certainly in on His biggest plan of all—the whole Salvation Plan). And that, in turn, means that Jesus calls us ‘friend’. Hold on a second. Friend. He calls us friend. When we decide to serve Jesus, He doesn’t say, ‘Oh, thanks for that, little minion.’ He says, ‘Bless you, my dear, precious friend.’ The One who’s worked for forever to save us all calls us friend, and not even because of the meagre amount of good that we (might) get done here on earth. It’s purely because, ‘<em>Everything that I learned from My Father, I have made known to you</em>.’ (John 15:15 NIV) So, when we’re told to: ‘Serve wholeheartedly, as if you were serving the Lord, not men,’ we’re actually being told to serve as if we’re serving our closest friend, who’s given everything He has to allow us to live truly well. Kind of puts things in perspective, doesn’t it? Do something servant–like for a friend (an earthly one) today. You’ll feel the new spin. Your heart will soar.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Hos 1-5; Luke 19:22-40; Ps 116:12-19; Pro 8:10-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65535&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Stop Talking. Listen.
content.introtext: '...Be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to become angry.' James 1:19 NIV<br /><br /><p>Have you ever thought what would happen if everything you thought came straight out of your mouth? This is what it may sound like: ‘So, this Bible verse is… ooo, a bird! Anyway… What’s for lunch?’ Probably not the most productive. Let’s face it, if we said every single thing that came into our heads, we’d probably look like we had the attention span of a butterfly (and offend almost everyone we met by the end of the day). Proverbs 17:28 says ‘<em>Even fools are thought wise if they keep silent, and discerning if they hold their tongues</em>.’ We all have foolish thoughts, and sometimes the smartest thing to do is, well, keep it shut! Not speaking can be great. Jesus was pretty good with His words (He never put His foot in it by speaking too soon), and He was also a great listener. As a result, He attracted people like a magnet in a room full of drawing pins. Doubtless there were times He was tired and didn’t feel like it—but He listened anyway. Listening is often more effective than talking. In fact, there’s a point in every conversation where you need to say less and listen more. It’s only by listening that we can learn. We can never come into deep relationships with those around us unless we listen to what they have to say. Can you think of anyone in your life you don’t listen to enough? Next time you see them, make it your mission to (fully) listen to what they have to say.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Hos 6-10; Luke 19:41-20:8; Ps 13; Pro 8:14-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65536&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: I Can't Go On. I'll Go On.
content.introtext: 'The... Lord is my strength... He enables me to [go on].' Habakkuk 3:19 NIV<br /><br /><p>When the things the prophet Habakkuk counted on started to crumble, he was forced to discern between what was truly important and what was just ‘here–today–gone–tomorrow’ stuff. We all have to do that at some point. Here’s what Habakkuk said, in the final three verses of his book: ‘<em>Even though the fig trees have no fruit and no grapes grow on the vines, even though the olive crop fails and the fields produce no grain, even though the sheep all die and the cattle stalls are empty, I will still be joyful and glad, because the Lord God is my Saviour. The Sovereign Lord gives me strength. He makes me sure–footed as a deer and keeps me safe on the mountains.</em>’ (Habakkuk 3:17–19 GNT) Habakkuk realised he had no control over certain things. So he chose to control his response. He rejoiced in the Lord regardless of what happened, and drew from God the strength to ‘go on’. What’s your source? The Bible says that ‘<em>the eyes of the Lord range throughout the earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to Him.</em>’ (2 Chronicles 16:9 NIV) As you read this maybe you could stop and listen as He draws close. May your eyes fix on the eyes of God, who loves, trusts, and wants to strengthen you. Draw close to Him and He will draw close to you (James 4:8). Write down some of the things that are bothering you or stressing you out, talk to Jesus about them and keep your joy. He will help you go on.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Lev 24:17-22; Deut 15:7-11; Matt 5:38-48 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65537&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Monster Seeds
content.introtext: 'A peaceful heart leads to a healthy body, jealousy is like cancer in the bones.' Proverbs 14:30 NLT<br /><br /><p>Jealousy starts as a seed. It’s the little, fleeting moment when we compare our abilities, appearance, or life–in–general with someone else’s (or with your whole Instagram feed…?) Chances are, when that happens, we probably don’t even recognise it to be the starting seed of jealousy. It’s such an insignificant thing, right? Well, it might look that way. But stick it in a lovely rich fertiliser of our oh–so–human insecurities, and water it with a bit of a desire for self–improvement, and it starts to grow. That tiny seed becomes a green–eyed monster plant of jealousy. Here are a couple of tips to root out the seed before it gets a chance to grow. (1) <em>Contentment</em>: It’s not always easy to decide to be happy whatever our circumstances and uproot those twinges of jealousy. In Philippians 4:10–13, Paul chats about contentment, then says: ‘<em>I can do everything through Him who gives me strength.</em>’ This means asking for help from the Holy Spirit. (2) <em>Community mentality</em>: We’re all on the same team. Let’s call it Team Humanity. When someone else is winning at life, that doesn’t mean you lose. If we’re on the same side, someone else’s happiness should be able to make our side stronger. The cure here is to literally celebrate with them, get in touch and enjoy their good times with them. Jealousy doesn’t have room to breathe when you choose to focus on someone else’s needs, especially someone who you might be a bit envious of. Think of a way to bless them and root out the jealousy seed.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Hos 11-14; Luke 20:9-26; Ps 55:1-11; Pro 8:17-18 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65538&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: What Now?!
content.introtext: 'Why is this happening to me?' Genesis 25:22 NIV<br /><br /><p>Some of us live waiting for a specific title or courier–delivered letter from God to find out what part we have to play in His Kingdom. But as Christians we have all already been given a role, an identity to take on, an invitation to accept. Understanding this truth makes sense of what God is doing in our lives. In the story behind today’s verse we find Rebekah asking the question, ‘<em>Why is this happening to me?</em>’ She’s carrying twins and the two babies in her womb keep wrestling with each other. She asks God and He tells her that there are two nations within her womb, and that one will serve the other. Why me? Why now? This is so difficult, so uncomfortable, so inconvenient. Have you ever found yourself saying these things? Just as it reassured Rebekah, often just knowing the fact that God’s at work helps us with these ‘Why me?’ moments. It’s easy to forget in the difficulties of the moment but turning to God and developing an awareness of His purpose and His presence makes all the difference. It’s about the direction of your heart, knowing that God’s already been working out His purpose for your life. Before you needed to ask. If the direction of your heart is towards God and the outworking of His will in you, then everything around you changes as you realise He is with you. Bring this question into your situation today: God what are You doing in this? Let me know that You are with me, help me to be aware of Your presence inside whatever I face today. What now, Father?</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 1-3; Luke 20:27-47; Ps 55:12-23; Pro 8:19-21 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65539&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Kingdom Come--Mercy
content.introtext: 'The merciful... will be shown mercy.' Matthew 5:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>Jesus taught us to pray ‘<em>on earth as it is in Heaven</em>.’ The earth–looking–more–like–Heaven thing seems to be fairly central to His whole message. Jesus’ life was all about bringing the Kingdom of Heaven near. ‘The Kingdom of Heaven’ He spoke about doesn’t mean where we go when we die, but places/ people/ homes/ hearts/ communities right here on earth. And Jesus is all about us advancing that Kingdom, right here, right now. Sounds abstract! What does that ‘advancing’ look like? Truthfully—it looks fairly messy. It probably looks like Christians getting our hands dirty; taking ourselves into the not–so–nice places, places we wouldn’t normally choose to be; it looks like gradual (sometimes difficult) prayerful work, with real, broken, hurting people. And, here’s the curious thing. We often forget that the Lord’s Prayer (Matthew 6:9–13) involves Jesus saying some incredibly challenging words about forgiveness. ‘<em>Forgive us what we owe to You, as we have also forgiven those who owe anything to us</em>.’ (Matthew 6:12 PHPS) So: if we forgive, we’ll be forgiven, if we refuse to forgive, we won’t! Whoops! To be Heaven to others, we need to start and end by forgiving. Surely Jesus’ challenge to us is clear, then? We really should (we absolutely need) to get over our own judgment if we have any hope of being a part of His Kingdom. What’s bugging you now? Are you feeling offended? Whether it’s a person or a group, find a practical way to show forgiveness. Bring the Kingdom of Heaven’s love and mercy down to earth today.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 4-6; Luke 21:1-24; Ps 38:1-12; Pro 8:22-23 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65540&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Kingdom Come--Peace
content.introtext: 'God blesses those who work for peace.' Matthew 5:9 NLT<br /><br /><p>Peace feels like an advert for a brand of tea—some hardworking soul arriving home for a soothing cuppa, accompanied by relaxing music and slow–wafting aroma. Most of us crave and deeply appreciate the peace that comes as a break from frantic busyness. But the Bible gives a much bigger picture of peace. It’s not just a calming interlude in the midst of problems. It’s something called ‘<em>Shalom</em>’. <em>Shalom</em> is restoration, making amends, making things good, bringing full well–being. Shalom is the world completed—as it was meant to be. The wholeness of God arriving. It’s not stepping back from the world to take a rest, it’s taking the world by the scruff of the neck and pulling it forwards into what God wants for it. <em>Shalom</em> meaning God re–forging things the way He intended, into real peace. It feels so good to say, ‘Aah, that’s better,’ when you put your feet up after a long day. More satisfying though, is that feeling of peace when you’ve patched up a friendship after an argument, when you’ve gone out of your way to help a needy person, when your family (or any family–like group) sits down together for a meal. It takes work to make peace arrive the way God wants, and it takes some knowledge of what He likes. But <em>Shalom</em> is His worked–for peace that brings a really solid satisfaction. So be Heaven in your world. Be someone who makes peace, who actively works for peace. If there conflict in your family, could you be the one who helps make amends and restores relationships?</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 7-9; Luke 21:25-38; Ps 38:13-22; Pro 8:24-26 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65541&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Agape
content.introtext: 'Through love serve one another.' Galatians 5:13 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Jesus said something incredible: His disciples would be recognised by their love for each other (John 13:34–35). And He used a special Greek word for love: <em>agape</em>. This distinguishes it from other kinds of love. <em>Agape</em>’s a love that serves, even it isn’t served. A love that gives before it receives. A love that forgives before it is forgiven. It’s a lavish love that goes beyond the love of a parent for a child, beyond the affection of one friend for another, beyond the attraction of a starry–eyed bridal couple. It’s the wildly–outrageous love that comes from God and enables people to overcome their selfish self–centred me–focus and instead give themselves in sacrificial service to strangers. It’s the kind of love that took Jesus to the cross for our sins. It’s the kind of love that enables us to follow Jesus’ command to do good to our enemies, bless those who hate us and pray for those who persecute us. (Matthew 5:44) That way, Jesus goes on to say, ‘<em>you will be acting as true children of your Father in Heaven. For He gives His sunlight to both the evil and the good, and He sends rain on the just and the unjust alike. If you love only those who love you, what reward is there for that? Even corrupt tax collectors do that much. If you are kind only to your friends, how are you different from anyone else? Even pagans do that. But you are to be perfect, even as your Father in Heaven is perfect.</em>’ (Matthew 5:45–48 NLT) What can you do today that shows <em>agape</em>?</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 10-13; Luke 22:1-23; Ps 69:1-18; Pro 8:27-29 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65542&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Want Success? Lower Yourself.
content.introtext: 'Whoever desires to become great among you shall be your servant.' Mark 10:43 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Pastor Andy Stanley says that you don’t need character in order to be a great leader. At first sight this looks plain wrong. When you look into it, it’s obvious. History teaches us that lots of people achieve greatness through lying, cheating, stealing, murdering, slandering and backstabbing their way to the top. Just read 1 and 2 Kings—prime material for a hit TV series. There’s a difference between great leaders and leaders with character. But it’s only the second sort who are actually worth following. Think for a moment about the people who’ve been able to motivate you. Most of us are (hopefully) inspired by people of integrity who’ve gone through suffering with determination, who’ve proved true greatness through overcoming challenges. Jesus is big on that too. Look at His letters to the churches in the first few chapters of Revelation—each one is packed with His shoulder–to–shoulder encouragement to ‘Hold on! Keep in there!’ Each one ends by mentioning the rewards He has planned for people who hang in until they get the victory. That’s what we mean by ‘leaders with character’. If your desire is simply fame, notability or even notoriety, then you’ll avoid learning to serve. But if you want to be one of those leaders who’s worth following, then you should begin to learn the true grit of servanthood. Paul says that Jesus humbled Himself, and in humbling Himself God exalted Him to the highest place (Philippians 2:5–8). Greatness starts as you humble yourself and take on all the ways of a servant. Serve someone today.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 14-17; Luke 22:24-53; Ps 69:19-36; Pro 8:30-31 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65543&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Not a Theatre
content.introtext: 'If you think you are too important to help someone, you are only fooling yourself.' Galatians 6:3 NLT<br /><br /><p>Ever felt as though you’re ‘above’ some task at church each week? It’s fair to say that we shouldn’t spread ourselves thin and try to be the hero that upholds the church. The point is that if everyone got stuck in, then our church services would run really well. But, why do we even talk about ‘serving’ in church in the first place? Somewhere along the line, in many churches, a committed few do most of the work. If we thought of Church as the ‘meeting of God’s people’, where we’re all coming together, and all playing a part, then instead of our assumption being ‘church is where I go to watch, but there’s no way they’re signing me up for some serving team,’ maybe we’d say ‘I love our church–family meetings, I think serving tea and coffee afterwards might help.’ If that’s already how you roll, great stuff! If you’re used to treating church like a theatre show rather than a family, maybe your definition of ‘fellowship’ and ‘worship’ need a check–up. So that service business then. It’s not just the necessary bit to stop your church’s most faithful bunch from crumpling with exhaustion, it’s also necessary to get you stuck into that larger ‘family’ a bit more. Funny what happens when we ‘serve together for Jesus’. Grab some church friends and chat about the service thing: do we see church more as theatre than family? Then, be the agent of change—ask your church leader where’s best to serve—and get stuck right in and work together.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Matt 21:1-16; Ps 118:19-29 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65544&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Shadow Service
content.introtext: 'Always keep busy working for the Lord.' 1 Corinthians 15:58 CEV<br /><br /><p>Remember yesterday’s reading? Yes? Good. Remember that verse about not trying to feel more ‘important’ than the task at hand? Today we’re going a step further—and we’ll let Paul do the talking for now: ‘…<em>If I were still trying to please men, I would not be a servant of Christ</em>.’ (Galatians 1:10 NIV) Ouch. We’ll be the first to own up. Offering to help out is often met by a ‘You sure?’, followed by our obliging ‘Yes, of course, I’ll make drinks. How many sugars?’ Half an hour later, though, when we aren’t met by a round of ‘thank you’ from all involved, the prospect of service gets a lot bleaker. Yep, when the ‘thank you’ is forgotten, it’s tough to remember we’re doing it for the Lord, not others. Got that? Essentially, we like (love?) being noticed by others. Why’s that, then? Well we, as mistake–prone humans, are partial to being a bit proud of ourselves. And if we aren’t careful, our motivation for ‘doing stuff’ will be whether we get the credit for it or not. There. Said it. Being humble in service requires us to look at God and others more than at ourselves. There. Said that too. Service is about starting small: it’s not easy but, at the end of the day, we’ll have trained ourselves to serve in the shadows when it comes to being ‘<em>trusted with much</em>.’ (Luke 16:10 NIV) Still up for serving at church this week? (No? Huh? See yesterday’s reading.) Why not whip up a batch of home–made cookies for another group who spend time serving? Go onnnn. Dare you.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 18-21; Luke 22:54-62; Ps 6; Pro 8:32-33 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65545&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Shake Off the Dust
content.introtext: 'Through love serve one another.' Galatians 5:13 NKJ<br /><br /><p>We’ve been quite service–minded for the last few days, so here’s a final thought. The doing–it bit. Now, we don’t want to give you a guilt trip. Nor do we want to skirt around the edges of what it looks like to take God’s ‘care–for–everyone–regardless’ love to a world that needs it. You see, service (as you might have gathered from the past few readings) is definitely an active thing. But it’s up to each one of us to recognise it for ourselves, and be ready to put our effort in. It’s far too easy to get into such a day–in–day–out routine of predictable, comfortable living that we forget that God is willing to use us in world–shaking ways. The challenge is found here: ‘<em>Whenever we have the opportunity, we have to do what is good</em>.’ (Galatians 6:10 GWT) And sometimes, those (big but seemingly small) opportunities will come when we really aren’t expecting it. We’ve just got to keep an eye out for the opportunities, and a free hand to be able to take them. So, the ‘serve one another’ part of today’s verse is a bigger challenge than meets the eye: it needs us to be ready for that thought–poke from God that could change the course of your day/week/month. Leaving your schedule closed to spontaneous initiative will result in gathering boring, spiritually dry dust. Been meaning to call a friend or help out somewhere for a while? Been procrastinating about getting something worthwhile done? Now’s the time to shake off the dust and do it. You will not regret it!</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 22-24; Luke 22:63-71; Ps 31; Pro 8:34-36 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65546&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Swapsies
content.introtext: 'Whoever believes will not act hastily.' Isaiah 28:16 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Cast your mind way back to primary school. That favourite playground activity: trading things. Especially things that didn’t quite balance out. Ever swapped out a shiny collector’s card/ pack of lollies for someone’s promise of lifelong friendship? Those days are behind us, right? Hmm... We may still be tempted to put God to one side and choose something else. We might be more prone to cheap trade–offs more reminiscent of our school days than we’d first think. The story of Jacob and Esau (check Genesis 25) highlights this pretty well. After a day’s work hunting, Esau wasn’t feeling too perky, and his feelings got the better of him. Then what? Well, his brother Jacob had exactly what he was after: food. ‘<em>What good is the birthright to me?</em>’ (Genesis 25:32 NIV) (Note: a birthright was stunningly important. Essentially a share in the family inheritance.) And in return? ‘<em>Jacob gave Esau some bread and some lentil stew.</em>’ (Genesis 25:34 NIV) Bread and bean soup in exchange for the land and livestock that formed the family inheritance! Wow. Perhaps a worse deal than we can see ourselves making. But the question is, how often do we swap out God’s promises of something much better for a cheap, short–lived pleasure? Answer: probably a lot. It’s probably worth a thought–process before making decisions. So when we’re asked to give up something for a momentary gratification, it’s good to ask: ‘Why do I want this? Why am I doing this?’ These are handy questions to ask anytime we’re distracted or tempted. It’ll also help us identify the things of real worth and value them enough not to swap them.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 25-27; Luke 23:1-12; Ps 72:1-11; Pro 9:1-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=65581&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Command Centre
content.introtext: 'I have rejoiced in Your decrees as much as in riches.' Psalm 119:14 NLT <br /><br /><p>It’s Maundy Thursday. Maundy (from <em>mandatum</em>) means ‘commandment’. It’s the day during Easter week when we remember the Last Supper and Jesus’ command to ‘l<em>ove one another</em>’ as He loves us (John 13:34 NIV). That’s a great place to start acting like today’s Scripture–loving Psalm writer. When we get that the basic principle of love is behind all of God’s laws, we can start to dig deeper into other teachings in Scripture. Paul writes: ‘<em>All Scripture is inspired by God and is useful to teach us what is true and to make us realise what is wrong in our lives. It corrects us when we are wrong and teaches us to do what is right.</em>’ (2 Timothy 3:16 NLT) That means the Bible’s teachings aren’t just helpful things to think about—they’re things we <em><strong>'do'</strong></em> with delight: commandments. Commandments require you to turn good thoughts into good actions. They’re not just words on a page written a couple thousand years ago, they’re alive, still being spoken by God: ‘<em>For the word of God is alive and powerful. It is sharper than the sharpest two–edged sword… It exposes our innermost thoughts and desires.</em>’ (Hebrews 4:12 NLT) The Bible commands us as well as teaches us because it’s still His <em><strong>'living'</strong></em> word, which is working today. Take up the challenge, listen to the commandments, and you’ll not just survive, you’ll live well.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 28-30; Luke 23:13-25; Ps 72:12-20; Pro 9:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=66461&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>
