content.title: No Fear In Death (1)
content.introtext: <p>'But those who die in the Lord will live; their bodies will rise again!' Isaiah 26:19 NLT<br /><br /></p>
content.fulltext: <p>Greek philosopher Aristotle called death the thing to be feared more than everything, because ‘it appears to be the end of everything’. Even as Christians, death’s appearance of ‘the end’ can still be intimidating. The first disciples themselves saw Jesus’ own death as a terrifying, hopeless end to begin with. ‘Good Friday’ is a strange name for remembering that day. Jesus Christ, the Saviour—the Messiah—was crucified, after a false trial and heavy torture. Those disciples wouldn’t have called it ‘good’. And don’t let yourself fall into the trap of seeing this as a fairy story or an unreal legend. In fact, scholars have used historical accounts, and solar and lunar calendars, to work out that Jesus’ crucifixion was likely to have been AD 33, Friday 3rd April… That’s a coincidence for us this year, but maybe it helps bring the important message home: this happened. In a real time, in a real place, our God really died. So why ‘Good’? Maybe it’s helpful that we call today ‘Good Friday’, to keep us from forgetting what God achieved through this death. God dying, when our sin means that it’s really us who deserved to, hits ‘reset’ on our relationship with Him. His death allows us to count our sin–life as dead with Him, and be ‘born again’ into a new life with Him. But that’s not the end. Stick around for Sunday, yeah? Jesus’ death was the universe’s biggest act of reconciliation. Today is a good time to take that up: do you have someone you can offer forgiveness and healing? An ‘enemy’ you can show love to in a practical way? Try it.</p> <p><br /><br />SoulFood Good Friday: Luke 23:26-49, Ps 22, Is 53<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob &amp; Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src="http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&amp;track=65551&amp;www=blog" height="0" width="0" alt="" /></p>

content.title: Easter Message
content.introtext: <p>'Looking for the blessed hope...' Titus 2:13 NKJ<br /><br /></p>
content.fulltext: <p><br />The hope we can have because of Jesus’ resurrection isn’t an airy ‘in–an–ideal–world’ hope. Jesus secured our future in Heaven with a promise: ‘…<em>Because I live, you will live also</em>.’ (John 14:19 NKJ) Paul records the amount of witnesses who saw Jesus soon after the resurrection: <em>‘five hundred of His followers at one time</em>’ (1 Corinthians 15:6 NLT) amongst several other instances. Hold up. That’s quite a lot, isn’t it? More than that, these witnesses saw Jesus in the flesh. Not some sort of ghost, or a ‘warm feeling’ in their memory. Jesus’ followers didn’t follow up His death with eulogies; the resurrection changed that. The disciples carried on acting as if He was alive—because something had convinced them He was. Anyone ever who has been convinced and changed by Jesus’ resurrected life has the same hope they had. Heaven is a reality we can look forward to. And more than that, just like the disciples, eternal life with God is something we can start living out right now. Discipleship isn’t a remembrance club, it’s a living walk with a real life God. When Jesus rose on the third day, He proved that sin could no longer come between us and God (Romans 6:18). We’re free. Today, as well as looking back to the world’s greatest sacrifice, let’s look ahead to the fact that our lives, and the lives around us, can change because of it. Does it feel like a while since you last asked God to change something in your life? Maybe you’ve gone back to an old habit. Don’t let anything delay you—invite Him to bring His resurrected life into those parts of you.</p> <p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 31-32, Luke 24:13-18, Ps 32, Prov 9:10-16<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob &amp; Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src="http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&amp;track=65555&amp;www=blog" height="0" width="0" alt="" /></p>

content.title: Be Consistently Strong
content.introtext: <p>'We must pay the most careful attention, therefore, to what we have heard, so that we do not drift away.' Hebrews 2:1 NIV<br /><br /></p>
content.fulltext: <p><br />What if there’s more to staying in tune with God in easy times than meets the eye? Take Samson. If you know one thing about him, it’ll be that he could push a pillar or two. Samson’s enemies tried time and again to discover the secret of his stupendous strength. Time and again, God helped Samson overcome his enemies, even when Samson was disobeying Him. Samson thought God would be with him always, no matter what sin he was involved in. He didn’t realise God was giving him time to repent. In the final (and successful) attempt of Samson’s enemies to take him down, it was his own pride that undid him. ‘<em>“I will go out as before, at other times, and shake myself free!” But he did not know that the Lord had departed from him.</em>’ (Judges 16:20 NIV) Look up the story in Judges 16. Surrounded by enemies and his own fame, he forgot that he had been drawing on God’s strength the whole time. Matthew Henry said, ‘Our minds and memories are like a leaky vessel, they do not, without much care, retain what is poured into them.’ Samson’s story is an extreme, but it illustrates quite a lot. If you’re strong at one point, don’t rely on yourself to keep that up. All good comes from God (James 1:7), and He wants you to move forward, not drift back. If there’s a sin you keep on committing, don’t assume like Samson that God will be with you, regardless. This is the time of His mercy. Don’t knock it back.</p> <p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 33:1-36:26; Luke 24:19-24; Ps 25:1-7; Pro 9:17-18<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob &amp; Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src="http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&amp;track=65556&amp;www=blog" height="0" width="0" alt="" /></p>

content.title: Get God's Opinion (2)
content.introtext: 'Don't let anyone look down on you...' 1 Timothy 4:12 NIV<br /><br /><p>You can't live a life that's not your own. It's really important to accept the guidance of others, and to take on board any gentle nudges (or steel-toed kicks too, come to think of it) God might give to you through your fellow human beings. However, it's not up to other people to determine what's for you and what isn't. Just because your parents want you to be a doctor, doesn't automatically mean that's what God wants. You've got to have an open enough mind for God to guide you to what you should be doing, even if it's entirely different to what your friends and family think you should be doing.</p> <p>The world defines 'success' differently from God. The most successful person in God's Kingdom isn't necessarily a CEO in an Armani suit. So, defy the world's expectations. God does. Paul told Timothy, 'Don't let anyone look down on you because you are young,' because people thought Timothy was an inexperienced kid. It's easy to let other people decide what your life should look like, and just assume they're right because they're older or cleverer or genuinely lovely. But Paul thought differently; and so does God. So get God's opinion. In the end it's the only one that counts.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Ezra 3-5, Lk 9:46-62, Ps 78:1-8, Prov 19:21-23<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62141&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Courage with Cold Feet
content.introtext: 'Benaiah...went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.' 2 Samuel 23:20 NIV<br /><br /><p>Benaiah was the warrior in charge of all King David’s bodyguards. He went into a pit on a winter’s day, maybe to shelter from the cold. Just as his feet were defrosting, he found a new pit buddy: a lion. Maybe it had come in for shelter too. Or more likely, it was hungry and at most fearless in the scarce winter months. Benaiah couldn’t turn and run because he’d only meet a wall. He had to fight, or he’d die. The strongest animal in Israel was staring him down, snow steaming off its flanks. Benaiah’s courage, especially with cold feet, is the reason he is a famously valiant member of King David’s mightiest men. Because there was no middle ground to hide in, he fought the lion and killed it. Thousands of years later, God and His people still look at this personality trait as characteristic of the God–centred soul: boldness, right at the moment that fear threatens to swamp you. Think: when you can’t keep any more distance from the thing you’re afraid of, how do you respond? What puts steel in your spine when fear presses in? If you’re frozen with fear, for any reason, a good idea would be to ask some Christian friends if you can all meet up and pray about it. While it’s great to ask for advice, praying together is much more powerful. Because praying together lets God in on the problem.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Ezra 9-10; Luke 10:16-28; Ps 78:17-31; Pro 19:27-29<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62144&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Read and Run
content.introtext: 'And the Lord answered me: "Write the vision; make it plain on tablets, so he may run who reads it."' Habakkuk 2:2 ESV<br /><br /><p>In today’s verse, Habakkuk the prophet had been given the job of getting God’s message out to everyone in Israel. Big ask. To do this he had to write down God’s message on tablets (no, this was not like an iPad, more like an iRock.) The idea was for Habakkuk to write God’s words down so that, like an athlete in a relay race, he could pass them on to the next runner quickly. Then that runner would pass them on to the next, and so on until the message was spread around the land. People would be able to share the message quickly because it was a clear message, an obvious message; anyone could get it. God always does this when He has an important message: He makes it clear. He makes it simple. Remember how He introduced Himself to Moses at the burning bush? ‘I AM!’ Think of the most popular verse in the Bible, too: ‘For God so loved the world that He gave His one and only Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish but have eternal life.’ (John 3:16 NIV) Some of the Bible is tricky to understand, but the important stuff isn’t. So how are you introducing God to others? Is it in a way they can simply and quickly understand? For some people, the idea that ‘God is real!’ needs to be the first thing they hear. For others, the fact God is loving is a brand new concept. What message has God given you to share?</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 John 1:1-3:10; Luke 10:29-42; Ps 78:32-39; Pro 20:1-3<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62145&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: A Way Past Worry (1)
content.introtext: 'Don't worry about anything; instead, pray about everything.' Philippians 4:6 NLT<br /><br /><p>What happens when you’re praying instead of worrying? What feeds your worries? Until you can express your fears you can’t get rid of them. Putting your worries into words strips them of much of their power. In the book <em>Life of Pi</em>, Yann Martel’s main character, Pi, finds himself adrift at sea on a lifeboat with a 200kg Bengal tiger as his companion. While on the lifeboat, Pi begins to analyse his fears, both of the sea and the tiger. He gives this counsel: ‘You must fight hard to express your [fear]. You must fight hard to shine the light of words upon it. Because if you don’t, if your fear becomes a wordless darkness that you avoid, perhaps even manage to forget, you open yourself to further attacks of fear because you never truly fought the opponent who defeated you.’ So pull back the curtain and expose your fears, each and every one. They’re creatures of darkness and can’t stand the sunlight. Financial fears, relationship fears, professional fears, safety fears—call them out in prayer. Drag them out and make them stand before God. How do you do that? ‘Don’t worry about anything; instead, pray about everything… Then you will experience God’s peace, which exceeds anything we can understand…’ (Philippians 4:6–7 NLT) Send your fear packing. Pray, now. God’s the one who can act on the object of your fear, but the act of praying will also reassure you that you’re not being controlled by fear.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: John 1:1-14; Matt 4:12-16; Matt 5:14-16; Acts 9:1-19<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62147&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: A Way Past Worry (2)
content.introtext: '...I tell you not to worry about everyday life...' Matthew 6:25 NLT<br /><br /><p>Jesus said, ‘Therefore I tell you, stop being perpetually uneasy (anxious and worried) about your life…’ (Matthew 6:25 AMP) Not because the stuff you’re worrying about doesn’t exist, but because committing it all to God throws our focus back on the One who can fully care for us, has cared for us, and is going to carry on caring for us. Philippians 4:6–7 NKJ says, ‘...let your requests be made known to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.’ And the Phillips version puts it like this, ‘Don’t worry over anything whatever; tell God every detail of your needs in earnest and thankful prayer, and the peace of God which transcends human understanding, will keep constant guard over your hearts and minds as they rest in Christ Jesus.’ (Philippians 4:6–7 PHPS) When you’re more caught up in your love for God than concerned with getting over your worry, you often find that the worry melts off like candle wax anyway. So let your problems drive you into the arms of Jesus. And when you get there, stay there. Isn’t it odd how trying not to worry can become just another thing to worry about? Shouldn’t it be easy, this whole ‘not worrying’ thing? So go to God right now, tell Him all those worries and leave them with Him. If you start to worry again, say, ‘Sorry, Lord. I took back what I’d given You.’ And keep doing this until His peace really does keep guard over your heart.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 John 3:11-5:21; Luke 11:1-13; Ps 78:40-55; Pro 20:4-6<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62148&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Barriers are in Your Mind
content.introtext: '...He has sent me to proclaim freedom...recovery...release...favour.' Luke 4:18-19 NIV<br /><br /><p>If you look at ancient maps, you’ll see places which are marked with pictures of sea monsters (‘<em>Here Be Dragons</em>,’ that sort of thing) to warn off sailors. Were the dragons real? Well, they were real enough in the minds of the sailors. Think of a barracuda in an aquarium tank. A glass barrier divides one half from the other. Each time the barracuda tries to swim at it, it bumps into it. Ouch! Eventually, even if the barrier is taken away, the barracuda still won’t swim beyond that point—because, yep, it’s learned the ‘ouch’ point. The barrier is still in its mind. Jesus was sent to proclaim freedom, recovery and release. Satan will place barriers in your mind that say you can’t go beyond a certain point in life. The barriers are lies. But a lie is as effective as the truth if you believe it and act on it. The Bible is filled with stories of people who were thought to be too ‘little’ or way too insignificant to matter. Those same people went on to smash through barriers they thought they couldn’t. God used them to do amazing things. He’ll do that for you too, no matter how small or limited you feel, if you ask for it. A lie is as effective as the truth when you believe it. Christians are people of the truth, so ask God for His help to see where you or other people are struggling believing wrong things about themselves. Pray for ways to join Jesus today in proclaiming freedom, recovery and release.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 1-2; Luke 11:14-28; Ps 78:56-64; Pro 20:7-10<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62149&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Christian Lingo Bingo
content.introtext: '...Each of you must...speak truthfully to his neighbour...' Ephesians 4:25 NIV<br /><br /><p>Christian lingo: that strange language that means we say, ‘Wow, that guy is really anointed at playing guitar’ instead of ‘nice guitar playing, friend.’ Sometimes to speak the truth properly, we have to ditch the lingo. Sometimes for people to feel heard and properly related to, we need to speak a little more, well, honestly. This isn’t to say that Christian words are wrong; specialised Christian words can make tricky ideas plain and shed light on deeper truths. But when these are overused, hard–to–spot barriers can form between Christians and our non–Church friends. To them, what does ‘grace’ or ‘God bless you’ even mean? We can throw in the odd ‘Christian–ese’ word when it needs to be there, but it is so much more honest when we say, for example, ‘I was hurt by what you said,’ than ‘You are being un–Christlike’; or ‘I don’t understand either,’ than ‘God’s ways are higher!’ The list goes on. Let’s use our language honestly to open a window on truth, not cover it up. And if there are tricky Christian words you use all the time but don’t know the meaning of, then check it out online or in one of those wildly big Bible concordances, if there’s one lying around.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 4:24-5:26; Luke 11:45-54; Ps 119:1-8; Pro 20:15-18<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62151&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Quit Hitting Yourself
content.introtext: '...I find this law at work: When I want to do good, evil is right there with me.' Romans 7:21 NIV<br /><br /><p>You know those times when you know the right thing to do, but just can’t go through with it? When we walk away from something good and we dislike ourselves for it. When we actively hurt other people and it really sticks in our gut. Maybe we know our own sin quite well—and when we see it in our actions and attitudes or the things we attach ourselves to, it hurts. Sin constantly causes that inner struggle. The back–and–forth between good and bad. Check out the bigger passage behind today’s verse and you’ll get the idea: ‘I have the desire to do what is good, but I cannot carry it out. ...in my inner being I delight in God’s law; but I see another law at work in me, waging war against the law of my mind and making me a prisoner of the law of sin at work within me... Who will rescue me from this body that is subject to death? Thanks be to God, who delivers me through Jesus Christ our Lord!’ (Romans 7:16–25 NIV) What we’re called to do when we see our own sin is not to melt down, or get really annoyed at ourselves. It’s to return to God in our thoughts, not to our guilt. Eventually, as you do this more and more, you get the sense of the ‘the fear of the Lord’. ‘The fear of the Lord’ is a gift that prods us to go to God so He can reorder our habits, our mind’s patterns. He is willing to do this, and is just waiting for us to return to Him.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 6:1-7:19; Luke 12:1-12; Ps 119:9-16; Pro 20:19-21<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62152&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The New Self
content.introtext: '...Put on the new self, created to be like God...' Ephesians 4:24 NIV<br /><br /><p>There are times when God’s laws seem ludicrous to us. It’s probably fair to say that some of them seem beyond human ability. Like, ‘be perfect as your heavenly Father is perfect’—just what, even? But perhaps that’s the point. In Jesus you have a new, different self, and when you surrender your own ability to ‘do’ Christianity, you ‘put off your old self…and…put on the new self, created to be like God…’ (Ephesians 4:22–24 NIV) Is this still true even when you have to grit your teeth and really force yourself to obey God’s laws, moving past your first instincts? Yes. Living by God’s laws will become your instinct with time (Romans 6:17 tells us so.) It’s like when you’re coming around after waking from deep sleep. It takes a while to remember who and where you are. With time you realise you are a new person. Christian speaker Arthur Burt said, ‘I knew a man who always said “Keep looking down,” “You mean keep looking up, don’t you?”, “No! No! We are seated together with Christ in heavenly places!”’ As Christians we are no longer our old selves. We’re new, and we’re already at home with Christ and His laws, even if it doesn’t feel that way just yet. Next time you have the impulse to check Facebook or whatever on your phone, take the moment to pray for the person whose message you’re scrolling past. Caring for others is one way to ‘keep looking down’ and to ‘put on the new self, created to be like God.’</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 7:20-9:44; Luke 12:13-21; Ps 119:17-24; Pro 20:22-24<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62153&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Imposter (1)
content.introtext: '...take thought for what is honest...' Romans 12:17 AMP<br /><br /><p>We all want good, honest friendships. But we also can’t help hoping that our friends see the right ‘version’ of ourselves. They are allowed to see the carefully–crafted Facebook profile, but we keep our raw, honest selves hidden. Author Brennan Manning calls that crafted persona ‘<em>The Imposter</em>’, and said that we put it on when we want to ‘present a perfect image to the public so that everybody will admire us and nobody will know us.’ You may find that in your Church community or house group it’s difficult to really be yourself. There is this idea that, if we just all show up together and call ourselves Christians, everything will work out. But real life’s not always as simple as that—we have to learn to remove our masks. To make a space for honesty, we need to trust God that people won’t be so offended by honesty it will destroy us. Honesty is a decision to act for other people’s good and our own good. Actually being honest, by not holding back our shortcomings and failures, means our friends have to get used to what’s true and real about us. But this is a real relief. It is so worth it. When we live genuinely, and trust in God, before our friends and the world, then the glory of God will be on show in our lives more than ever before.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 16:1-18; John 6:1-15; John 6:25-40; 1 Cor 11:23-24 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62154&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Imposter (2)
content.introtext: '...In all things grow up into Him... that is, Christ.' Ephesians 4:15 NIV<br /><br /><p>Yesterday we saw that when we trust God, we can be more honest with ourselves and others about our shortcomings. Today we’re looking onwards. Ephesians 4 gives us a route into becoming someone who looks, sounds, and moves like Christ. The whole way through, this chapter is confident that we can get there. You are ‘created to be like God, truly righteous and holy.’ (Ephesians 4:24 GWT) ‘Then we will no longer be infants, tossed back and forth by the waves, and blown here and there by every wind...’ (Ephesians 4:14 NIV) What this Bible chapter says sounds next to crazy—‘<em>You, dear reader, hello—you! Yes, you can become like Jesus!</em>’—and it doesn’t hold back from letting you know. But spiritual growth doesn’t happen automatically. Growth always begins with a decision. When Jesus asked Matthew to become His disciple, Matthew didn’t really get all the implications of his decision; he more–or–less said, ‘Yeah, alright boss,’ and went from there. That’s all you need to get started. A decision. Nothing shapes your life like the decisions you make. If you want to know what you’ll be like twenty or thirty years from now, look closely at the commitments that rule your life today. Is the challenge of Ephesians 4 pressing into your life, now? Look at your commitments and priorities. Type them up. And put today’s verse at the top. How do the things you want or need to do line up with becoming more like Jesus? If they don’t, it’s time to rethink them.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 10:1-12:22; Luke 12:22-34; Ps 119:25-32; Pro 20:25-27<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62155&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: God as a Parent (1)
content.introtext: 'You gave me life and showed me kindness, and in Your providence watched over my spirit.' Job 10:12 NIV<br /><br /><p>We’re not likely to hear people say ‘God is my mother’. But some of the things we usually expect our mothers to do, God also does for us. God’s care, kindness and (yep, almost motherly...) life–giving love is there for us. We’re supposed to get comfort from it, when we need it. In Job 10, Job’s life has gone down the tube. He was alone. He was covered in painful sores. Most of his family was dead. Then he remembered where he came from in the first place. Job asked God where His comfort and care went to and why God had stopped acting like the good Parent he used to know. When we’ve lost perspective on our life because things are tough, we can turn to God like this. He’s the Provider who has promised to keep a caring eye on us all our lives, so we can say, ‘God—you birthed me into this world. You saved me and promised to look after me. Where are You now? Come help me!’ Job recognised he needed this kind of perspective. He looked back on his life and recognised that God had always been faithful, and it’s the same for us—He’s been with us since day one, and isn’t about to stop. You know that ‘just came back after a weekend/month/term away’ catch–up chat that happens when you get home? Have it with God. Just spend time talking through life right now with Him. Ask Him to have His hand in it.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 12:23-15:29; Luke 12:35-48; Ps 119:33-40; Pro 20:28-30<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62156&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: God as a Parent (2)
content.introtext: 'Blessed are those whose ways are blameless, who walk according to the law of the Lord.' Psalm 119:1 NIV<br /><br /><p>If we want to actually grow as His children, God wants us to do more than lean on His mercy. We need to start there. Absolutely everything has to come first from His love for us. Equally, that isn’t the end of His gift to us. He wants us to develop our character as we put His laws into practice, because we can grow into something better. God is a Father who wants to see us become closer to Him both in relationship and likeness. He doesn’t want us to see Him as Someone shouting down rules from the clouds. When we get this, His correction starts to make sense. We start to listen to His laws, to stay attentive for His voice that draws us into life, to see joy where we currently struggle with sin, to ‘get’ the need for discipline where we have no patience. He will resist our excuse–making, our posing, and our hiding from obedience because He’s painting a bigger picture. We only know whatever details are in front of us right now. But He knows how the whole thing is going to look when it’s finished! We only know the corner of the room we happen to be in today, He has the blueprints for the whole house. Be reassured that He knows what He’s building in you and that His plans are perfect.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 16-18; Luke 12:49-59; Ps 119:41-48; Pro 21:1-3<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62157&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: God as a Parent (3)
content.introtext: 'Give ear and come to Me; listen, that you may live. I will make an everlasting covenant with you...' Isaiah 55:3 NIV<br /><br /><p>So let’s bring these last two days’ readings together. God’s care looks like the love of a good parent: sometimes comfort, sometimes discipline. But when we zoom out, it’s all part of His promise never to stop loving us. There’s a word for that. Many Bibles translate it as ‘loving–kindness’, but the Hebrew word for it is ‘chesed’ (pronounced ‘hes–ed’). ‘Chesed’ is the love promised by God to His people. It’s very different from every other form of love out there because it involves loyalty from a perfect God. His unshakeable, undeserved love that sticks with us because He is for us. Even when we’re against Him. 2 Timothy 2:13 NIV says: ‘If we are faithless, He will remain faithful.’ God knows we’re an unfaithful bunch—But that doesn't phase Him. ‘Chesed’ is an active love: not just a one–off sweet deal at the Cross, but God moving in our lives every day. This is great news. It makes us here at word4U2day excited, anyway! And God doesn’t force us to reflect His love! We enter out of our own freedom into a relationship with Him. Even when our feelings betray us, or we have a bad day and can’t be bothered with the thought of picking up a Bible, God’s given us something that goes beyond emotions, a love that we can decide to do, not just feel our way into. One good way of helping your decision/will to support your love for God is to read the Bible everyday. If you haven’t started with SoulFood yet, why not begin today?</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 19:1-23:20; Luke 13:1-17; Ps 119:49-56; Pro 21:4-6<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62158&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Beauty in Corners
content.introtext: 'Whatever is right... think about [it].' Philippians 4:8 NIV<br /><br /><p>A man chained in a prison cell wrote, ‘...whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is admirable—if anything is excellent or praiseworthy—think about such things.’ This was Paul, locked up in a foreign country just for being a Christian. He was writing the letter to the Philippians. He won’t have taken a lot of inspiration from his immediate environment—four tight corners and a damp ceiling—and, worse, he was stuck there day in, day out. It’s not always easy to get inspiration from what’s physically in front of you. Your school may not have been the nicest place to attend. Your street may not have been a great place to grow up. And on a bad day, being pushed into a tight corner just one time too many can kick off a gloomy mood. God is the stable centre of all beauty. Wherever and whenever you are, you can live healthily, if you are fixed on Him. Whether that’s some truth you’ve found in the Bible or a person who shows you the beauty of Jesus or just a morning of quiet worship while you get on with your job, it doesn’t matter. When we have God at the forefront of our minds we can say, ‘The Lord is my chosen portion and my cup; You hold my lot. The lines have fallen for me in pleasant places; indeed, I have a beautiful inheritance.’ (Psalm 16:5–6 ESV) American pastor Jonathan Martin said, ‘Whenever and wherever you see beauty, you will always be able to follow it back to Jesus.’ Keep an eye out.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 23:21-26:19; Luke 13:18-35; Ps 119:57-64; Pro 21:7-9<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62159&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Your Doubts Don't Disqualify You
content.introtext: '...Do not be unbelieving, but believing.' John 20:27 NKJ <br /><br /><p>*<em>Previously, in the book of the Gospel of John...</em>* The resurrection happened and someone missed it. He got a bit huffy. ‘Unless I see the nail marks in His hands and put my finger where the nails were, and put my hand into His side, I will not believe.’ (John 20:25 NKJ) Yep, it was Thomas and he wasn’t going to be taken in by any nonsense about people rising from the dead. As if! ‘A week later His disciples were in the house again, and Thomas was with them. Though the doors were locked, Jesus came and stood among them and said, “Peace be with you!” Then He said to Thomas, “Put your finger here; see My hands. Reach out your hand and put it into My side. Stop doubting and believe.” Thomas said to Him, “My Lord and my God!”’ (John 20:24–28 NIV) Jesus put an end to Thomas’ unbelief, but He didn’t tell him off for having doubts. It’s so important we get this. Jesus does not hate us for struggling with doubts—not even doubts about His existence. What He wants to do is show you Himself, not punish you for wondering or thinking. Your doubts do not disqualify you. (It’s important to add we shouldn’t allow them to take control. God isn’t a ‘tame lion’ and He won’t always show Himself up the way we ask Him to. But countless doubting Christians have found that when they’ve searched for God, they’ve found hope.) Recently been finding yourself doubting? Take it slowly. Step by step. Whatever’s on your mind, share it with someone you trust—maybe your youth pastor. And, our inbox is always open. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chron 26:20-29:30; Luke 14:1-14; Ps 119:65-72; Pro 21:10-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62160&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Habitat for Divinity (1)
content.introtext: '...This has been your manner from your youth...' Jeremiah 22:21 NKJ<br /><br /><p>How often do we go through our days multi–tasking between our ‘Christian’ mind and our ‘normal’ mind? Like tabbing between pages on a web browser, this can eventually use up all our attention and wear us out. We are whole people, not fractured beings. Splitting off our minds into a spiritual bit and non–spiritual bit ends up being unhealthy. How do we fix this? First up: habits are key. The patterns in how you think about things, how you act in certain situations, and the behaviours you return to, make up your whole person. So they’re pretty important, and God cares about them (Like, a lot. The story behind today’s verse is God calling out His people for repeatedly ignoring Him over centuries...) Habits can keep your attention on God and the person He has made you to be, bringing your mind into a focused peace. Habits free you up to do things more quickly and remove mental clutter so that you can think clearly about important things. They play a part in making your whole being a place that God can come and live in. More on that tomorrow! A good way to check your habits may be to have someone you respect and trust question you on the way you react to people, particularly when you’re tired or upset. Are your responses coming from a fear of people, or a ‘fear of God’? (check back to August 8 for more on the ‘fear of God’.) </p><br /><br />SoulFood: John 4:4-26; John 7:37-41; Exo 17:1-7; Isa 35:1-7 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62161&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Habitat for Divinity (2)
content.introtext: 'And you shall again obey the voice of the Lord and keep all His commandments... [He] will again take delight in prospering you...' Deuteronomy 30:8-9 ESV<br /><br /><p>Your habits make a habitat. If those habits make a habitat of praise, then it will be a place where God comes and lives. ‘You inhabit the praises of Israel.’ (Psalm 22:3 NKJ) When we try hard to live in a way that is in line with God’s law, though we can’t fully get it right at first (trying to love your enemies—whaaat?) our attempts make room for God to come and ‘fill in the gap’. So, for example, we may start out trying to love people who are very hard to like. It’s definitely possible to act for the wellbeing of another person without actually liking the person. And God wants it, and we’re keeping His command, so that’s great. But as we keep on trying out that ‘practical’ love, we make space for God to come and fill our hearts with a love that includes feelings, includes joy, and includes—yes!—actually liking the people we find hard to like. This is the power of the Holy Spirit. Our attempts to do things we find impossible make us fall back on the transforming power of God, and His grace. We submit to God and He enables us to make it happen. You could start (if you’re feeling brave... err, not feeling brave? Then ask Him for a bit of courage), by approaching the person who’s come to mind in this reading. A few difficult but meaningful kind words can change a lot. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 1-4; Luke 14:15-24; Ps 119:73-80; Pro 21:14-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62162&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: A Thumbs-Up That Matters
content.introtext: 'Who is he who condemns?...' Romans 8:34 NKJ<br /><br /><p>When it comes to an area of your life that needs improvement, it’s good to be concerned about it, but not consumed with it. You’ll always be working on some area of your life, so learning that who you are in Christ is not going to change will be pretty important if you want to sleep at night: ‘There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus…’ (Romans 8:1 NKJ) Because God has chosen to see you ‘in Christ’, He finds you acceptable, every day (more than that, He’s downright thrilled to know you. Really.) and you always have access to Him. Your ‘who’ is not based on your ‘do’. God’s not about shaming and blaming you. Yeah, He’ll convict you (meaning His Holy Spirit will point out the things you’ve done wrong.) When you stop resisting His goodness (hint here: repent—that means decide to turn your back on your bad habits and turn to Him) He’ll get you back up on your feet, but He won’t be shaking His head and glaring while He does it. You do that to yourself. God never will. ‘Who is he who condemns? It is Christ who died, and furthermore is also risen, who is even at the right hand of God, who makes intercession for us.’ (Romans 8:34 NKJ) This means Jesus gives you His thumbs–up, and it remains the only thumbs–up–or–down that matters. Conclusion: ”What then shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?” (Romans 8:31 ESV)</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 5-7; Luke 14:25-35; Ps 119:81-88; Pro 21:17-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62164&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Faceplanting out of Freedom
content.introtext: 'Blessed are they... who walk according to the law of the Lord.' Psalm 119:1 NIV<br /><br /><p>Have a flick through Psalm 119, and you’ll see that the writer really, really liked getting stuck into God’s law. This is not just a hobby. So, why should we choose to focus on what only God wants for us, and not work off our instincts or other people’s advice? You’ll start to understand the Psalmist’s enthusiasm about hard moral codes if you think about kids playing on a cliff edge. Without a fence you’re counting the seconds until one of them makes a fatal faceplant. With a fence, there’s no worries. God’s law is a fence that brings incredible freedom. Maybe it’s only a matter of time until one of the kids starts wondering what’s on the other side of the fence. If they don’t know or trust the fence builder, they hop the fence—and kerplonk. Brutal. If they survive, they come back saying like the Psalmist, ‘I used to wander off until You disciplined me; but now I closely follow Your Word.’ (Psalm 119:67 NLT) The Ten Commandments start with the words, ‘I am the Lord your God…’ (Exodus 20:2 ESV) All the don’t kill, steal etc. bits come after; God speaks about the relationship first, then about the rules that keep it on safe ground. It’s when we understand that the fence builder absolutely loves us and wants the best for us we’re happy to stay on the right side of the fence. In your prayer time with God today, ask Him to point out where He’s put up important fences you might have not seen yet. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 8-11; Luke 15:1-10; Ps 119:89-96; Pro 21:20-23 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62165&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Help for Stress (1)
content.introtext: 'Anxiety weighs down the heart, but a kind word cheers it up.' Proverbs 12:25 NIV<br /><br /><p>Your stomach’s in knots, you feel like an elephant’s on your chest, your thoughts are smashed by a whirlwind. Where can you find relief? In stressed–out days it’s hard to remember that you, as you are, with all your weakness and tired thoughts, are still valued by God. He has said you are His beloved. Even when you come down harshly on yourself, He does not change how He thinks about you. When you forget that God has said you are valued, it’s important to have friends who will come and show you that. Especially if you show kindness to others when they are struggling, but you don’t always show to yourself. One of the wonderful things about being part of the Church is that other Christians can ‘be’ Christ to you in those moments. They can show you what God thinks of you, in patience, quiet listening, in some well–placed humour at the right time. These are really important ways we experience the love of God through our friends who carry His Holy Spirit. Do you have those sorts of friends? And, if you’re feeling pretty on top of things at the moment, are you that sort of friend to someone else? If you’re going through a stressy patch, it could be helpful to venture out and connect with friends who’ve proven to be good listeners before. Or you can txt (0401 132 888) or call PrayForMe (1800 PrayForMe), if you want to chat it over anonymously. Find a way to bring your anxiety to God.</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: 2 Chron 12-15; Luke 15:11-32; Ps 119:97-104; Pro 21:24-27 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62166&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Help for Stress (2)
content.introtext: 'In the multitude of my anxieties within me, Your comforts delight my soul.' Psalm 94:19 NKJ<br /><br /><p>About three hundred years ago, minister Matthew Henry rifled through the Bible and wrote cool comments on all the verses. Here’s what he had to say about today’s verse: ‘The world’s comforts give little delight to the soul, when hurried with melancholy thoughts; but God’s comforts bring that peace and pleasure which the smiles of the world cannot give, and which the frowns of the world cannot take away.’ Today, most people sense there must be something deeper to how we feel than ‘just getting through’ from day to day. To stay in touch with our humanity we have to look out for God’s comforts. As you walk around today, notice what God puts in your path. The old clichés are to watch a sunset or lie on a beach. It’s true; these are things we can be grateful for when we’re able to do them. But you might have to train yourself up to look out for the beauty of God in places you can notice every day. To appreciate a conversation with a friend. To make a small gesture of kindness to someone in your family you take for granted. To stop being hurried and find that deeper comfort that the world can’t take away. When you do this, you might even find that the Author of beauty Himself sneaks up on you to delight in it with you. Nothing restores your soul more than God Himself. If you’re on autopilot today, take a deep breath, switch it off and turn to Jesus in prayer. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 16-18; Luke 16:1-18; Ps 119:105-112; Pro 21:28-31 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62167&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Bring It. (1)
content.introtext: 'If you are insulted for the name of Christ, you are blessed, because the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you.' 1 Peter 4:14 ESV<br /><br /><p>Corrie Ten Boom was a young Christian when her home country, the Netherlands, was invaded in World War II. She quickly got fearful she wouldn’t know what to do if the Nazis confronted her. So her dad told her, ‘When you are going to take a journey on the train, do I give you your ticket three weeks early or just as you get on the train?’ Corrie said, ‘As I get on the train.’ ‘So God will give you the special strength you need to be strong in the face of death just when you need it, not before.’ Are you worried you don’t have the strength to live for God? Feel like you lack the ‘oomph’ to be a powerful Christian? Whether you discover it like Corrie, facing danger and persecution, or right when you step out to tell someone the Gospel, or in the moment when you get hit by hurtful insults, God’s strength comes right when you need it. We’re even promised: ‘...don’t worry about what to say or how to say it. At that time you will be given the things to say. It will not really be you speaking but the Spirit of your Father speaking through you.’ (Matthew 10:19–20 NCV) Whether you feel it or not, your God has got your back: when you step out for God (and maybe not even a second beforehand), you’ll discover you have all that you need. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 19-21; Luke 16:19-31; Ps 119:113-120; Pro 22:1-3 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62168&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Bring It. (2)
content.introtext: '...God led you through the wilderness...to prove your character...' Deuteronomy 8:2 NLT<br /><br /><p>In Florida, wiry trees called Caribbean Pines thrive in deadly environments. They stick out drought, fire and hurricanes. In fact, if you plant them in a setting trees normally love, they’re so hardcore they just shrivel and die. It can be a similar case with our souls: we shrivel because things go so well we feel we don’t need God. Sometimes we need a wilderness to refine our faith like the children of Israel who were led into the desert: ‘to prove [their] character, and… find out whether or not [they] would obey His commandments.’ They could choose to give up and shrivel up there, or trust Him to bring them safely to the Promised Land. When things get too comfortable, our faith actually shrivels. The odd blast of wilderness can be genuinely good for us. Sometimes God allows the fiery draught of very difficult times so we can see what’s in our faith—is it made of the good, solid stuff that trusts in God?—and to mature it and get to the true and better person inside. God leads you through the wilderness to prove your character. That also means that He’s in control. Your ‘wilderness’, if you’ve given your life to God, is both for a purpose (the best there can be: His loving plan for you) and it’s safe—in His hands. Look back on the last three months. What hard times have you been brought through? What good things have come from them that couldn’t have happened otherwise? Rejoice when rough times look like they’re about to sweep in. Bring it on! </p><br /><br />SoulFood: John 10:1-18; Rev 7:13-17; Ps 23; Luke 15:1-7 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62169&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Mentor, Mentee
content.introtext: '...The works that I do [you] will do also...' John 14:12 NKJ<br /><br /><p> Jesus told His disciples, ‘The works that I do you will do also.’ Skip forward to the book of Acts and guess what? They did! They took on His character and became like Him. What happened in between? He mentored them. If you want to get somewhere in life, ask God for the right mentors. Some mentors you get for a short chunk of your life, others for a lifetime. Some of them might even be close friends who end up discipling you in a quiet, hidden way. So how do you recognise a mentor? They might be someone who sticks by these promises: (1) I’m willing to spend time to build a close relationship with this friend; (2) I’ll keep believing in the potential of this friend, keep getting them excited about the future I see ahead of them; (3) I’m willing to be vulnerable and available to my friend, to share not only my strengths and successes, but also my weaknesses, failures, and generally–rubbish moments; (4) When it’s right to, I am willing to be honest in confronting my friend; (5) I am committed to standing by them through trials—even trials that they bring on themselves; (6) I’ll help them set goals for a spiritual life or ministry; (7) I’ll actually practice what I preach. None of this ‘talking the talk without walking the walk’ business. Find a mentor. Become a mentor. It’s a top way to fit all the different pieces of the Christian life together. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 22-24; Luke 17:1-10; Ps 119:121-128; Pro 22:4-7 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62170&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Thank God?
content.introtext: '...His sheep follow him because they know his voice.' John 10:4 NIV<br /><br /><p>If you’re chatting with a good mate, there’s an ease in the flow of your conversation because you know who you’re talking to. You know the person who’s listening to your words. You feel safe in knowing what you say won’t be taken the wrong way. Talking to God is sometimes less easy when you’re first getting to know Him because it can feel like talking to a blank canvas (maybe you remember that, or you’re going through it now). Who is He? What does He want to hear? What does He want me to say? Or even if He seems to have gone quiet with you, or was never ‘loud’—how do you get into a place where you can even begin to learn to hear His voice? This is why so many of Christianity’s traditional prayers start with thanks. When we start our prayers with gratefulness we are doing what’s right (giving God His due for everything He’s given) and we’re starting to get a sense of the person we’re talking to: the Giver of all good gifts. When we’re thanking Him, we’re starting to learn His character. Ann Voskamp says, ‘Giving thanks in all things is how to pray continually [1 Thessalonians 5:17–18]... This is the way to do God’s will for your right now. Thanks to God is what calms the wild heart.’ So, praise Him! Lots! Then listen out...</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: 2 Chron 25-28; Luke 17:11-19; Ps 119:129-136; Pro 22:8-10 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62172&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Shadow Ops
content.introtext: 'He... shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty.' Psalm 91:1 NKJ<br /><br /><p>What is the ‘shadow of the Almighty’? You might think of an overcast day and wonder if this is a bit of a not–very–sunshiney gloomy thought. But if you’d been living in the blistering heat of a desert for the last forty years—which is exactly what God’s people had been doing for a fair chunk of the Old Testament (post–Prince of Egypt)—then it’s something a little more appealing. So the Israelites, as you can imagine, liked a good shadow or two. It meant shelter and comfort in a very hot climate. What does it mean for us? We know that God’s personality isn’t all–guns–blazing, instead He’s our place of safety. We can read ‘shadow’ as ‘safety’. In the blistering heat of life’s battles, temptations, and worries, God is the life–saving shadow we can always come back to. Yes, we have to go on the offensive sometimes, and withstand the attacks of Satan, and fight back with Scripture. But, in reality, as humans, we aren’t set up to be at the forefront of battle all the time. We need to rest in God. Think about this: could you spend the whole day walking in the shadow of the person beside you. How close would you have to stay to be able to manage it? Would you have to change the rhythm of your walk to stay there? What does this tell you about ‘being in God’s shadow’? Yep, stay close and move as God moves.</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: 2 Chron 29-31; Luke 17:20-37; Ps 119:137-144; Pro 22:11-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62173&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Faith! But What Does It Mean?
content.introtext: 'Faith is the substance of things hoped for...' Hebrews 11:1 NKJ<br /><br /><p>There’s lots we can’t do on our own. Especially as Christians. Stuff like overcoming the world—see 1 John 5:4—can only be done with faith in God. ‘Faith’ is one of those words that’s not often defined for us (like ‘Hosanna’ or ‘Amen’... ‘Bless’...) But today’s verse gives a pretty clear definition of what faith is. What does it look like? (a) Being certain of victory. Back to 1 John 5:4. Our victory over Satan comes by faith, not by willpower and discipline. Faith comes from the Word of God, not from anything within ourselves. (b) Being certain of growing to be like God. Faith isn’t a one–time event that starts and finishes the moment you become a Christian. We keep growing in our faith. By learning. ‘So faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of Christ.’ (Romans 10:17 ESV) And by doing. ‘What good is it, my brothers, if someone says he has faith but does not have works?’ (James 2:14 ESV) So much of this ‘faith’ business is about being ok with the future. This is not easy… if you’re struggling to see past things that worry you, head back to August 3 & 4. And soak in the knowledge that, as you spend daily time in the Word of God (try SoulFood), that God will build faith in you. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 32-34; Luke 18:1-17; Ps 119:145-160; Pro 22:14-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62174&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Too Busy to Love?
content.introtext: '...He has commanded us to love one another...' 2 John 1:6 NLT<br /><br /><p>Life can be busy. And it’s great (really, really great) you take time out with God in the middle of all that. So now, what about your on–earth relationships? Jesus made it pretty clear the second most important thing in life, right after loving God, is loving people (that’s in Matthew 22:37–40, team). And to do that, we have to spend time around others— even those irritating, imperfect, demanding, frustrating people. It’s awful for our relationships if we don’t put time and effort into them. That’s how friends ‘drift apart’ and how families can start to misunderstand each other. Plus, we need other people. That few minutes spent chatting to your mate, or that Sunday roast round the table—it all adds something to your life because God made us to live in community. The love of others is good for us. And, the love we send out is good for those others. Ask God to fill you up with His love, to the point that you’re positively overflowing with it. Then, if you take the time to really share a little of your day with another person, chances are, you’ll be able to share God in some way too. Even if that’s just in the friendly hello someone needs to hear today. A practical exercise in loving: Go to your phone. Scroll down to the 10th person you texted and start there. Pray for that person that they’ll have a really blessed day. You could even send them an encouragement to top it up, if you liked. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chron 35-36; 2 John; Luke 18:18-30; Ps 119:161-168; Pro 22:17-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62175&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Keep On Keeping On and Keeping On
content.introtext: '...but I focus on this one thing: Forgetting the past and looking forward to what lies ahead.' Philippians 3:13 NLT <br /><br /><p>In Philippians 3, Paul talks about how he really, genuinely, very–very–earnestly wants to live a Jesus–centred life. But he’s under no illusions. He knows he’s not already perfect. Read Philippians 3:12–13. There, Paul explains something so important— that, no matter how human he is in this life, he’s adamant that he’ll press on, looking forward to his future relationship with Christ perfected in Heaven. What a brilliant example! We all need to recognise where our lives don’t look like Jesus’, and take those areas to God in prayer and apologise. As soon as we give our mistakes up to God, He lays them to rest, reminding us to move on, looking ahead to our final goal of being with Christ forever. But we can have a tendency to keep hold of the past. Sometimes that’s through guilting ourselves, but sometimes in a very different way. In a weird way, it can be tempting to look fondly on our past sins (Really. Think about it… it happens more than you might realise). There’s a part of us all that’s twisted and wants to be loudly proud of those ‘wasn’t I a rebel’ moments. Truth is, that point of view is just not healthy. If you’re still tied to your past in any way, it’ll be harder to move forwards, towards ‘that perfection’ that Paul calls for us to focus on. Think: what have you done (or do you still do) that you feel stops you heading towards ‘that perfection’? Pray your apology, and ask for help. Then hit delete. Let it go from your records, just like it’s gone from God’s.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 3 John; Jude; Luke 18:31-43; Ps 119:169-176; Pro 22:20-23 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62178&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Your Life is a Tree
content.introtext: 'Endure until your testing is over. Then you will be mature and complete...' James 1:4 GWT<br /><br /><p>Tomorrow is the official start of Spring. Flowers and stuff. Great. Then, a few months from now, spring will have sprung and it’ll be sizzling into summer. Your life works the same, in cycles and seasons. That means some periods of our lives are all green grass, shiny newness and fresh loveliness. It also means some periods will be dead leaves, rain and sniffles. Whichever you have right now, God’s on it. He’s the one who decides when we get spring–like growth seasons. And when we need a stretch of... being s t r e t c h e d... He brings us into (and through) it. ‘For everything there is a season.’ (Ecclesiastes 3:1 NLT) That’s not to downplay how outright rubbish those tough seasons can feel. But they’re a necessary part of God’s long–term plan. Think about a tree. The only reason it has space to grow strong, healthy, green leaves in spring is because it lost the leaves it’d finished with last autumn. And it only grew new ones after shivering, bare–branched, through winter. If everything looks barren and cold around you right now, we 100% guarantee it’s only for a time. In that time, the best thing you can do is stick to God, and let the difficulty He has allowed you to face do its work. Seasons come and go. So it’s important to have a stable centre to your life. Are there any places in your room that you can turn into ‘prayer spaces’? It doesn’t have to be a wooden bench to kneel at, it could even just be a beanbag. Make it special place to remind you to meet with God each day.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Phil 2:5-11; Rev 19:11-16; Acts 3:1-16; Matt 1:18-21 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62180&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Resetting the Relationship
content.introtext: 'Tell the Israelites to designate the cities of refuge...' Joshua 20:2 NIV<br /><br /><p>In the Old Testament, God’s people had a High Priest every generation, set apart and ‘anointed with the holy oil’ (Numbers 35:25 NRS) to represent that generation to God, and also to represent God to them. When he died, then the one who had represented God had passed away. God allowed his death to signify the removal of sin from His people and to ‘reset’ their relationship with Him. This was particularly useful with regard to the laws about accidentally killing someone. Legally, the victim’s family could take your life in exchange. Not good. But God is all about forgiveness. He told Israel to set up six ‘cities of refuge’—essentially safe bases. You ran to them, explained your story to the town elders, and hid out in the town, knowing they were duty–bound to protect you. No–one hunting you was allowed to enter the city at all. Safe. And the thing that really showed the extent of God’s grace was this: you weren’t even trapped there for life. When the High Priest died, you were ‘forgiven’—released from your sanctuary and allowed to go home. No one was permitted to harm you. The relationship had been ‘reset’. Spotted Jesus yet? Jesus, our ‘High Priest’, really represents us to God (Hebrews 4:14): Jesus didn’t just carry us into a Temple’s Holy of Holies but into the throne room of Heaven itself. He died once, for all time, resetting our relationship with God to ‘forgiven’. If you run to God’s refuge in Jesus, then wherever you are, Satan can’t touch you, and you’re in a completely restored relationship with God. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Josh 1-4; Luke 19:1-10; Ps 84; Pro 22:24-26 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62181&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Brethren, Assemble (1)
content.introtext: 'Behold, how good and how pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity!' Psalm 133:1 KJV<br /><br /><p>Grab a Bible and read Psalm 133. It’s short. It’ll probably take about half a second. Ok, maybe half a minute. Chances are you’ve heard that opening verse before. And yeah, it certainly is nice when we get along. But why? What is there about unity that’s so special for us Christians? Is there something more to it than it just making us feel warm and fuzzy? Well, verses two and three of Psalm 133 name oil and dew. Hmm. It might seem a bit poetic at first, but it’s got real meaning. Oil being dropped on a person happened as a symbol of the Holy Spirit ‘anointing’ them, and the power that comes with that. More often than not, that ‘anointing’ was a sign of God giving someone the power to go and carry out one of His plans. And dew crops up in Isaiah 26:19. Interestingly, it’s a symbol of that same power giving new life (by resurrecting the dead) to God’s people. Oil = God’s Spirit and power. Dew = God’s Spirit and power. So, what the Psalmist seems to be saying here is that, when we ‘live together in unity’ (Psalm 133:1 NIV), something mind–blowingly huge happens—as a community, we receive death–beating power that enables us to do what God wants. God comes to rest in a very real way over the collection of people who are brought together because of Him. As individuals, we don’t have what we have as community. Pretty good reason to do that ‘fellowship’ thing, huh? </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Josh 5:1-8:29; Luke 19:11-27; Ps 103:1-12; Pro 22:27-29 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62182&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

Romans 12:5 NIV<br /><br /><p>Yesterday was all about what happens when Christians work together. Wonderful stuff. Now. How? How do we work together? How do we do unity? Paul has some great advice in Romans. He compares the Church to the human body. He writes: ‘...since we are all one body in Christ, we belong to each other, and each of us needs all the others. If every piece chooses to be the right shape, the overall picture will come together, no problems. And, with a God–designed team around you, you have no reason to be nervous of taking up your part in things. content.title: Grow Passion, Grow Fruit
content.introtext: '...he who does wrong will receive the consequences...' Colossians 3:25 NAS<br /><br /><p>John Ortberg writes: ‘My friend Andy Chan headed up the placement office for helping graduates find work. He says that some day he wants to write a book called The Myth of Passion. This is the myth that somewhere out there is the perfect job, the idealised calling that fits my soul the way a key fits into a lock. And if I could just find that job, torrents of passion would cascade out of my heart like water going over Niagara Falls.’ Just about all of us have a romantic idea that we will find ‘job–love at first sight.’ But what if you are in a job that doesn’t excite you? What if you have to study stuff that seems downright boring? Ortberg writes: ‘Passion for our work is not usually a subterranean volcano waiting to erupt… It is a muscle that gets strengthened a little each day... as we do what is expected of us, and then some.’ Paul wrote: ‘Whatever you do, do your work heartily, as for the Lord... knowing that from the Lord you will receive the reward of the inheritance. It is the Lord Christ whom you serve. For he who does wrong will receive the consequences of the wrong which he has done.’ (Colossians 3:22–25 NKJV) Maybe it would help to put a sticker up on your phone: ‘For God’s sake—do your best!’ Why? For two reasons: (1) Because you represent Christ wherever you go. (2) When you are faithful in small things, He will promote you to greater things (Matthew 25:21). </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Josh 11-13; Luke 19:41-48; Ps 111; Pro 23:4-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62185&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: It Is Worth It.
content.introtext: 'If I can just touch [Him], I will be healed.' Mark 5:28 NLT<br /><br /><p>Mark’s Gospel records the story of a Jewish woman who, for twelve solid years, had been suffering from an ‘issue’ of constant bleeding. For this lady, in the society in which she lived, the impact on her life was devastating. She was totally broke, having spent all her money on medical bills. The religious laws said her husband couldn’t go near her. Babies were totally off the cards. Everything she touched was considered ‘spiritually unclean’. The religious laws meant she couldn’t even go to worship God in the Temple. She was completely worn–out, and not even allowed to go to God’s house to be refreshed. At the end of her tether, she decided to put her trust in God. She went out into a crowd that was disgusted by (and probably afraid of) her, and she grabbed hold of the fringe of Jesus’ prayer cloak. And it worked. Her earnest faith did something amazing—it drew the power of God to her, and she was healed. She was freed from all of the laws that made her life difficult. She could enter God’s temple, stand tall in her community again, not look in the mirror and see ‘unclean’. And all of this, just from grabbing Jesus’ garment in an act of faith as He passed by. What could you do, if He stood in front of you now? Is there an ‘issue’ where you need to reach out in faith to Jesus to be healed? Take it to Him now.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Josh 14-15; Luke 20:1-8; Ps 142; Pro 23:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62187&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: On You Go
content.introtext: 'There are different kinds of gifts, but the same Spirit...' 1 Corinthians 12:4 NIV<br /><br /><p>Paul writes, ‘There are different kinds of gifts, but the same spirit.’ Successful people invest their time, energy and resources into their core strengths. Why? Because that is where they get their highest return! Occasionally they’ll try their hand at something new. Take Michael Jordan, for example, arguably the world’s most famous basketball player. For various reasons MJ decided to try his hand at baseball for a season. He may have enjoyed the experience, but exiting the game so early is probably not what he’d like to be remembered for. God gave you gifts that make you unique, gifts that hold great possibilities. But you have to discover them and develop them. A sign on a DIY shop says it all: ‘We’ve got it, if you can find it.’ Nobody was ever born without talent, including you, but you’ve got to find it. What keeps us from doing that? (1) The company we keep. The old saying goes, ‘If you run around with turkeys, you’ll never fly with eagles.’ The Scripture says, ‘He who walks with wise men, will be wise...’ (Proverbs 13:20 NKJV) (2) Failing to spend time in prayer and in God’s Word. God is not only the giver of your gift, He supplies the strength to function successfully in it. Aristotle said, ‘We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence then is not an act, but a habit.’ So if you want to succeed, consult God, and operate in your God-given strength. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Josh 16:1-19:23; Luke 20:9-19; Ps 20; Pro 23:10-12 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62188&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Commitment Issues
content.introtext: '...Let us love one another, for love comes from God...' 1 John 4:7 NIV<br /><br /><p>Oops. We said it. But relax; we’re not going to force you into marriage. What we’re talking about is Godly commitment to everyone around you, and everything you do. God commits to loving, growing and parenting you. And with Him doing that, you can’t help but share that love with others. The whole of 1 John 4:7 NCV reads: ‘Dear friends, we should love each other, because love comes from God. Everyone who loves has become God’s child and knows God.’ Now, hands up… who speaks Greek? Hmm, stick with us anyway. That second sentence, ‘Everyone who loves has become God’s child and knows God’ isn’t exactly straightforward. In the original Greek, there is one word that means ‘has become God’s child’, and it does some weird stuff with tenses. It’s past and present all at the same time; it means ‘has become God’s child right at that point, and will continue to become more and more God’s child as time goes on.’ Sooo… everyone who shows God’s love has been adopted by God and shows Him through their relationships and work. But it doesn’t stop there. God promises to put work into fathering and teaching them, every day, for the rest of their lives (pretty good model for commitment). And under that sort of attention from God, our human commitment to sharing love with the world becomes way more do–able each day. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Heb 11; Matt 21:18-22; Matt 8:5-13; Mark 6:1-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62189&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: It's Not You, It's Me
content.introtext: '...be patient, bearing with one another in love.' Ephesians 4:2 NIV<br /><br /><p>When it comes to any of our ‘relationships’ with others (literally any friendships, siblings, colleagues you kinda–don’t–wanna–but–kinda–hafta sit next to, marriage, parents), there’s a simple acid–test we should be checking. Ready? Here it is: ‘Am I going in the right direction?’ But what does this question mean about navigating a world populated with friends and strangers? Well, all your thoughts, plans and decisions are either heading in your direction, or away from yourself and to God’s direction. And God’s direction is always towards the well–being of the other person. Guess it’s kind of obvious. We all have relationships we don’t enjoy, though: what about when they just keep getting it wrong, and we have to get all defensive? Or when they’re so full of gossip that it’s impossible not to join in (and maybe later gossip about them too?) Or when they’ve messed up but so have we, and still the easiest thing to do is just pass the blame entirely on to them? Hmm. When you are taking the trouble to bring about the best for another person, not to focus on their problems or mistakes, you’re doing it right. Choose not to gossip. Instead, make it a habit to give genuine compliments to others and build them up. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Josh 19:24-21:45; Luke 20:20-26; Ps 112; Pro 23:13-15 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62190&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>
