content.title: The Word, For You, Today (2) -- It's Oh So Quiet
content.introtext: '...I have treasured the words of His mouth more than my daily bread.' Job 23:12 NIV<br /><br /><p>Job could not find God. He just couldn’t. And it’s not like he didn’t try. The thing is, sometimes God chooses to be silent for a while. Sometimes He steps back. He’d never do it without good reason (and it’s frustrating when we don’t know the reason), but sometimes it’s necessary. The question that lives in that type of silence is: ‘How do you fill it?’ If it seems you can’t feel or find God, how do you navigate your life with Him? Well, the fact is, by some sort of Design, His words are always around. You guessed it. The Bible. Even if you don’t feel bird–sized butterflies in your stomach while you’re reading it, the Bible’s still speaking directly into the life you’re living. That’s what it’s there for. Job didn’t feel the presence of God for ages, but could still confidently say, ‘I have kept to His way without turning aside. I have not departed from the commands of His lips; I have treasured the words of His mouth more than my daily bread.’ (Job 23:11–12 NIV) He loved the words of God that He remembered from the past, even when God wasn’t speaking to him in the present. And that’s what kept him going. That’s what kept his life right when he couldn’t hear God in any other way. What are some Bible verses you should write out and keep in your wallet for those days when God seems silent? Commit them to paper today.</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: Col 1-2; Luke 20:41-47; Ps 78:1-8; Pro 23:19-21 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62192&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (3) -- Mmmmm, Milk!
content.introtext: 'Like newborn babies, crave pure spiritual milk, so that...you may grow...' 1 Peter 2:2 NIV<br /><br /><p>Let’s face it. We don’t always feel like reading the Bible. It’s all well and good to be told to ‘crave pure spiritual milk’ like that, but craving isn’t a choice, is it? Not exactly. But you can choose to make it a daily practice, steering yourself towards a place where it’ll happen naturally. Scripture mentions the need to get rid of ‘all malice and all deceit, hypocrisy, envy, and slander of every kind’ (1 Peter 2:1 NIV) before craving spiritual milk. It makes it seem like Peter thinks that it’s not possible to get to a place of true, honest desperation for Godly growth whilst having a heart full of hateful emotion. Hmm, curious that… Also, 1 Peter 2:3 NIV explains that craving good God–things comes from having ‘tasted that the Lord is good.’ You have to ‘taste’ your Bible (read it a bit) and notice the positive effects, before you can start to crave it regularly. The first step towards that is to commit to a routine. To make the decision to read a bit of your Bible every day. The second step is to actually do it. Even when you really don’t want to. Especially when you really don’t want to. And if you miss a day or two (or a week), pick it up again anyway from that day. Keep going. Then, maybe after a while, you’ll find that it becomes a part of your day that you look forward to. Get started then! Plan exactly when you’ll spend that time today, then actually do it. SoulFood will help you start. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Col 3-4; Philemon; Luke 21:1-11; Ps 78:9-16; Pro 23:22-25 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62193&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (4) -- Lifestyle Origami
content.introtext: '...You received His message... And this word continues to work in you who believe.' 1 Thessalonians 2:13 NLT<br /><br /><p>So, after taking yesterday’s advice onboard—what then? What do we do with the Bible that we read? Let’s look at 1 Thessalonians 2:13–14. It explains a sort of folding–out effect from getting close to God’s words—starting with hearing or reading them, and ending in living them out. Thessalonians 2:13 lays out the in–between steps that makes living the Bible possible. And they’re pretty interesting: (1) ‘You received the word of God…’ —That’s the reading, the listening. There’s no way around it. Read your Bible. (2) ‘You accepted it not as a human word, but as… the Word of God.’ —This is about recognising the value and authority of those words of God. It’s so important to remember the Bible is a Spirit–infused letter, full of God’s authority and knowledge. (3) ‘Which is indeed at work in you who believe’ —All of that Spirit, authority and knowledge of God that’s in the Bible… well, it’s ‘at work in you who believe.’ If you read God’s words and acknowledge the power of them, that power starts to work as part of your life. Then, after the reading, the accepting, and the having–it–work–in–you, comes the action. And it comes very naturally. Once you’re changed on the inside, the choice to ‘live it out’ should be an easy one. You’ll learn the best way to act from your Bible (Jesus is a good example for that), and find yourself more ready to follow it. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Neh 1-4; Luke 21:12-24; Ps 78:17-31; Pro 23:26-28 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62194&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Word, For You, Today (5) -- The Letter of the Law
content.introtext: 'Your promises have been thoroughly tested, and Your servant loves them.' Psalm 119:140 NIV<br /><br /><p>Psalm 119 is kinda incredible. It’s a really impressive acrostic poem (remember them? They’re the ones where the first letter of each line spells out a word or name) and it constantly refers back to the words of God. Every single thing that this Psalm says about God, or asks of Him, comes back to the Torah (the old Hebrew word for teaching or direction. It comes from an archery term and the idea behind it is instruction on how to hit a bullseye every time). It’s veeeeerrrryyy obvious this poet was extremely focused on it; he’s clearly read it a lot and constantly comes back to it. All of the stuff the poet knows about who God is circles back around to his knowledge of the Torah. There’s something we could (and should) learn from this. In 2014, Christians always seem to stress the relationship with God as the important thing. And that’s true. But, over the centuries, it’s possible we’ve lost touch with the fact some of that relationship is built through following the Bible’s instruction. We can get to know so much about God’s personality through the pointers He gives us in His Word on how to live. When we really get to grips with how to live as God wants, we automatically get to know Him better. Psalm 119 demonstrates it. When we read the Bible in a way that changes us and our actions, we open ourselves to being pulled a whole lot closer to Him. So, if you don’t already, why not dedicate a day a week to God as a ‘Sabbath’ holy day? Decide to rest, to make real time to dig into His written word (start with Exodus 20:8–11), and serve Him through serving those around you. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Neh 5-7; Luke 21:25-38; Ps 78:32-39; Pro 23:29-35 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62195&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Jesus the Mediator
content.introtext: 'There is one...mediator between God and men...Jesus.' 1 Timothy 2:5 KJV<br /><br /><p>You’re a professional bricklayer. We all are. We spend our days adding bricks to the wall that separates us from God. Most Christians call that wall ‘sin’. Call it what you will, it’s built to separate us from any sort of relationship with God–the–Father. And sin would’ve gotten away with it, if it wasn’t for Jesus. He came, He gave Himself up, and He tore down all the walls we ever built (and ever will build) between us and the love of God. That’s what 1 Timothy 2:5 means—that Jesus is the one who stands alongside humankind and God–the–Father at the same time. He communicates across the gap between us and God, and makes things right—He even prays on our behalf (see John 17 for details). When Jesus said, ‘No one comes to the Father except through Me’ (John 14:6 NIV), that’s exactly what He meant. No one can kneel, stand, sing, whisper, cry or anything before God if they don’t go to and through Jesus first. He fought and died for our right to be on good terms with God. And that’s the absolutely vital importance of Jesus in Christianity. If it wasn’t for the Master–Plan of His sacrifice, we’d have no place before God. We’d have no Heaven to look forwards to. Instead we’d have, well, nothing but outer darkness for company. Practical exercise: grab a scrap of paper. Write down the name of a particular sin you feel is really hard to shake off at the moment. Read your Bible. Pray that God will remove that sin away from your life through the power of His Son Jesus. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Heb 11:23-28; Exo 3; Exo 33:7-23; Exo 34:29-35 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62196&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Pardon True
content.introtext: '...The Lord forgave you, so you must forgive others.' Colossians 3:13 NLT<br /><br /><p>It’s fair (and right) to work through feelings of hurt, not deny them. But, forgiveness still has to happen. Have a look back at yesterday’s reading. Jesus stepped in to fix things between us and God. This hurt Them—the Father and Jesus both. It hurt Jesus in the shape of metal nails, whip–lashes, spears and a crown of thorns. And it came with its own soundtrack of the careless laughter of His enemies, alongside the heartbroken cries of His family. But He embraced the experience, full of forgiveness. Jesus shows there is a healthy way to get over hurt. Forgiveness is not about staying the victim, but about taking control through loving–but–strong action. He did it so we could be let off for all of the wrong things we still do. Wow. That’s inspiration enough to forgive the people who’ve acted really terribly towards us. Still, it doesn’t actually make it much easier to do. (And sometimes there need to be other steps first—like letting people know if you’ve been seriously hurt and it’s been kept secret.) But it provides the reason to. And, incidentally, the whole amazing plan of the Cross provides a bridge back to God as well as access to His power. And if anything can help you to forgive, it’s God’s power. Just ask Him. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Neh 8-10; Luke 22:1-13; Ps 78:40-55; Pro 24:1-4 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62197&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Knock Knock
content.introtext: 'Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.' Matthew 7:7 NKJ<br /><br /><p>In Matthew 11:5–8, it tells the story of some guy who knocks on his neighbour’s door in the middle of the night to ask to borrow some bread. The neighbour mutters to himself, rolls over, grumbles, rolls over some more and finally, because he can’t stand the guy’s continual knocking, opens up and gives the guy what he wants. All because he wouldn’t stop knocking. You see, God admires persistence. It’s not that He wants us to be rude, He wants us to know what love He has for us. He invites us to ask for what we need so that we will experience that love. He makes it pretty clear—‘Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.’ (Matthew 7:7 NKJ) If you want to hear from God, start up the conversation. Ask Him to speak. Don’t shout out from a distance, go right up to the door of His Word and knock. Steadily. He’s already on the other side of the door, waiting to answer. But don’t hightail it outta there as soon as you’ve pressed the buzzer once. Stay there, and make sure you’re ready for His response. It’s no good asking anything of God if you don’t make space and silence to hear back. Stay parked at the door of His Word, reading it carefully and you’ll find what you truly seek. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Neh 11-13; Luke 22:14-23; Ps 78:56-64; Pro 24:5-10 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62198&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Crossing Paths
content.introtext: '...By love serve one another.' Galatians 5:13 KJV<br /><br /><p>To work for God properly we have to have the right people around us, giving us the necessary pointers, handing us the necessary materials or just cheering us on when we need it. And God makes sure that happens. Whatever He’s planning for you, He’ll first drop you in exactly the right situation to make it happen just how He wants. That means He’ll steer you into the right place, at the right time, with the right group of people around you. That’s pretty good of Him, huh? All of the people around you are there because God wants them to be. Seriously. If you carry the person of Jesus in you (like… by being a Christian) then God will be arranging appointments for you. He’ll put people in your path. And they might just be the key to His next step for you, whether that’s by developing some part of your character, or by sending an opportunity your way. So take your relationships to God, the good along with the bad, and ask Him for the strength and maturity to recognise God–given people and opportunities. And make sure to be patient with every single person in your life. Extend grace to them constantly. Who knows what role they may end up playing in the future? And lastly, pray for those around you. Whenever you get the chance. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Micah 1-4; Luke 22:24-38; Ps 78:65-72; Pro 24:11-14 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62199&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: An Active Good
content.introtext: 'We know that all things work together for good...' Romans 8:28 NKJ<br /><br /><p>It’s a danger to stop Romans 8:28 right after the word ‘good’ as lots of people do. We miss some critical information that way. This verse packs a real punch. It calls for active life–changing. Take a moment to read it again, slowly, out loud. ‘And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose.’ (Romans 8:28 NIV) Try the same with John 14:21 NIV: ‘Whoever has My commands and keeps them is the one who loves Me. The one who loves Me will be loved by My Father, and I too will love them and show Myself to them.’ So, those who obey God love Him. And those who do that have everything in their lives sewn together for their good. If we want the ‘all things working together for good’ bonus, we’re called to live like God wants. We have to actually love God in our actions and thoughts, not just sing it in songs and tell Him in prayers every now and then. Re–reading Romans 8:28 with that thought in mind feels a little punchier. It’s no longer just something encouraging to say when someone’s had a bad day. It becomes a call to act in the way that Jesus teaches us to, in order to have a really good life. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Micah 5-7; Luke 22:39-53; Ps 24; Pro 24:15-18 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62200&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Jesus-Like (1) -- Humility
content.introtext: 'Your attitude should be the same as that of Christ Jesus.' Philippians 2:5 NIV<br /><br /><p>Think about all the rights we have enshrined in Australian law. The right to education, free speech and communication, to live free of all sorts of discrimination. But, sometimes, we can cling to our ‘rights’ until our fingers turn blue and we’re kicking and climbing on others to keep hold of what we think we’re entitled to. That isn’t Jesus–like. Think about it. Then check out Philippians 2:1–11. That’s right. Jesus ‘...did not think that being equal with God was something to be used for His own benefit... He gave up His place with God and made Himself nothing.’ (Philippians 2:7 NCV) He took on the status of a slave. A slave. The King of the universe didn’t see Himself as too entitled to anything to step right down onto this messy, ignorant earth. And He didn’t step down onto a comfy, shiny, golden throne; He placed Himself in a rough old animal trough. More than that—He died the death of a criminal. He definitely didn’t deserve that. And that’s our example to follow. If stuff that we don’t deserve comes our way (and it will, at some point), Jesus shows us that it’s our job to deal with it gracefully. We’re called to find the balance between living healthy lives for ourselves, and putting others (appropriately) first. Tricky, but it’s definitely do–able. That’s the way that Jesus lives. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Tim 1-4; Luke 22:54-62; Ps 19; Pro 24:19-22<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62201&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Jesus-Like (2) - On Offer Live like Jesus.
content.introtext: 'Grace and peace be yours in abundance through the knowledge of God and of Jesus our Lord.' 2 Peter 1:2 NIV<br /><br /><p>You’ve heard it. You probably aim to do it. Why, though? To show your friends what Christianity should look like? To make the world a better place? To please God? They’re all good reasons, and they all happen, in their own way, when our lives start to look more like that of Jesus. But God has a far more personal reason to ask us to imitate His Son. You see, the request for us to ‘live like Christ’ is an offer, not just a command. After He’s set you free from sin (and only after that), God offers a new way of life, filled with ‘grace and peace’. The fact of the matter is this: living that new, Jesus–style life is exactly what we were built for. So once we start allowing ourselves to act like God wants, we start to look like the person He designed us to be. That’s when that ‘grace and peace’ come into play. Making the decision to delve as deeply as you can into Jesus’ life, and putting what you learn into practice, won’t lead you any way other than towards God. And, the closer you get to God, the more you’re surrounded by His ‘grace and peace’. So, when He asks you to live like Jesus, what’s He’s saying is ‘come closer to Me, and life will start to feel as it should.’ And that is the ultimate offer of all time. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Zech 1-4; Luke 22:63-71; Ps 3; Pro 24:23-25 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62202&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Jesus-Like (3) -- Give It Heart
content.introtext: '...Leaving you an example, that you should follow in His steps.' 1 Peter 2:21 NIV<br /><br /><p>Jesus’ heart is geared towards others. He loves us, and He loves God. Everything about Him is built on His own relationship with His Father and the Holy Spirit, which is, safe to say, entirely perfect. He’s also intent on bringing us imperfect humans into that relationship. So, obviously, Jesus is pretty plugged in to the Holy Spirit and God–the–Father. Jesus’ first recorded sermon starts: ‘The Spirit of the Lord is upon Me…’ (Luke 4:18 NAS), and He went off alone to talk to His Father heaps of times throughout the Gospels. He’s so in tune and in love with the Spirit and the Father that they’re a constant feature of His words and actions. That’s a great model to live by. The way that God works (the Jesus–Spirit–Father bond) is the best model of living in relationship that you could wish for. It’s worth spending some time having a look into how Jesus lives it out in the Gospels. That others–focused heart is one of the foundation–bricks of knowing how to live like Him. If we’re raring to love and serve God and, by extension, the people He’s created, then being Jesus–like becomes more of a natural leaning. If you think you’re ready, pray to God that He will make your heart more like Jesus’. Ask Him to prompt you throughout the day to act in a Jesus–like way towards others.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Ki 17:1-6; 1 Ki 18:16-39; 1 Ki 19:9-18; 2 Ki 2:1-12 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62204&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Jesus-Like (4) -- Except Not, Though.
content.introtext: '...Take the yoke I give you. Put it on your shoulders and learn from Me...' Matthew 11:29 CEV<br /><br /><p>Have the last three days got you worried? Does the challenge to ‘live like Jesus’ sound too much? Stop, and maybe even write this down somewhere. The first call of Christianity is not ‘Live Like Jesus’. The first call is: ‘Come Home, All Is Forgiven.’ The call to live like Jesus is for after that. It’s for after you’ve come home, after you’ve been picked up and held safe by the Father of the universe. So if you’re worried that you’re not thinking, or acting, like Jesus, don’t panic your way out of His arms. From inside those arms you can watch His heart and thoughts close up. It’s only once you’re home that you can see how the Son deals with problems. Sure, we really want you to live like Jesus. (Fact is, we really want us all to live like Jesus...) Imagine what the world would be like if we all did. But if we allow ourselves to slip into thinking, ‘If I don’t live like Jesus... am I really a Christian?...’ we’ve allowed ourselves to swallow the secret lie that it depended on us being holy enough, or doing enough ‘things’ as a Jesus–copy. That’s not what the Cross was for. Living like Jesus is something that God grows (and not overnight) in the lives of those who have been called to Him whilst they were still dirty, tired, and broken. The only thing that every single one of us needs to ‘do’ is receive the love of His Father. The rest comes from there. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Zech 5-8; Luke 23:1-12; Ps 39; Pro 24:26-28 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62205&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: A Regular Chill
content.introtext: '...Let's go off by ourselves to a quiet place and rest awhile...' Mark 6:31 NLT<br /><br /><p>In today’s verse, we notice Jesus telling His disciples He wanted a decent bit of quiet time. Did He get it? Well, no. Not right then. They went off to find that ‘quiet place’ and got followed by crowds. Instead of a chilled Jesus–and–His–pals time, a little thing we’ve come to call the ‘Feeding of the Five Thousand’ happened. Not that relaxing at all. As soon as that amazing miracle was done, Jesus ‘went up on a mountainside to pray.’ (Mark 6:46 NIV) Just like the rest of us, Jesus needed time out. He had a busy, busy, busy life but He never allowed Himself to be overwhelmed by His work. When things were too hectic, He took Himself off, normally up a mountain, and spent a while away from everything. Just Him and God. Now, even though we don’t have crowds chasing us around, our lives can feel (nearly) as hectic as that of Jesus. And, just like His, our planned time off can be sniped far too easily, either by work or by that super–active eager friend. It’s so important to step back every now and then, sometimes to just do nothing (yes, that really is ok sometimes), as well as having those times to spend with God. So, pick a day. A whole day. Schedule it in as a day for nothing but rest, relaxation and time with God. Plan to do something you enjoy. And stick to it. Put it on your calendar now. Maybe even think about making that a regular thing… Yes! Actually have a Sabbath?! </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Zech 9-11; Luke 23:13-25; Ps 34; Pro 24:29-31 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62206&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Go, Fish
content.introtext: '...All...were astonished at the catch of fish...' Luke 5:9 NIV<br /><br /><p>Jesus never trained as a fisherman; His trade was carpentry. Yet, in Luke chapter five, He gave fishing advice to professional fish–catcher Simon and his partners. Simon had worked all night and seemed to have decided to follow Jesus’ advice more to humour Him than anything else. Despite showing more than a hint of doubt, he still did what Jesus said. He didn’t say, ‘Look, buddy, I’m the professional here. It’s not the right time to fish.’ He simply said, ‘Because You say so.’ It works exactly the same for us. Whatever our specialist area is, God knows what we need to do to max–out our potential in it. And He’s ready to share that know–how. The problem is, we often assume we know best. Or that God isn’t particularly interested telling us how to be the best essay–writer ever, or most–efficient barista ever to have worked the coffee bar. But if God’s placed you in a role, He’s the best person to advise you on it. Just ask Him. Don’t let doubt stop you from saying, as Simon did, ‘Because You say so.’ Taking God’s advice in the everyday can often be more important than it seems. Simon did what Jesus suggested concerning his fishing–job. Then, as soon as that was done, he found himself moving on to being a ‘fisher of men’. God’s current plans and instructions may be preparation for, or a sign of, bigger plans to follow. So, take Him up on His advice, and see what happens. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Zech 12-14; Luke 23:26-34; Ps 52; Pro 24:32-34 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62207&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Weighty Words
content.introtext: '...God...calls things that are not as though they were.' Romans 4:17 NIV<br /><br /><p>Umm, stop a second. Just think about that verse. God ‘calls into being things that were not.’ God speaks, and things that didn’t exist suddenly… do. That’s huge in two ways. First, only God has that power. The Bible definitely doesn’t say we call into being things that were not. It doesn’t say your parents or friends call into being things that were not. At the end of the day, no matter what effect we feel people’s words have on us, they don’t actually change anything. Just because someone you thought was your friend called you an idiot, doesn’t make it true. If your parents tell you you’re going to be a doctor, it doesn’t automatically mean it’s going to happen. On the flipside, it means that whatever God says is absolutely 100% true. Whatever He speaks comes into being. If He says you’re going to be a doctor, you will. And by Him saying it, it becomes a thing. A real–life, living–breathing, guaranteed thing. You need to have faith like Abraham and be “fully convinced that God [is] able to do what he [has] promised.” (Romans 4:21 ESV). We’ve pointed out God’s promises and declarations for you lots of times before. (If you missed them, then Romans 8:1 & Romans 8:31 should get you started.) Forget what anyone else has said. The only important thing is what God has said. </p><br /><br />SoulFood (Feast of Trumpets): Num 29:1-6; Matt 24; Rev 11:15-19; 1 Cor 15:50-58<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62208&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Don't Let Rejection Put You Off
content.introtext: '...His own received Him not.' John 1:11 KJV<br /><br /><p>We all come up against rejection. Jesus had a lot of it. ‘He came to that which was His own, but His own did not receive Him.’ (John 1:11 NIV) There are two examples of ‘His own’ here: His very own created universe, belonging to Him. And ‘His own’ did not receive Him; this means His people—those whom He chose and loved as His own didn’t want to be seen near Him. Ow. They even accused Him of being fake (check out Matthew 12:24, for instance.) When God gives you a passion for something, when you’re dead set on making a positive change, then it’s usually not a dead–end (unless you’re ignoring God–honouring motives and into something a bit reckless or stupid—worth asking your church leader if you want a double–check!) Jesus didn’t let one person’s voice silence Him, He simply moved on and took His life–giving message to whoever would listen: ‘...to those who believed in His name, He gave the right to become children of God.’ (John 1:12 KJV) So, what matters most, rejection or reaction? Whenever you feel put down by someone’s dismissal of you, going back to God first is your best bet. Don’t go into a knee–jerk defence, ask your heavenly Father to defend you. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Cor 1-3; Luke 23:35-43; Ps 54; Pro 25:1-3<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62216&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Treasured
content.introtext: 'Where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.' Matthew 6:21 NIV<br /><br /><p>Ever been to a pawnshop? The idea is simple; if you need money, you take a valuable item like jewellery or a musical instrument to the shop where the pawnbroker checks out the quality of it and gives you cash in exchange. But if you don’t return within the specified time to redeem the item, you lose ownership. Although it was yours originally, you no longer have legal possession till you buy it back. And if you wait too long, it can be lost forever. Have you ever thought of yourself as somebody who needs to be redeemed, so you can be returned to your rightful owner? God created us to enjoy a relationship with Him. But sin caused us to fall into ‘the snare of the devil...held captive...to do his will.’ (2 Timothy 2:26 NAS) Restoration to God, your rightful owner, could only come through redemption. And that’s exactly what God did! ‘For God so loved the world, that He gave His only Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have eternal life.’ (John 3:16 ESV) Christ’s death was the price of your redemption; that’s how much God values you! But redemption only becomes a reality when you realise you’re a sinner, and trust Christ as your Saviour. The moment you do, He reunites you with God—ransomed, redeemed, restored to your original owner. So the question is: have you taken up His offer of salvation, the one that makes you a member of His family? If you’re able to read this, it’s not too late. You can do it right now wherever you are. (If you’re a little hazy on what to pray, check out the inside back cover of this devotional for some help.)</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: 1 Cor 4-6; Luke 23:44-56; Ps 13; Pro 25:4-8 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62210&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Prodigal Son II -- The Return (1)
content.introtext: '...There was a man who had two sons.' Luke 15:11 NIV<br /><br /><p>Here’s a story you may have heard before. A father. Two sons. The younger brother wants out of the house. He leaves and messes up. On return, he is welcomed with open arms. Is this about leaving for uni? Nope. It’s about walking out on what our heavenly Father wants. He has an awful lot in store for His ‘children’, but sometimes we don’t want to live under His care. Now, let’s look a bit closer: Both sons had their faults: one was miserable, but obedient. The other, younger one was the classic rebel of the story. It’s hard to say who was really worse, deep down. Both of them were self–centred. You might not be the problem child, but (and we know this is rough to consider) do you have any traits of the jealous older brother? In the parable, the father says ‘…Everything I have is yours’ (Luke 15:31 NIV) to his older son. The older son didn’t seem to get that. He was worried about his kid brother getting an extra share of their inheritance. Sometimes, even though we’re right in front of the Father, we can be so focused on our ‘rights’ that we forget to look at Him for guidance. So, let's keep our eyes on Jesus. He's the 'older brother' of everyone who is part of the family of God and He gives us an example of how any 'older brother' should rightfully behave.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Heb 11:7; Gen 6:9-22; Gen 8:18-22; Matt 24:36-41 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62212&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Prodigal Son II -- The Return (2)
content.introtext: 'He came to his senses...' Luke 15:17 NIV<br /><br /><p>To fully understand exactly who God is, it might be we have to reach a low point. A really low point. Our own personal pig–sty can put the love of God that we’re missing back into perspective. It can lead us to the first part of repentance (turning back to God). So, it took a lot for the younger son to finally come to ‘his senses’, after walking out on all his father had for him. However, today’s curveball from word4Uday is another thought regarding the older brother in the story: was he guilty of something just as bad? In a house with his loving father, completely cared for, supplied with everything he needed, he still hadn’t come to his senses. Check this out: ‘…This son of yours who has squandered your property with prostitutes comes home, you kill the fattened calf for him!’ (Luke 15:30 NIV) Ouch. He didn’t think his kid brother deserved any favours… true, but neither did he. Unlike the younger son, he wasn’t aware of his problem: judgmentalism. He built himself up by tearing his ‘unholy’ brother down. As Christians, one of the first stumbling blocks we need to get past is simply accepting that God, our heavenly Father, loves us. Sounds simple, huh? But if we truly get our heads around it, that we simply can’t do anything to earn it, it makes accepting others a lot easier. That’s the kind of perspective on things that the younger brother had—he knew he wasn’t worthy. Think about what God gives us freely. Acceptance? Freedom? What else? Now, show some of that grace to someone who needs it—invite them into your life/friendship group and get alongside them. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Cor 7-9; Luke 24:1-12; Ps 91; Pro 25:9-12 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62213&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Prodigal Son II -- The Return (3)
content.introtext: '...He was lost and is found.' Luke 15:32 NIV<br /><br /><p>The last couple of days we’ve focused on the older brother in the parable of the prodigal son. There’s a lot there for long–standing ‘got it together’ Christians. But today, we thought we’d address the main character in the parable, the younger brother. Like his sibling, he didn’t fully grasp the nature of his father, but for different reasons. When he walked away from his home, he left all the good he could have freely had. Who in their right mind would do that? Everything he needed to live life to the fullest was right under his nose. That definitely sunk in later. And like the prodigal son, when we look back in hindsight at a good thing we’ve left behind, it’s easy to admit we’ve been stupid (think of the robes! think of the inheritance! think of the cake!) Finding yourself stuck in a rut with no strength left and nowhere else to turn is often when you realise you should have stayed in the house, where God’s got everything we need. But, in practice, turning back to God takes some real humility—we can either stick it alone, or run back home with nothing to show for what we’ve done. Yet, that’s what matters. Messing up is not the end of the story. Nope. The younger brother got up, and chose to admit his mistakes. The Father was waiting for the son with open arms. Do you need to come home today? Take a look at the inside back cover.</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: 1 Cor 10-11; Luke 24:13-24; Ps 68:1-18; Pro 25:13-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62214&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Prodigal Son II -- The Return (4)
content.introtext: '...All that I have is yours.' Luke 15:31 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Last one. Let’s wrap this up with three big points: (1) Anger holds you back. You won’t learn or grow if, whenever you see something positive happening in someone’s life, you take up the ‘older brother’ attitude of criticising it. Nah. That’s not good. We’ve all been there, and there’s no other way round it, if we’re ever to grow: along with the Father, we need to forgive and move on from the irritations that others might cause us. (2) ‘…Son…all that I have is yours.’ (Luke 15:31 NKJ) There it is, plain and simple: there was enough to go round for not just the prodigal son, but the older brother. When you notice God rocking someone’s life, He’s not forgotten you. And He certainly won’t hold back from blessing you beyond anything you could imagine. (3) God always listens. Sounds obvious? The older brother didn’t think so. But God says: ‘Let us then approach the throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need.’ (Hebrews 4:16 NIV) We reckon that, if the older brother just asked for help to overcome his bitterness, life would have even far simpler for him. If any one of those points resonates, make time now to be honest with God. It pays off.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Cor 12-14; Luke 24:25-35; Ps 68:19-35; Pro 25:17-20 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=63435&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Gold Standard?
content.introtext: '...When they measure themselves by themselves and compare themselves with themselves, they are not wise.' 2 Corinthians 10:12 NIV<br /><br /><p>Take a look at today’s verse (we couldn’t fit it all—definitely a good excuse for you to crack open your Bible… :) hint…) It’s a bit of a pressure–point in society today, but comparing themselves to others can make our lives difficult. Thankfully, it’s possible to find confidence in God. But, can it go both ways? Is it sometimes a little too easy to be comfortable in our own skin? Here it is: what about when we KNOW we’re good? Like, being humble is all well and good, but as soon as you know you’ve got an intelligence/ability one–up on your mates/colleagues, doesn’t it get a bit too easy to be happy with yourself, at the expense of relying on God for your self–worth? Well, those who are ‘commending themselves’ (first part of the verse), was written in reference to false teachers within the Corinthian Church who were big–noting themselves and criticising Paul and his authority as an Apostle. They thought they were 'all that', and pretty much nobody could touch them. Yet here, they (and we) are warned of assuming we’re the standard to measure by. So, how is it possible to really be good at something, but not compare yourself negatively with others who aren’t so good? ‘Let the one who boasts boast in the Lord.’ (2 Corinthians 10:17 NIV) That winning ability that you have? Don’t let your self–worth hinge on it: acknowledge that it’s God–given. Whatever it is, it’s meant to build others up, not for putting them down. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Cor 15-16; Luke 24:36-44; Ps 60; Pro 25:21-22 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62217&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Hide, or Speak?
content.introtext: 'When I am afraid, I will put my trust in You.' Psalm 56:3 NLT<br /><br /><p>Oi. You! Yes, you! Come out from behind that plant. Metaphorically speaking. In Genesis 3:8, Adam and Eve knew they’d done wrong. It was enough to make them need to change their fig–leaves (and they’d only put them on fresh about a verse ago, sigh). They were so terrified of the consequences they went and hid in some bushes. That didn’t work too well, either. God is good at finding people. So, why do we still try to hide? When that ‘sin’ happens, we can often try our very best to avoid God. We don’t want to face telling Him about it, or dealing with the aftermath. We don’t want to experience His disappointment in us. Or our own disappointment in ourselves. It’s easier to just keep our mouths shut, and hope we can carry on without having to face Him. But that’s not God’s plan. Life with Him isn’t some sort of monstrous game of hide–and–seek. Take a look at Genesis 3. When God found Adam and Eve, He started a conversation. He dealt with their mess. Then (in the first verse of chapter 4), He still helped them. You see, there’s always going to be consequences for our mistakes. But, when we take them to God and ask Him to deal with them, there’s still Life with Him in and after those consequences. So, trust God’s justice. Be honest with Him about your mistakes now, tell Him about them frankly. Deal with the consequences. And watch Him make something beautiful out of your life. </p><br /><br />SoulFood (Day of Atonement): Lev 16; Lev 23:26-32; Heb 9:1-14; Heb 13:11-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62219&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Making Heads or Tails of It
content.introtext: 'You are in error because you do not know the Scriptures.' Matthew 22:29 NIV<br /><br /><p>Remember playing Pin the Tail on the Donkey as a kid? As soon as that blindfold went on and you started to spin around, your other senses would go into overdrive to try and compensate. Could you sniff your way to victory? The world teaches us to rely on the stuff we can see and sense to be able to find our way. So when one or more of those abilities fails, we end up pinning tails nowhere close to target. But what if someone you trusted guided you all the way? What if you had a mate who whispered ‘Left a bit… straight ahead… up a centimetre!’ in your ear? Yes, it’d probably get you disqualified, but you’d also land right where you’re supposed to. Knowing and trusting God’s Word is a bit like that (except it’s not cheating!  happy days.) There will be plenty of times in life you’ll need to pin a tail blind, when you won’t be able to see clearly ahead. But you’ll still need to make wise choices. Taking the time to know what the Bible says about the things you might face is vital—it means that, when all your senses fail, you’re still right on course.</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: Heb 11:8-12; Gen 17:1-27; Gen 22:1-18; Jas 2:21-24 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62221&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Lucky Dip Living (1)
content.introtext: 'The Lord's instruction is right... His commands...give us light.' Psalm 19:8 CEV<br /><br /><p>There’s a hilarious section in Adrian Plass’ book, <em>The Sacred Diary of Adrian Plass, aged 37¾</em>, where Adrian opens his Bible at random. He’s in search of some encouragement, but lands on: ‘The dogs licked up the blood.’ (1 Kings 21:19, in case you wondered…) Not exactly the words of promise he’d hoped for! Do you ever do that? Wait until you’re upstream without a paddle and then go frantically scrambling for random Scriptures? Do you ever treat the Bible a bit like a lucky dip? ‘Must find a verse—ANY VERSE—to make me feel better!’ Psalm 19:8 CEV tells us God’s Word ‘makes our hearts glad’, that His commands ‘give us light’. But why wait until you’re in the middle of darkness to go lucky dipping for light? Instead, the Psalms say that God’s Word should be ‘stored up’ (Psalm 119:10–11 ESV) and Job says ‘I have treasured the words…’ (Job 23:12 NAS) Storing and treasuring take time and dedication, but it’s totally worth it for the sake of not getting into a flap when trouble comes. Count the Bible verses you know off by heart, not including John 3:16. Have you counted more than three? It’s useful to know Scriptures word–for–word, because there will be times when it helps LOADS to have those promises already stored in your head. Writing them down or saying them out loud might help you to memorise them. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 4-6; John 1:1-13; Ps 63; Pro 25:26-28 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62222&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Lucky Dip Living (2)
content.introtext: 'The entrance of your words gives light...' Psalm 119:130 NKJ<br /><br /><p>If you type ‘Bible or the Bard’ into an internet search, you’ll come face to face with a quiz that asks stuff like: ‘Who invented the phrase give up the ghost—Shakespeare or the Bible?’ Frankly, would you know where that phrase came from? It’s a decent exercise for letting us know whether we’ve spent more time in the sonnets or the psalms, but the Bible is so much more than just a collection of snappy catchphrases. So here’s where we level up and get serious. Paul says to Timothy, ‘Study and be eager and do your utmost to present yourself to God approved (tested by trial), a workman who has no cause to be ashamed, correctly analysing and accurately dividing [rightly handling and skilfully teaching] the Word of Truth.’ (2 Timothy 2:15 AMP) That’s a tricky verse to get your head around, but it basically says: ‘Get your head in the Bible. Know it. Understand it. Tell others about it.’ That doesn’t mean just memorising the bits of the Word that give you warm fuzzies. It means studying the bits you’d rather skip. Why? Because time and again we’re told that God’s Word—all of it—is a ‘light’, and not only for us, but for those around us too. Started with SoulFood yet? Had a try but found it too hard to keep going? Ask God for help as you switch on the ‘light’ and begin again. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 7-9; John 1:14-28; Ps 92; Pro 26:1-3<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62223&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Recognising Trouble When It Walks In
content.introtext: 'In this world you will have trouble...' John 16:33 NIV<br /><br /><p>We’re told not to worry about our lives (Matthew 6:25), but it’s also vital not to be naïve. Wearing a WWJD wristband does not make you exempt from life’s issues—and if Jesus Himself says trouble is a certainty, you can be sure that sooner or later it’ll be doing more than knocking on your door, it’ll be kicking it down. You could encounter any number of testing scenarios—health issues, relationship breakdowns, money worries; a whole bunch of things that could potentially stare you out and threaten to take you down like the Incredible Hulk on a bad day. But the next bit of today’s verse in John 16:33 is the ultimate save–the–day line. Jesus says: ‘But take heart! For I have overcome the world.’ Note Jesus doesn’t say that all the trouble will evaporate. Instead, He’s pointing you out to the bigger picture—a picture of the endgame. You don’t need to sit there paranoid and wondering when the next battle is coming, because He told you 2000 years ago that it’s already taken care of. And just in case there’s any doubt about the outcome, here’s a hint: you in Him = win. So, armour up today. Read Ephesians 6:10–20 to remind yourself of the spiritual weapons at your disposal: helmet of salvation, breastplate of righteousness, belt of truth, shield of faith, sword of the Word of God, shoes of the preparation for the Gospel of peace and, capping them all, prayers and songs of praise. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 10-12; John 1:29-42; Ps 29; Pro 26:4-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62224&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Withstand Bullets
content.introtext: 'Do not be dismayed, for I am your God.' Isaiah 41:10 NIV<br /><br /><p>In <em>The Matrix</em>, Neo discovers his mind has the ability to create and affect the world around him. He can withstand bullets, jump 50-metre gaps, and bend spoons—just by focusing all of his mental energy on the ‘truth’ (and by engaging his intense stare/squared–jaw combo, naturally). He learns the hard way that, the moment he loses sight of that ‘truth’, the world around him has the ability to crush him. The battle is primarily in his mind. The Bible says that the truth sets you free (John 8:32 NIV), but that’s not a one–time event. Your mind is a battleground, and knowing Jesus doesn’t make you immune to very real attacks of despair, fear or self–pity. Sometimes, we just don’t have the mental energy, and that’s ok. But the ability to remind yourself of His truth in the middle of the turmoil is the difference between withstanding the enemy’s ‘bullets’ or not. Verses like Joshua 1:9 ‘I am the Lord your God, and I will be there to help you wherever you go’, Deuteronomy 31:6 Be strong and courageous... the Lord your God goes with you; He will never leave you...’, Jeremiah 15:20 ‘I am with you to rescue and save you,’ says the Lord, Isaiah 12:2 ‘The Lord Himself is my strength and my defence’ and many more exist to make you strong when the world tries to crush you. They are the kind of truth to build your life on. As soon as the worries start to wage war in your head, declare with certainty: ‘I will not be afraid. The Lord God Himself will fight for me.’ </p><br /><br />SoulFood (Feast of Tabernacles): Lev 23:33-44; John 7:1-40; Zech 14:16-21 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62225&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: How Sweet the Sound
content.introtext: '...the true worshippers will worship the Father in spirit and in truth...' John 4:23 NIV<br /><br /><p>You may not believe your ten minutes of wailing <em>Amazing Grace</em> in the shower does a whole lot, but the Bible says that worship packs quite a punch. Ever heard the story of Jehoshaphat? His people were about to be smashed to bits by a huge enemy army. Jehoshaphat didn’t hang about. He went straight to God and reminded Him, ‘You are so powerful that no one can defeat You’ (2 Chronicles 20:6 CEV), and God—through a prophet called Jahaziel—replied, ‘You won’t even have to fight... the Lord will be there with you.’ (2 Chronicles 20:17 CEV) Jehoshaphat led his army out to the battlefield, and told the worshippers to get right out there in front and sing praises to God. As soon as they started to sing, God did all the fighting on their behalf. He confused the opposition, and they began to wipe each other out. Nobody in Jehoshaphat’s army raised a weapon. Pretty soon ‘every soldier in the enemy’s army was lying dead on the ground.’ (2 Chronicles 20:24 CEV) As soon as you see an enemy on the horizon—whatever that might look like to you—don’t waste time. Seek God and worship him. See, worship requires you to look up to God. And if you’re looking up, you can’t navel–gaze (unless you’re one of those ‘gifted’ folk who can do multi–directional staring...) When you focus on His power instead of your problem, He moves on your behalf. So if you have a tendency to wallow, it would be a good idea to create an anti–navel–gazing playlist, and make your first port of call Psalm 42. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 13-15; John 1:43-51; Ps 131; Pro 26:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62226&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Dodgy Sat-Nav
content.introtext: 'Lead me, O Lord... make straight Your way before me.' Psalm 5:8 NIV<br /><br /><p>Ever had the Sat-Nav take you to a dead–end street rather than the highway on–ramp you were expecting? Or failed to re–direct you off that one–way street or the access to the river? Do you still remember the smash or the splash? When it comes to the question of your life’s direction, you don’t want to rely on a dodgy Sat-Nav to steer you the right way. Here are a few navigation systems to avoid: (1) <em>Your emotions</em>. Very rarely will raw feelings about something point you down the right path. These powerful little hormone combos make up a large part of who we are, but emotions are also very changeable. Handle with care. (2) <em>Your mind</em>. Sometimes God’s direction just doesn’t seem logical at all. Rub mud into a man’s eyes and he’ll see (John 9:11). Throw your net down for the thousandth time, and you’ll finally catch some fish (John 21:5–6). Sounds a bit strange, right? Except, God says clearly, ‘My thoughts are nothing like your thoughts... My ways are far beyond anything you could imagine.’ (Isaiah 55:8 NLT) (3) <em>Well–meaning people</em>. When someone starts a sentence with ‘God told me to tell you that...’ resist the urge to take everything at face value immediately. (Or to dismiss it!) Whilst God absolutely does use people to deliver His messages, sometimes people get things wrong. Go to God for yourself. Ask Him. There’s a lot of stuff out there promising to show us the right way, when really what we need is a solid, close relationship with God and a hunger for his Word.</p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 16-18; John 2:1-11; Ps 23; Pro 26:10-12 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62228&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Correction, Consequence and the Small Voice
content.introtext: '...The Lord corrects everyone He loves...' Proverbs 3:12 CEV<br /><br /><p>What does God’s correction look like? Back in the Old Testament, the consequences of messing up were steeeeeep. Plagues of locusts, rivers of frogs and pillars of salt, anyone? Jesus came so that, if we believe in Him, we don’t get punished like we deserve. But that doesn’t mean God sits idly by while we get on with crazy living. Correction, rather than punishment, is a sign of a God who loves us and wants the best for us. Sometimes correction might come in the form of direct consequence. If you get drunk and end up throwing up all over your new shoes, you might think again before drinking too much, right? Alternatively, correction might feel like a quiet spiritual prompting. A tiny voice inside that says, ‘Not that way...’ And you can choose—because you can always choose—whether or not you listen. Part of the point of being corrected is so that you don’t stay the same. Romans 12:2 NIV says ‘...be transformed by the renewing of your mind...’ and in 2 Corinthians 3:18, Paul says that we’re all ‘...being transformed...’ into God’s likeness. That process requires change, and—yes—correction. The key is to lift your gaze from your correction to His process. Take a moment today to think about the ways you feel God corrects you. Do you need to become more sensitive to His nudges? Could you do with learning from the consequences of a lesson you’ve repeated over and over? </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 19-21; John 2:12-25; Ps 110; Pro 26:13-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62230&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Does God Really Heal?
content.introtext: '...I am the Lord, who heals you.' Exodus 15:26 NIV <br /><br /><p>Does God really heal? Let’s cut to the chase: God calls Himself a healer, Jesus spent a lot of miracle–hours healing people, the Holy Spirit is more powerful and loving that we can even begin to imagine. So we can safely say that yes—God can and does heal people today. But that’s really easy to say before someone we love gets diagnosed with cancer, or the doctor says we’re injured beyond repair. Believing in God for healing is a whole other ballgame when facing sickness head–on. And then there are the healings that don’t ever come: the times when our faith gets shaken out and thumped hard because we just don’t understand why. So we wrestle with the idea that God is still good and powerful when it feels like He’s nowhere. And we wonder if we prayed the ‘wrong way’, or not enough. And all the while the pain of disappointment sits on our chest like a double–decker bus... There is a choice to be made. Either God is a liar, or He’s telling the truth. If He’s telling the truth, then perhaps our perception of healing is incomplete. Perhaps it’s possible to face sickness, and still know total peace—and even joy. Perhaps, when it feels like God’s ignoring you, He’s actually healing the stuff that’s unseen. Here’s a thought from CS Lewis: ‘God whispers to us in our pleasures, speaks in our conscience, but shouts in our pain. It is His megaphone to rouse a deaf world.’ Is He whispering, speaking or shouting to you today? </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 22-24; John 3:1-21; Ps 89:1-14; Pro 26:17-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62231&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Chasing Payments
content.introtext: 'They are...to be rich in good works, to be generous and ready to share...so that they may take hold of that which is truly life.' 1 Timothy 6:18-19 ESV<br /><br /><p>How rich do you want to be? You might have ambitions to be a millionaire or even just to be ‘comfortable’, but have you considered what the Bible says about you and money? For a start, nothing we possess actually belongs to us: it’s all God’s (Psalm 24:1). So no matter how hard you struggle to acquire more, you’re still only ever the caretaker of it. That truth is actually really freeing: it means that the pressure is off. You’re not defined by the size of your bank account and you can start trusting God to bless you so you have enough to give to others, without sorrow for yourself. (Proverbs 10:22) God’s hugely keen on stewardship—that is, the way you manage the stuff He gives you. Are you stingy? Are you reckless? Are you self–centred when it comes to money? Don’t expect Him to bless you with very much of it then. The Bible is clear about generosity. It’s also clear about taking responsibility: in Luke 16:11, Jesus says that, if you can’t be trusted with worldly wealth, you won’t be trusted with ‘true riches’. What have you been given? You might have a job, a part–time job or an allowance; whatever it is, you’ve been entrusted with it. So start thinking about ways you can be generous with it. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 25-27; John 3:22-36; Ps 89:15-37; Pro 26:20-22 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62232&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Rules Rule?
content.introtext: 'If we receive God's approval by obeying the laws in the Scriptures, then Christ's death was pointless.' Galatians 2:21 GWT<br /><br /><p>Grace (the undeserved love that God gives us) doesn’t give anyone permission to live as they please just saying: ‘God loves me so it doesn’t matter’ but the ‘judgmentalism’ that comes from insisting others live by our standards has caused untold damage. Chuck Swindoll writes, ‘Legalism spreads a paralysing venom... blinds our eyes, dulls our edge and arouses pride in our heart... Love is overshadowed by a mental clipboard with a long check–list... requiring others to measure up... Soon friendship is fractured by a judgmental attitude and a critical look.’ Think you’re not guilty? Check out your own attitude when you meet another Christian who doesn’t think, act or dress the way you do. You might break out a fake smile to disguise your real feelings but what is your head thinking? It doesn’t take long before your mouth is talking! Jesus said, ‘Never criticise... or it will all come back on you.’ (Luke 6:37 TLB) When you throw mud you don’t just get your hands dirty, you lose ground! ‘If any one of you is without sin, let him be the first to throw a stone at her.’ (John 8:7 NIV) Blowing another person’s light out won’t make yours shine brighter. Paul writes: ‘If we receive God’s approval by obeying the laws in the Scriptures, then Christ’s death was pointless.’ You say, ‘What if someone is deliberately sinning?’ Paul answers: ‘...humbly help that person back onto the right path... be careful not to fall into the same temptation yourself.’ (Galatians 6:1 NLT) It’s good that we try to live God’s way but it isn’t a competition. Build people up, don’t knock them down and show them the grace that God has shown you. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 28-29; John 4:1-12; Ps 89:38-52; Pro 26:23-26 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62233&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Ask God for what you want!
content.introtext: 'The reason you don't have what you want is... you don't ask God.' James 4:2 TLB<br /><br /><p>Imagine walking into your local Chinese takeaway and asking if your order is ready. ‘When did you phone it in?’ the server asks. ‘Oh I didn’t,’ you reply, ‘I just thought perhaps you’d have something with my name on it.’ Sound ridiculous? No more so than expecting God to answer requests you haven’t made. The book of James says, ‘The reason you don’t have what you want is... you don’t ask God.’ Does that mean He’ll automatically give you everything you ask for? No. James adds, ‘Even when you do ask you don’t get it because... you want only what will give you pleasure.’ (James 4:3 TLB) Your motives need to be in tune with what God knows is best for you. John says, ‘This is the confidence... we have in Him... if we ask anything... according to His will...He...hears.’ (1 John 5:14 AMP) Lamentations 3:25 AMP says, ‘The Lord is good to those who wait... expectantly for Him.’ Expectant prayer demonstrates confidence in God’s goodness. Instead of stressing out and taking matters into your own hands, say, ‘Lord, I’m going to trust you with this, no matter what happens,’ so He can honour your faith. Do you need a job? Help overcoming a problem? Do your friends or family need to become Christians? Need a deeper walk with God? Do you need physical or emotional healing? Jesus said, ‘It gives your Father great happiness to give you the [benefits of His] Kingdom.’ (Luke 12:32 NLT) God wants to be good to you, so tell Him the ‘desires of your heart’. (Psalm 37:4 NKJ) Thank Him that the answer will come in His time! </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 30-32; John 4:13-26; Ps 100; Pro 26:27-28 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62234&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Life is what you make it
content.introtext: 'Always full of the joy of the Lord, and always thankful.' Colossians 1:11-12 TLB<br /><br /><p>Once there was an old and very wise man. Every day he and his granddaughter would sit outside a petrol station in his rocking chair, waiting to greet tourists as they passed through their small town. One day a tall man, who surely had to be a tourist, began looking around as if he were checking out the area for a place to live. ‘So what kind of town is this?’ he asked. The old man replied, ‘Well, what kinda town are you from?’ The tourist said, ‘One where everyone is very critical of each other. It’s a real negative place to live.’ The old man said: ‘Well, y’know, that’s just how this town is.’ Later, a family passing through also stopped for petrol. The father stepped out and asked the old man, ‘Is this town a good place to live?’ He replied, ‘Well, what about the town you’re from?’ The father said, ‘In the town I’m from everyone is very close and always willing to lend a helping hand. I really hate to leave it.’ The old man smiled and said, ‘Well, y’know, that’s a lot like this town.’ After the family had left the granddaughter looked up and asked, ‘Grandpa, how come when the first man came you told him this was a terrible place to live, yet when that family came you told them it was wonderful?’ The old man looked down into his granddaughter’s wondering blue eyes and said, ‘No matter where you go, you take your attitude with you. And that’s what makes it terrible or wonderful.’ Life is what you make it! </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 33-35; John 4:27-38; Ps 32; Pro 27:1-3 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62235&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: THREE 'R's
content.introtext: '...all of this is a gift from God, who brought us back to himself through Christ. And God has given us this task of reconciling people to him.' (2 Corinthians 5:18 NLT)<br /><br /><p>Reconciliation. Restoring relationships. That’s what the Cross does. It changes everything. The moment we give ourselves fully over to God because of that Cross, life changes completely. Nothing will ever be the same again. And if we think that stops at us, we’re totally wrong. What starts in our individual lives has a ripple effect, out into the lives of others. Pastor Matt Chandler puts it like this: ‘Think of the Gospel as a stone landing in a pond. The life, death, and resurrection of Jesus are the cause of many ripples; they are the epicentre of God’s work in the world.’ And he reckons the ripples go out like this: (1) The first restores our personal relationship with God. (2) The second helps us restore and create human–to–human relationships to make up the worldwide Church. (3) The third ripple happens when we move ourselves out and take the message of Jesus to those who are not yet a part of the Church. Essentially, what he’s saying is that God ‘reconciles’ us to Himself, and that makes us able to go out and let Him use us to restore other people’s relationships with Him. Once we’re brought back into that beautiful relationship with God, it only makes sense to share that with those around us. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Acts 13:21-22; 1 Sam 16; 1 Sam 17:32-51; 1 Sam 24:1-17<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62236&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: The Woe Factor
content.introtext: '...I saw the Lord sitting on a throne...' Isaiah 6:1 NKJ<br /><br /><p>It’s absolutely impossible to have a real encounter with God and not be changed by it. Just look at Isaiah, and in particular Isaiah 6:1–5. After meeting with God, Isaiah said, ‘Woe is me, for I am undone! Because I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King.’ (Isaiah 6:1–5 NKJV) Heavy, yes. But the point is, Isaiah’s entire outlook turned around after one encounter with God. The guy was ‘undone’! You see, as soon as Isaiah gets a glimpse of God’s holiness, he immediately understands himself and his own mistakes. Butcher–turned–writer Simon Ponsonby puts it like this: ‘God doesn’t tell Isaiah he is sinful—He doesn’t need to. As light reveals darkness, God’s holiness exposes man’s sinfulness… he never saw it before, but then he had never seen God before.’ It all starts with seeing, with light coming to shine into darkness. That’s why it’s good to confess our mistakes to God and, in some circumstances, to other trustworthy Christians—asking God to shine that light, and allowing others to see it can help a whole lot. This is one of the (not–so–secret) secrets of finding a way past sin, and making positive changes to become more like Jesus. We all prefer others to see our ‘wow’ rather than our ‘woe’, but letting God shine a light into our darkest places is essential for our holiness. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 36-38; John 4:39-54; Ps 87; Pro 27:4-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62237&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Waiting Game (1)
content.introtext: 'How long, O Lord, must I call for help?...' Habakkuk 1:2 NIV<br /><br /><p>There’s one very good word you could use to define the Christian view of the world: ‘waiting’. This whole crumbling creation is waiting for the day Jesus returns and sets things straight once and for all. But in our own lives too, there’s often an agonising amount of waiting. Perhaps you’re waiting for an answer to a prayer? A breakthrough in a painful situation you’re facing? Mr or Ms Right? Well, you’re not the first person to struggle with the idea of waiting, and you won’t be the last. God said to the prophet Habakkuk, ‘The revelation awaits an appointed time … and will not prove false. Though it lingers, wait for it; it will certainly come and will not delay.’ (Habakkuk 2:3 NIV) Why did God say that? Well, it was a direct answer to Habakkuk’s question, ‘How long, O Lord, must I call for help, but you do not listen?’ Waiting is never easy. So what should we do? Make it active waiting: pour yourself into the job at hand; otherwise you’ll short–change your own future. Even if it feels like all you’re doing is standing on God’s promises, waiting for change, keep at it. Sighing and resorting to twiddling your thumbs won’t go towards anything. James writes, ‘Be patient… See how the farmer waits for the land to yield its valuable crop and how patient he is for the autumn and spring rains. You too, be patient and stand firm.’ (James 5:7–8 NIV) So: next time you’re in a queue, make use of that time. Pick a person out, and silently pray for them the whole time you’re waiting. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Exo 39-40; John 5:1-15; Ps 41; Pro 27:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62238&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Waiting Game (2)
content.introtext: '...I will wait, 'til my change comes.' Job 14:14 NKJ<br /><br /><p>Sometimes the most helpful advice for living comes from the natural world. A mud–covered and unnoticed seed becomes a giant, fruit–bearing plant after weeks in the dark, suffocating underground. Then the shoot that forms must force its way out to be seen by everyone for its beauty. It’s not quick, and it’s probably not much fun for the seed. The same is true for your life in God: when you don’t rush His purpose in your life, the results will be powerful, and unexpectedly good. Perhaps you’re thinking, ‘I can’t wait for this (job contract / school term / illness / loneliness / unemployment* (*delete as applicable) to be over.’ That’s understandable—Job couldn’t either. He said, ‘All the days of my hard service I will wait, ’til my change comes.’ But by God’s grace he made it, and ended up with twice as much as he lost. Twice as much. So hold on, your change is coming. God won’t give up on you, so don’t give up on Him. He’s working through you as we speak, you know... Perhaps something is ending that has to end, so that something better can come through. God never disappoints; don’t look at what’s going around you without seeing it through His eyes. Ecclesiastes 3:1 tells us there is a right time for all things and a season for every activity—including waiting! </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Isa 1-3; John 5:16-30; Ps 15; Pro 27:10-12 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62239&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Way Ahead of You
content.introtext: 'Go to the land I will show you ... and I will bless you.' Genesis 12:1-2 NIV<br /><br /><p>Nobody likes to be the first to arrive at a party, and it’s a brave thing to show up alone to an event where you might not know anyone. Most of us chicken out and try to pitch up with at least one other friend (or lurk in the doorway till we see a familiar face...) What is it we’re so afraid of? Looking like a fool or a Billy–no–mates? Maybe it’s the fear that our friend might not show up at all. If we’re honest, we sometimes think God might leave us hanging too. What if I go and You don’t come through for me? But if God’s called you to go, you can be sure He will show. In fact, He won’t just turn up, He’ll get there before you do. Abraham discovered this to be true: ‘By faith Abraham, when called to go to a place he would later receive as his inheritance, obeyed and went, even though he did not know where he was going.’ (Hebrews 11:8 NIV) Read his story and you’ll see how God went ahead of him, working things out for him and his family, rearranging circumstances to his advantage. Here’s a verse to copy into the front of your Bible: ‘I am the Lord your God, who teaches you what is best for you, who directs you in the way you should go.’ (Isaiah 48:17 NIV)</p><br /><br /> SoulFood: Isa 4-7; John 5:31-47; Ps 5; Pro 27:13-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2014 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=62240&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>
